<div id="p-tb" class="vector-menu mw-portlet mw-portlet-tb">
	<div class="vector-menu-heading">
		General
	</div>
	<div class="vector-menu-content">
		
		<ul class="vector-menu-content-list">
			
			<li id="t-whatlinkshere" class="mw-list-item"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:WhatLinksHere/2023_in_American_television" title="List of all English Wikipedia pages containing links to this page [Alt+Shift+j]" accesskey="j"><span>What links here</span></a></li><li id="t-recentchangeslinked" class="mw-list-item"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:RecentChangesLinked/2023_in_American_television" rel="nofollow" title="Recent changes in pages linked from this page [Alt+Shift+k]" accesskey="k"><span>Related changes</span></a></li><li id="t-upload" class="mw-list-item"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:File_Upload_Wizard" title="Upload files [Alt+Shift+u]" accesskey="u"><span>Upload file</span></a></li><li id="t-permalink" class="mw-list-item"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;oldid=1280844559" title="Permanent link to this revision of this page"><span>Permanent link</span></a></li><li id="t-info" class="mw-list-item"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=info" title="More information about this page"><span>Page information</span></a></li><li id="t-cite" class="mw-list-item"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special:CiteThisPage&amp;page=2023_in_American_television&amp;id=1280844559&amp;wpFormIdentifier=titleform" title="Information on how to cite this page"><span>Cite this page</span></a></li><li id="t-urlshortener" class="mw-list-item"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special:UrlShortener&amp;url=https%3A%2F%2Fen.wikipedia.org%2Fwiki%2F2023_in_American_television" aria-haspopup="dialog"><span>Get shortened URL</span></a></li><li id="t-urlshortener-qrcode" class="mw-list-item"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special:QrCode&amp;url=https%3A%2F%2Fen.wikipedia.org%2Fwiki%2F2023_in_American_television"><span>Download QR code</span></a></li>

</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content hlist">

</tr></tbody></table> 
<p>In <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_television" class="mw-redirect" title="American television">American television</a>
 in 2023, notable events included television show debuts, finales, and 
cancellations; channel launches, closures, and re-brandings; stations 
changing or adding their network affiliations; information on 
controversies, business transactions, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carriage_disputes" class="mw-redirect" title="Carriage disputes">carriage disputes</a>; and deaths of those who made various contributions to the medium.
</p>
<meta property="mw:PageProp/toc">
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Notable_events">Notable events</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Notable events"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="January">January</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: January"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th>Date
</th>
<th>Event
</th>
<th>Source
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th>2
</th>
<td>During the first quarter of that night's <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monday_Night_Football" title="Monday Night Football">Monday Night Football</a></i> game against the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Bengals" title="Cincinnati Bengals">Cincinnati Bengals</a> at <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paycor_Stadium" title="Paycor Stadium">Paycor Stadium</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buffalo_Bills" title="Buffalo Bills">Buffalo Bills</a> safety <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Damar_Hamlin" title="Damar Hamlin">Damar Hamlin</a> went into <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cardiac_arrest" title="Cardiac arrest">cardiac arrest</a> and collapsed midfield after tackling Bengals wide receiver <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tee_Higgins" title="Tee Higgins">Tee Higgins</a>. Hamlin received treatment (including CPR and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_external_defibrillation" class="mw-redirect" title="Automated external defibrillation">automated external defibrillation</a>) on-field by stadium medical personnel, who were able to restore his heartbeat, and was subsequently taken to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Cincinnati_Academic_Health_Center" class="mw-redirect" title="University of Cincinnati Academic Health Center">University of Cincinnati Medical Center</a>
 in critical condition. (Hamlin came out of his induced coma on January 
5, with his neurological functions determined to be intact; he was 
released from UCMC on January 9 and returned to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buffalo,_New_York" title="Buffalo, New York">Buffalo</a>, where he underwent two additional days of evaluation at <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buffalo_General_Medical_Center" class="mw-redirect" title="Buffalo General Medical Center">Buffalo General Medical Center</a>
 before being released there.) After being suspended for roughly 45 
minutes with 5:58 remaining in the quarter, the game—which was simulcast
 on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a>, in addition to its regular broadcasts on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">ESPN</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN2" title="ESPN2">ESPN2</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN_Deportes" title="ESPN Deportes">ESPN Deportes</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN%2B" title="ESPN+">ESPN+</a>—was postponed. On January 6, the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL" class="mw-redirect" title="NFL">NFL</a> announced that the game would not be completed; <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022%E2%80%9323_NFL_playoffs" title="2022–23 NFL playoffs">playoff seeding</a>
 that was to be determined by the Bills–Bengals game was instead decided
 by winning percentage (factoring this, the Bengals would clinch the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AFC_North" title="AFC North">AFC North</a> championship title), and matchups were determined through <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL_playoffs" title="NFL playoffs">Wild Card</a> games (involving the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Dolphins" title="Miami Dolphins">Miami Dolphins</a> against the Bills, and the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baltimore_Ravens" title="Baltimore Ravens">Baltimore Ravens</a>
 against the Bengals) scheduled for January 14 and 15, respectively. The
 Bills and Bengals would each advance to the Divisional Playoffs, which 
saw the Bengals qualify for the AFC Championship, 27–10, in a January 22
 rematch against the Bills.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-:1_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-1"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>3<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>5<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>3
</th>
<td>For <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_View_(talk_show)" class="mw-redirect" title="The View (talk show)">The View</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s first episode of the year, current and former hosts (including original panelists <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_Jones" title="Star Jones">Star Jones</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Debbie_Matenopoulos" title="Debbie Matenopoulos">Debbie Matenopoulos</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meredith_Vieira" title="Meredith Vieira">Meredith Vieira</a>, the latter appearing via phone call due to illness) reunite to honor <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barbara_Walters" title="Barbara Walters">Barbara Walters</a>. Walters, who died on December 30, 2022, at age 93, created and produced the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a> daytime talk show, and was among its panelists from its August 1997 debut until her retirement in May 2014.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>5
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a> West Coast <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flagship_(broadcasting)" title="Flagship (broadcasting)">flagship</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KCBS-TV" title="KCBS-TV">KCBS-TV</a> and independent <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KCAL-TV" title="KCAL-TV">KCAL-TV</a>, both in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Owned-and-operated_station" title="Owned-and-operated station">owned by the network</a>, jointly rebrand their news department as <i>KCAL News</i>.
 The change takes effect with the launch of a six-hour local morning 
newscast on KCAL-TV, with a one-hour simulcast on KCBS-TV (which begins 
carrying <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_Mornings" title="CBS Mornings">CBS Mornings</a></i> live at 4 a.m. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Time_Zone" title="Pacific Time Zone">PT</a> along with the West Coast feed at 7 a.m. PT). Local and network management agreed to the <i>KCAL News</i>
 rebrand as a way to leverage KCAL-TV's stronger identity in the market,
 having been the first station to launch a three-hour primetime newscast
 in 1990.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>6
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dish_Network" title="Dish Network">Dish Network</a> removes 32 stations collectively owned by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mission_Broadcasting" title="Mission Broadcasting">Mission Broadcasting</a> (including <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPIX" title="WPIX">WPIX</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WXXA" class="mw-redirect" title="WXXA">WXXA</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albany,_New_York" title="Albany, New York">Albany</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WYOU" title="WYOU">WYOU</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scranton" class="mw-redirect" title="Scranton">Scranton</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilkes_Barre" class="mw-redirect" title="Wilkes Barre">Wilkes Barre</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KWBQ" title="KWBQ">KWBQ</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KASY" class="mw-redirect" title="KASY">KASY</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albuquerque" class="mw-redirect" title="Albuquerque">Albuquerque</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santa_Fe,_New_Mexico" title="Santa Fe, New Mexico">Santa Fe</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WNAC-TV" title="WNAC-TV">WNAC</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Providence,_Rhode_Island" title="Providence, Rhode Island">Providence</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KAMC" title="KAMC">KAMC</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lubbock" class="mw-redirect" title="Lubbock">Lubbock</a>, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KLRT" class="mw-redirect" title="KLRT">KLRT</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KASN" title="KASN">KASN</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Little_Rock" class="mw-redirect" title="Little Rock">Little Rock</a>) and White Knight Broadcasting (owner of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WVLA" class="mw-redirect" title="WVLA">WVLA</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baton_Rouge" class="mw-redirect" title="Baton Rouge">Baton Rouge</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KFXK" class="mw-redirect" title="KFXK">KFXK</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longview,_Texas" title="Longview, Texas">Longview</a>), after the satellite provider and the two <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nexstar_Media_Group" title="Nexstar Media Group">Nexstar Media Group</a>
 affiliate companies fail to renew a carriage agreement that expired 
that day. The blackout effectively leaves the affected Mission and White
 Knight stations without satellite distribution as both groups have been
 involved in separate carriage disputes with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DirecTV" title="DirecTV">DirecTV</a> (and co-owned <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DirecTV_Stream" title="DirecTV Stream">DirecTV Stream</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U-verse_TV" title="U-verse TV">U-verse TV</a>) that began in October 2022.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-auto3_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-12"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto2_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-13"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>10
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/80th_Golden_Globe_Awards" title="80th Golden Globe Awards">80th Golden Globe Awards</a> air on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">NBC</a> and stream on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peacock_(streaming_service)" title="Peacock (streaming service)">Peacock</a> from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Beverly_Hilton" title="The Beverly Hilton">The Beverly Hilton</a> in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beverly_Hills" class="mw-redirect" title="Beverly Hills">Beverly Hills</a>, with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jerrod_Carmichael" title="Jerrod Carmichael">Jerrod Carmichael</a> hosting. It follows a one-year absence from the network after NBC declined to air the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/79th_Golden_Globe_Awards" title="79th Golden Globe Awards">previous year's ceremony</a>
 in support of boycotts by various media companies, actors, and other 
creative individuals in the entertainment industry over the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hollywood_Foreign_Press_Association" title="Hollywood Foreign Press Association">Hollywood Foreign Press Association</a>'s lack of action to increase the diversity of the organization's board membership. Among television awards, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abbott_Elementary" title="Abbott Elementary">Abbott Elementary</a></i> was the top winner with three awards each ("<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Television_Series_%E2%80%93_Musical_or_Comedy" title="Golden Globe Award for Best Television Series – Musical or Comedy">Best Television Series – Musical or Comedy</a>", "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Actress_%E2%80%93_Television_Series_Musical_or_Comedy" title="Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Television Series Musical or Comedy">Best Actress in a Television Series – Musical or Comedy</a>" for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quinta_Brunson" title="Quinta Brunson">Quinta Brunson</a>, and "Best Supporting Actor in a Television Series – Musical-Comedy or Drama" for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyler_James_Williams" title="Tyler James Williams">Tyler James Williams</a>), tying with top film winner <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Banshees_of_Inisherin" title="The Banshees of Inisherin">The Banshees of Inisherin</a></i> (which won for "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Motion_Picture_%E2%80%93_Musical_or_Comedy" title="Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy">Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy</a>", "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Screenplay" title="Golden Globe Award for Best Screenplay">Best Screenplay</a>", and "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Actor_%E2%80%93_Motion_Picture_Musical_or_Comedy" class="mw-redirect" title="Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy">Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy</a>" for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colin_Farrell" title="Colin Farrell">Colin Farrell</a>)
 for the most wins overall among the ceremony's awards. The 80th Golden 
Globe Awards is the final ceremony to air on NBC before <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HFPA" class="mw-redirect" title="HFPA">HFPA</a> was rebranded to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_Globe_Foundation" title="Golden Globe Foundation">Golden Globe Foundation</a> on June 12, 2023.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-GGF_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GGF-17"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>12
</th>
<td>Nexstar Media Group ceases live streams of local programming 
(including newscasts) produced by its stations on their websites and 
mobile apps, instituting a two-hour delayed feed of each station's local
 programs in its place. The change is an apparent effort to obtain 
leverage in contractual negotiations with linear pay TV providers, amid 
Nexstar's carriage disputes with providers such as DirecTV, Dish Network
 and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verizon_FiOS" class="mw-redirect" title="Verizon FiOS">Verizon FiOS</a> (see January 6 entry as an example). Three of the group's major-market stations (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WGN-TV" title="WGN-TV">WGN</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago" title="Chicago">Chicago</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KTLA" title="KTLA">KTLA</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KRON" class="mw-redirect" title="KRON">KRON</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco" title="San Francisco">San Francisco</a>),
 and live breaking news and severe weather events covered by the 
affected stations are exempt from the change, which deviates from the 
now-standard practice of offering live newscasts online for the 
convenience of viewers who are unable to view them at home or who live 
outside of the station's home market.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>18<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>15
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/28th_Critics%27_Choice_Awards" title="28th Critics' Choice Awards">28th Critics' Choice Awards</a> airs on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_CW" title="The CW">The CW</a> from the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Century_Plaza_Hotel" title="The Century Plaza Hotel">Fairmont Century Plaza Hotel</a> in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Century_City" title="Century City">Century City</a>, with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chelsea_Handler" title="Chelsea Handler">Chelsea Handler</a> as host. Among television nominees, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Better_Call_Saul" title="Better Call Saul">Better Call Saul</a></i> had the most wins with three awards ("<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critics%27_Choice_Television_Award_for_Best_Drama_Series" title="Critics' Choice Television Award for Best Drama Series">Best Drama Series</a>", "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critics%27_Choice_Television_Award_for_Best_Actor_in_a_Drama_Series" title="Critics' Choice Television Award for Best Actor in a Drama Series">Best Actor in a Drama Series</a>" for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Odenkirk" title="Bob Odenkirk">Bob Odenkirk</a>, and "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critics%27_Choice_Television_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actor_in_a_Drama_Series" title="Critics' Choice Television Award for Best Supporting Actor in a Drama Series">Best Supporting Actor in a Drama Series</a>" for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giancarlo_Esposito" title="Giancarlo Esposito">Giancarlo Esposito</a>), while <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abbott_Elementary" title="Abbott Elementary">Abbott Elementary</a></i> won two awards ("<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critics%27_Choice_Television_Award_for_Best_Comedy_Series" title="Critics' Choice Television Award for Best Comedy Series">Best Comedy Series</a>", and "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critics%27_Choice_Television_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actress_in_a_Comedy_Series" title="Critics' Choice Television Award for Best Supporting Actress in a Comedy Series">Best Supporting Actress in a Comedy Series</a>" for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sheryl_Lee_Ralph" title="Sheryl Lee Ralph">Sheryl Lee Ralph</a>). <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Everything_Everywhere_All_at_Once" title="Everything Everywhere All at Once">Everything Everywhere All at Once</a></i> won five awards (including "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critics%27_Choice_Movie_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Critics' Choice Movie Award for Best Picture">Best Picture</a>", and "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critics%27_Choice_Movie_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actor" title="Critics' Choice Movie Award for Best Supporting Actor">Best Supporting Actor</a>" for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ke_Huy_Quan" title="Ke Huy Quan">Ke Huy Quan</a>) to become the ceremony's top winner overall and among film nominees. Special honors went to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeff_Bridges" title="Jeff Bridges">Jeff Bridges</a> (Lifetime Achievement Award) and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janelle_Mon%C3%A1e" title="Janelle Monáe">Janelle Monáe</a> (#SeeHer Award).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>19<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>20<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>17
</th>
<td><i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Daily_Show" title="The Daily Show">The Daily Show</a></i> begins its post-<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trevor_Noah" title="Trevor Noah">Trevor Noah</a> era, returning from a five-week hiatus with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leslie_Jones_(comedian)" title="Leslie Jones (comedian)">Leslie Jones</a> beginning a week-long stint as guest host. Jones is the first in a series of guests who will anchor the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comedy_Central" title="Comedy Central">Comedy Central</a>
 nightly program while the network determines a permanent successor for 
Noah, who ended a seven-year run as host in December 2022.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Deadline-12062022_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Deadline-12062022-24"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>24<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>19
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LIV_Golf" title="LIV Golf">LIV Golf</a> signs a multi-year deal with The CW to broadcast and stream its events beginning with the 14-tournament <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_LIV_Golf_League" title="2023 LIV Golf League">2023 season</a> (the first event being the LIV Golf Mayakoba tournament at the El Camaleón Mayakoba Golf Course in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solidaridad,_Quintana_Roo" class="mw-redirect" title="Solidaridad, Quintana Roo">Solidaridad, Quintana Roo</a> from February 24 to 26). The deal is the golf organization's first U.S. broadcast deal—its <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_LIV_Golf_Invitational_Series" title="2022 LIV Golf Invitational Series">inaugural year in 2022</a> was available only through <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a>—and the CW's entry into live sports telecasts. This deal was criticized by the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Press_Club_(United_States)" title="National Press Club (United States)">National Press Club</a> as an attempt by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>'s <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Politics_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Politics of Saudi Arabia">monarchy</a> (which finances LIV through a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Investment_Fund" title="Public Investment Fund">sovereign wealth fund</a>) to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sportwashing" class="mw-redirect" title="Sportwashing">sportwash</a> its unflattering reputation after their alleged involvement in the October 2018 <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_Jamal_Khashoggi" title="Assassination of Jamal Khashoggi">assassination</a> of journalist <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamal_Khashoggi" title="Jamal Khashoggi">Jamal Khashoggi</a>. As CW stations are only contractually obligated to air the network's prime time schedule, 14 affiliates (eight owned by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_News_and_Stations" title="CBS News and Stations">CBS</a>, five owned by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tegna,_Inc." class="mw-redirect" title="Tegna, Inc.">Tegna</a>, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weigel_Broadcasting" title="Weigel Broadcasting">Weigel</a>-owned <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WCIU-TV" title="WCIU-TV">WCIU</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago" title="Chicago">Chicago</a>) declined to air the LIV telecasts; CW majority owner Nexstar leased airtime on other stations in those markets.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>25<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>26<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>27<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>29<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">23
</th>
<td><i>CBS News Detroit</i>, a localized extension of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_News" title="CBS News">CBS News</a>'s <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_News_(streaming_service)" class="mw-redirect" title="CBS News (streaming service)">streaming service</a>, formally launches in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Detroit" title="Detroit">Detroit</a>. CBS-owned <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WWJ-TV" title="WWJ-TV">WWJ-TV</a>
 simulcasts the 6 and 11&nbsp;p.m. newscasts, with additional newscasts 
debuting on both platforms in the coming weeks. This marks a return to 
local news on WWJ-TV since a partially-outsourced morning drive newscast
 was cancelled in 2012. (An 11&nbsp;p.m. newscast, produced by co-owned <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WKBD-TV" title="WKBD-TV">WKBD-TV</a>, ran from 2001 to 2002, when the entire news service was shuttered.) The launch of <i>CBS News Detroit</i> was delayed throughout much of 2022 due to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_States" title="COVID-19 pandemic in the United States">pandemic</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supply_chain" title="Supply chain">supply chain</a>-related delays. WKBD-TV's 10&nbsp;p.m. news, originally produced remotely from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KTVT" title="KTVT">KTVT</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KTXA" title="KTXA">KTXA</a> in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dallas" title="Dallas">Dallas</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Worth" class="mw-redirect" title="Fort Worth">Fort Worth</a>, had already been relaunched as <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_News_Now" title="CBS News Now">Detroit Now News</a></i>, a hybrid national-local newscast featuring <i>CBS News Detroit</i> reports and content.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-vty-cbsnewsdetroit_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vty-cbsnewsdetroit-30"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>31<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bc-cbsnewsdetroit_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bc-cbsnewsdetroit-33"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-freep-cbsnewsdetroit_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-freep-cbsnewsdetroit-34"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pickleball#Professional_pickleball" title="Pickleball">Association of Pickleball Professionals</a>, now the Association of Pickleball Players, signs multiplatform deals with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_Sports" title="CBS Sports">CBS Sports</a>
 and ESPN to broadcast and stream its tournaments beginning with the 
league's 2023 season. In addition to coverage on APP's standalone 
outlet, APP TV, the agreements encompass eleven of the 22 APP Tour 
events scheduled for the 2023 season, covering streaming coverage of 
eight events on ESPN+ (beginning with the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daytona_Beach,_Florida" title="Daytona Beach, Florida">Daytona Beach, Florida</a>
 event held from February 8–12) and accompanying hour-long recap shows 
airing on ESPN2, and linear broadcasts of three additional events and 
recap programs on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_Sports_Network" title="CBS Sports Network">CBS Sports Network</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>36<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>37<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">24
</th>
<td>In the wake of felony charges of domestic abuse against him being made public following a court hearing on January 12, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adult_Swim" title="Adult Swim">Adult Swim</a> announces that it has severed ties with <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rick_and_Morty" title="Rick and Morty">Rick and Morty</a></i> co-creator <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Justin_Roiland" title="Justin Roiland">Justin Roiland</a>. The single-count charges of domestic battery and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/False_imprisonment" title="False imprisonment">false imprisonment</a>,
 to which Roiland pled not guilty in October 2020, were related to a 
complaint involving an alleged incident that occurred ten months prior 
with an unidentified woman. Following Roiland's exit, production of the 
animated series will continue with co-creator <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dan_Harmon" title="Dan Harmon">Dan Harmon</a> remaining as its lone showrunner, while the title characters, which had been voiced by Roiland, will be recast. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hulu" title="Hulu">Hulu</a> would follow suit the next day, dropping him from <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_Opposites" title="Solar Opposites">Solar Opposites</a></i> (the lead character of which he also voiced, in addition to handling showrunning duties) and the just-premiered <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koala_Man" title="Koala Man">Koala Man</a></i>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>38<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>39<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>40<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FCC" class="mw-redirect" title="FCC">FCC</a> issues a fine of $504,000 against <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox</a> for "willfully violating" regulations prohibiting the sounding of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergency_Alert_System" title="Emergency Alert System">Emergency Alert System</a>
 tones or the simulation of an EAS alert during television programming 
in the absence of an emergency for a November 2021 promotional segment 
that aired during <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_NFL_Sunday" title="Fox NFL Sunday">Fox NFL Sunday</a></i> for a game telecast involving the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Giants" title="New York Giants">New York Giants</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles" title="Philadelphia Eagles">Philadelphia Eagles</a>
 that followed the pre-game show. (The Giants won that game, 13–7.) The 
promo mimicking an emergency broadcast, described by Fox as a "short 
comedic advertisement", began with a three-second excerpt of the 
853&nbsp;Hz and 960&nbsp;Hz tones used to precede EAS alert 
transmissions, which the network admitted had been downloaded or 
recorded from a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a> video.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>41<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>42<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">25
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DirecTV" title="DirecTV">DirecTV</a> removes <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newsmax_TV" title="Newsmax TV">Newsmax TV</a> from the namesake satellite provider, and sister services DirecTV Stream and U-verse TV, after the company and network parent <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newsmax_Media" class="mw-redirect" title="Newsmax Media">Newsmax Media</a>
 fail to agree on a new contract. Although DirecTV cites aggressive 
carriage fee demands for the removal (while noting the wide availability
 of the network's content on its website and free streaming platforms), 
Newsmax accused the company of "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deplatforming" title="Deplatforming">deplatforming</a>" it and fellow <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservatism_in_the_United_States" title="Conservatism in the United States">archconservative</a> news and commentary channel <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One_America_News_Network" title="One America News Network">One America News Network</a>
 (which DirecTV removed in April 2022)—inferring an ideological motive 
for the decision, even though DirecTV continues to carry their main 
conservative rival <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_News" title="Fox News">Fox News</a>—and dishonesty about the network's fee increase offers. A group of 41 <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republican</a> congressmen led by Rep. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wesley_Hunt" title="Wesley Hunt">Wesley Hunt</a> (R-<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas" title="Texas">TX</a>) sent a letter to the CEOs of DirecTV and shareholders <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AT%26T" title="AT&amp;T">AT&amp;T</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TPG_Capital" class="mw-redirect" title="TPG Capital">TPG Capital</a> the week before, warning them of possible <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_House_of_Representatives_committees" title="List of United States House of Representatives committees">House committee</a> hearings over the impasse should the provider drop the network. Newsmax TV, as with OAN, has challenged the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2020" class="mw-redirect" title="United States presidential election, 2020">2020 presidential election</a>, earning support from former <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">president</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> (who is a personal friend of Newsmax CEO <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_Ruddy" title="Christopher Ruddy">Christopher Ruddy</a>) amid his criticism of Fox News for being the first television news outlet to call <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arizona" title="Arizona">Arizona</a> for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)" title="Democratic Party (United States)">Democratic</a> challenger <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a> in that election. DirecTV reached an agreement to resume carriage of Newsmax on March 22.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>45<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>46<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>As part of a multi-year agreement that also extends their carriage contract for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Court_TV" title="Court TV">Court TV</a>, the E. W. Scripps Company and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YouTube_TV" title="YouTube TV">YouTube TV</a> announce that the vMVPD service will add <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ion_Television" title="Ion Television">Ion</a> and digital multicast networks <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bounce_TV" title="Bounce TV">Bounce TV</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scripps_News" title="Scripps News">Scripps News</a>
 to its lineup, effective on this date. Under the terms of the deal, 
YouTube TV has the option of adding fellow Scripps-owned multicast 
networks <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grit_(TV_network)" title="Grit (TV network)">Grit</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ion_Mystery" title="Ion Mystery">Ion Mystery</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laff_(TV_network)" title="Laff (TV network)">Laff</a> at a later date.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>47<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">27
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ABC_News_(United_States)" title="ABC News (United States)">ABC News</a> officially cuts ties with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amy_Robach" title="Amy Robach">Amy Robach</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T._J._Holmes" title="T. J. Holmes">T. J. Holmes</a>. The two hosts of <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GMA3:_What_You_Need_to_Know" title="GMA3: What You Need to Know">GMA3: What You Need to Know</a></i>, who had respectively been with the network since 2012 and 2014, had been off the air since December 5, 2022, after a <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daily_Mail" title="Daily Mail">Daily Mail</a></i>
 exposé revealed they had been in a romantic relationship (and had left 
their respective spouses), an affair ABC described then as "an internal 
and external disruption" but not a violation of company policy (although
 an internal investigation would commence). On May 11, the news division
 named <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Good_Morning_America" title="Good Morning America">Good Morning America</a></i> weekend co-anchor Eva Pilgrim and correspondent <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demarco_Morgan" class="mw-redirect" title="Demarco Morgan">Demarco Morgan</a> to co-host <i>GMA3</i>, while transportation correspondent <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gio_Benitez" title="Gio Benitez">Gio Benitez</a>
 (who was among those acting as substitute hosts on the program 
following Holmes and Robach's departure) will take over Pilgrim's <i>GMA</i> weekend anchor slot.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>48<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>49<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deadline_Hollywood" title="Deadline Hollywood">Deadline</a></i> reports that <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNBC" title="CNBC">CNBC</a>
 will discontinue producing original entertainment content for its prime
 time block, emphasizing instead on reruns of reality and documentary 
shows (e.g. <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shark_Tank" title="Shark Tank">Shark Tank</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Greed" title="American Greed">American Greed</a></i>).
 The business news-oriented network's prime time had been home to 
first-run unscripted content that focused on wealth and lifestyle, 
including <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jay_Leno%27s_Garage" title="Jay Leno's Garage">Jay Leno's Garage</a></i> (whose cancellation had been announced earlier in the week) and the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_O%27Leary" title="Kevin O'Leary">Kevin O'Leary</a>-hosted <i>Money Court</i>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="3">30
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramount_Global" title="Paramount Global">Paramount Global</a> announces plans to fully integrate its <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Showtime_(TV_network)" title="Showtime (TV network)">Showtime</a> network with the premium tier of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramount%2B" title="Paramount+">Paramount+</a> streaming service, beginning on a future date yet to be announced. The combined service will be branded as <i>Paramount+ with Showtime</i>, replacing a bundle of the same name that launched in mid-2022.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FuboTV" title="FuboTV">FuboTV</a> loses access to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a> stations in 160 markets after their respective owners (including Nexstar Media Group, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinclair_Broadcast_Group" title="Sinclair Broadcast Group">Sinclair Broadcast Group</a>, the E. W. Scripps Company, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hearst_Television" title="Hearst Television">Hearst Television</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cox_Media_Group" title="Cox Media Group">Cox Media Group</a>
 and Tegna) declined to accept the terms of a renewed master affiliate 
carriage agreement negotiated between network parent Paramount Global 
and the vMVPD. A national CBS feed, offering most of the network's base 
schedule (excluding some live sports events) and news content from the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_News_Streaming_Network" class="mw-redirect" title="CBS News Streaming Network">CBS News Streaming Network</a>, was provided to substitute the affected affiliates. (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_News_and_Stations" title="CBS News and Stations">CBS's owned-and-operated stations</a>
 were not affected by the impasse as they were carried on a different 
carriage agreement.) Three weeks after the affiliate board approved a 
revised carriage deal, the affected stations began returning to Fubo on 
March 31.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>52<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>53<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Longtime <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KSAT-TV" title="KSAT-TV">KSAT-TV</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Antonio" title="San Antonio">San Antonio</a>
 sports director Greg Simmons resigns after 42 years, a decision made 
after his being charged for DWI. Weekend sports anchor Larry Ramirez 
would serve as KSAT's interim sports director.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>54<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>31
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YouTube_TV" title="YouTube TV">YouTube TV</a> drops <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MLB_Network" title="MLB Network">MLB Network</a>
 from its channel lineup after failing to reach a contract renewal 
agreement. Subscribers will be able to continue watching select national
 <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> games on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox</a>, ESPN and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TBS_(American_TV_channel)" title="TBS (American TV channel)">TBS</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>56<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="February">February</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: February"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th>Date
</th>
<th>Event
</th>
<th>Source
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th>3
</th>
<td>For the first time since 2015, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Shaffer" title="Paul Shaffer">Paul Shaffer</a> reunites <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_World%27s_Most_Dangerous_Band" class="mw-redirect" title="The World's Most Dangerous Band">The World's Most Dangerous Band</a> (the house band for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Letterman" title="David Letterman">David Letterman</a>'s <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Late_Night_with_David_Letterman" title="Late Night with David Letterman">Late Night</a></i> and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Late_Show_with_David_Letterman" title="Late Show with David Letterman">Late Show</a></i>) to fill in for <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Tonight_Show_Starring_Jimmy_Fallon" title="The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon">The Tonight Show's</a></i> regular house band <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Roots" title="The Roots">The Roots</a>, who were in Los Angeles preparing for a performance at the Grammys.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>5
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/65th_Annual_Grammy_Awards" title="65th Annual Grammy Awards">65th Annual Grammy Awards</a> airs on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a> from the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crypto.com_Arena" title="Crypto.com Arena">Crypto.com Arena</a> in Los Angeles. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trevor_Noah" title="Trevor Noah">Trevor Noah</a> serves as host of a ceremony that sees notable winners including <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lizzo" title="Lizzo">Lizzo</a>, whose "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/About_Damn_Time" title="About Damn Time">About Damn Time</a>" wins <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Record_of_the_Year" class="mw-redirect" title="Record of the Year">Record of the Year</a>; <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Styles" title="Harry Styles">Harry Styles</a>, whose <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry%27s_House" title="Harry's House">Harry's House</a></i> wins <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Album_of_the_Year" title="Grammy Award for Album of the Year">Album of the Year</a>; and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9" title="Beyoncé">Beyoncé</a>, whose four wins on the night (including <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renaissance_(Beyonc%C3%A9_album)" title="Renaissance (Beyoncé album)">Renaissance</a></i> as <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Best_Dance/Electronic_Album" class="mw-redirect" title="Best Dance/Electronic Album">Best Dance/Electronic Album</a>) push her career Grammy mark to 32, making her the most-lauded artist in Grammy history.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>58<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>7
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL_Network" title="NFL Network">NFL Network</a> removes analyst and former player <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Irvin" title="Michael Irvin">Michael Irvin</a> from its coverage of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_LVII" title="Super Bowl LVII">Super Bowl LVII</a> following allegations of sexual misconduct toward a woman at a hotel he was staying at in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoenix,_Arizona" title="Phoenix, Arizona">Phoenix</a> area, where the game will be held. Though surveillance video showed him interacting with the woman, Irvin told <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dallas" title="Dallas">Dallas</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Worth" class="mw-redirect" title="Fort Worth">Fort Worth</a> radio station <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KRLD-FM" title="KRLD-FM">KRLD-FM</a> and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Dallas_Morning_News" title="The Dallas Morning News">The Dallas Morning News</a></i>
 that he had no recollection of any incident because he had been 
inebriated, and denied any wrongdoing. Irvin would file a $100 million 
defamation suit against the anonymous accuser and the hotel on February 
9.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>60<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">8
</th>
<td><i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i> reports <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warner_Bros._Discovery" title="Warner Bros. Discovery">Warner Bros. Discovery</a> will continue to operate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discovery%2B" title="Discovery+">Discovery+</a>
 as a standalone streaming service, a pivot from the company's initial 
plans to shutter it entirely following the May 13 launch of its 
combination service <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_(streaming_service)" title="Max (streaming service)">Max</a>, which will feature most of Discovery+'s existing content library in addition to the full <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HBO_Max" class="mw-redirect" title="HBO Max">HBO Max</a>
 library. WBD cites concerns about Discovery+ subscribers opting out of 
moving to the pricier offering for the decision. (WBD has indicated that
 the combined service's ad-supported and ad-free tiers will be set at a 
higher price point than those of HBO Max and Discovery+.)
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>62<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NewsNation" title="NewsNation">NewsNation</a> correspondent Evan Lambert is arrested on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disorderly_conduct" title="Disorderly conduct">disorderly conduct</a> and criminal <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trespassing" class="mw-redirect" title="Trespassing">trespassing</a> complaints for allegedly disrupting a news conference by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_Governor" class="mw-redirect" title="Ohio Governor">Ohio Governor</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_DeWine" title="Mike DeWine">Mike DeWine</a> on the February 3, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Ohio_train_derailment" class="mw-redirect" title="2023 Ohio train derailment">derailment</a> of a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norfolk_Southern" class="mw-redirect" title="Norfolk Southern">Norfolk Southern</a> freight train containing hazardous chemicals that prompted residential evacuations in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Palestine" class="mw-redirect" title="East Palestine">East Palestine</a>. The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D.C." class="mw-redirect" title="D.C.">D.C.</a>-based correspondent was conducting a live report for the Nexstar-owned cable news channel's <i>Rush Hour</i>
 program when police officers inside the gym of the village's elementary
 school, where the news conference was held, told him to conclude the 
report while DeWine was speaking, and subsequently pushed Lambert to the
 ground and handcuffed him after acceding to their request. DeWine later
 condemned the officers' actions, clarifying he did not authorize 
Lambert's arrest. Lambert was released from the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Columbiana_County" class="mw-redirect" title="Columbiana County">Columbiana County</a> Jail later that evening on an $850 bond; he is scheduled to be arraigned on February 23.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>63<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>64<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>12
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Kansas_City_Chiefs_season" title="2022 Kansas City Chiefs season">Kansas City Chiefs</a> defeat the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Philadelphia_Eagles_season" title="2022 Philadelphia Eagles season">Philadelphia Eagles</a>, 38–35, in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_LVII" title="Super Bowl LVII">Super Bowl LVII</a> at <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_Farm_Stadium" title="State Farm Stadium">State Farm Stadium</a> in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glendale,_Arizona" title="Glendale, Arizona">Glendale, Arizona</a>, which was broadcast on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox</a> (in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a>) and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Deportes" title="Fox Deportes">Fox Deportes</a> (in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>), and streamed on the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Sports_(United_States)" title="Fox Sports (United States)">Fox Sports</a> app and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL%2B" title="NFL+">NFL+</a>. It was the first Super Bowl assignment for play-by-play announcer <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Burkhardt" title="Kevin Burkhardt">Kevin Burkhardt</a> and color analyst <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Olsen_(American_football)" title="Greg Olsen (American football)">Greg Olsen</a>, who succeeded <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Buck" title="Joe Buck">Joe Buck</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Troy_Aikman" title="Troy Aikman">Troy Aikman</a> as Fox's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL_on_Fox" title="NFL on Fox">NFL broadcast</a> team in 2020 after they were hired by ABC/ESPN to call its <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monday_Night_Football" title="Monday Night Football">Monday Night Football</a></i> and NFL playoff telecasts. The Fox telecast averaged 115.1 million viewers according to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nielsen_Holdings" title="Nielsen Holdings">Nielsen</a> data, becoming the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_most_watched_television_broadcasts_in_the_United_States" title="List of most watched television broadcasts in the United States">most-watched program in American television history</a> (just ahead of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLIX" title="Super Bowl XLIX">Super Bowl XLIX</a>), with viewership reaching 118.7 million during the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_LVII_halftime_show" title="Super Bowl LVII halftime show">halftime show</a> (headlined by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rihanna" title="Rihanna">Rihanna</a>,
 who revealed her second pregnancy with the performance); the Fox 
Deportes telecast was watched by 951,000 viewers, becoming both the 
most-watched Super Bowl broadcast and the most watched non-soccer sports
 telecast in Spanish-language cable history.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>65<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>66<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>67<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Inabinett_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Inabinett-70"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>73<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 1<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>15
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gray_Television" class="mw-redirect" title="Gray Television">Gray Television</a> sells Fox affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KNIN-TV" title="KNIN-TV">KNIN</a> in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boise,_Idaho" title="Boise, Idaho">Boise, Idaho</a> (operated by the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._W._Scripps_Company" title="E. W. Scripps Company">E. W. Scripps Company</a>) to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marquee_Broadcasting" title="Marquee Broadcasting">Marquee Broadcasting</a> in exchange for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MeTV" title="MeTV">MeTV</a> affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPGA-TV" title="WPGA-TV">WPGA</a> in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macon,_Georgia" title="Macon, Georgia">Macon, Georgia</a>.
 When completed, the deal will result in Gray owning at least one 
full-power station in nine of Georgia's eleven television markets. The 
deal was completed on May 1.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>75<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>16
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryan_Seacrest" title="Ryan Seacrest">Ryan Seacrest</a> announces he will step down as co-host and executive producer of <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Live_with_Kelly_and_Ryan" class="mw-redirect" title="Live with Kelly and Ryan">Live with Kelly and Ryan</a></i>, which he has hosted alongside <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kelly_Ripa" title="Kelly Ripa">Kelly Ripa</a> since 2017, to concentrate full-time on other projects (including his hosting duties on <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Idol" title="American Idol">American Idol</a></i> and his <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/On_Air_with_Ryan_Seacrest" title="On Air with Ryan Seacrest">syndicated radio program</a>). Ripa's husband, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Consuelos" title="Mark Consuelos">Mark Consuelos</a>, who has frequently served as guest host since she became co-host of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disney%E2%80%93ABC_Domestic_Television" title="Disney–ABC Domestic Television">Disney/ABC</a>-produced syndicated morning talk show in 2001, will succeed Seacrest on April 17 as permanent co-host of the renamed <i>Live with Kelly and Mark</i>. Seacrest—who will return occasionally to guest co-host—will continue hosting <i>Live</i> through April 14, at which time he will relocate to Los Angeles to host <i>Idol</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s live performance shows.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>80<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>22
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectrum_News_13" title="Spectrum News 13">Spectrum News 13</a>
 reporter Dylan Lyons is killed, and colleague and photojournalist Jesse
 Walden critically injured, in a shooting incident in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orlando,_Florida" title="Orlando, Florida">Orlando</a> suburb of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pine_Hills,_Florida" title="Pine Hills, Florida">Pine Hills, Florida</a>
 that also claimed the life of a nine-year-old girl and critically 
injured her mother. Lyons and Walden were at the scene of a homicide 
that claimed the life of a woman earlier that day. A teenager was taken 
into custody as a suspect in both incidents.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>82<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">23
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ellen_Pompeo" title="Ellen Pompeo">Ellen Pompeo</a> makes her last appearance as a cast regular on <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grey%27s_Anatomy" title="Grey's Anatomy">Grey's Anatomy</a></i> as her character, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meredith_Grey" title="Meredith Grey">Meredith Grey</a>, leaves <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle" title="Seattle">Seattle</a> and Grey Sloan Memorial Hospital for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston" title="Boston">Boston</a> in the episode "I'll Follow the Sun."  Pompeo has been with the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a>
 medical drama since its 2005 premiere, and remains attached as an 
executive producer and narrator, in addition to making occasional 
on-screen guest appearances, the next of which will be the current <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grey%27s_Anatomy_(season_19)" class="mw-redirect" title="Grey's Anatomy (season 19)">19th season's</a> finale in May.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>83<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dish_Network" title="Dish Network">Dish Network</a>
 is hit by a cyberattack that resulted in data being extracted from its 
IT networks; and the company's internal servers, customer support 
systems and company websites being knocked offline, with service 
disruptions affecting its co-owned vMVPD service <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sling_TV" title="Sling TV">Sling TV</a> and wireless provider <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boost_Mobile" title="Boost Mobile">Boost Mobile</a>.
 Dish and Sling subscribers also experienced difficulties accessing 
streaming apps (such as its Dish Anywhere service, OTT services 
purchased through Dish and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TV_Everywhere" title="TV Everywhere">TV Everywhere</a>
 apps of various networks carried by the Dish satellite service and 
Sling) using their provider logins. Some employees continued to be paid 
during the outage despite it preventing them from performing their jobs.
 Although Dish restored "many of the systems," including its websites, 
customer service operations and self-service applications within weeks 
of the attack, service disruptions and technical issues lingered into 
March as customers continued to report call center backlogs (some 
lasting up to 14 hours) and problems processing payments. Several Dish 
investors filed a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Class_action" title="Class action">class action</a> lawsuit over the breach on March 30, accusing the company of negligence in failing to properly secure customer data.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>84<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>85<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>86<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>87<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>88<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">24
</th>
<td>Warner Bros. Discovery informs the teams whose games air on its <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AT%26T_SportsNet" title="AT&amp;T SportsNet">AT&amp;T SportsNet</a> channels based in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AT%26T_SportsNet_Rocky_Mountain" title="AT&amp;T SportsNet Rocky Mountain">Denver</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AT%26T_SportsNet_Southwest" class="mw-redirect" title="AT&amp;T SportsNet Southwest">Houston</a>, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AT%26T_SportsNet_Pittsburgh" class="mw-redirect" title="AT&amp;T SportsNet Pittsburgh">Pittsburgh</a> that the company will exit the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_sports_network" title="Regional sports network">regional sports network</a> business, and that its AT&amp;T Sports Networks unit will file for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chapter_7,_Title_11,_United_States_Code" title="Chapter 7, Title 11, United States Code">Chapter 7 liquidation bankruptcy</a> unless the channels are sold or the teams take back their broadcast rights by March 31. Teams that air on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle" title="Seattle">Seattle</a>-based <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Root_Sports_Northwest" title="Root Sports Northwest">Root Sports Northwest</a> are not part of the proceedings as WBD only holds a minority stake in that network.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-WBDRSN_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WBDRSN-90"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>89<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>90<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Warner Bros. Discovery files a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breach_of_contract" title="Breach of contract">breach of contract</a> lawsuit with the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Supreme_Court" title="New York Supreme Court">New York Supreme Court</a>, accusing <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramount_Global" title="Paramount Global">Paramount Global</a> of violating a 2019 agreement that gave <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HBO_Max" class="mw-redirect" title="HBO Max">HBO Max</a> rights to stream the first 23 seasons of <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Park" title="South Park">South Park</a></i> as well as three subsequent seasons that had yet to air at the time on Paramount-owned <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comedy_Central" title="Comedy Central">Comedy Central</a>. The suit alleges Paramount diverted most of the animated series' post-2019 episodes to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramount%2B" title="Paramount+">Paramount+</a> under a separate $900-million deal between ViacomCBS Domestic Media Networks (now <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramount_Media_Networks" title="Paramount Media Networks">Paramount Media Networks</a>) and series creators <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trey_Parker" title="Trey Parker">Trey Parker</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Stone" title="Matt Stone">Matt Stone</a>
 reached in August 2021, despite WBD holding streaming exclusivity over 
the series under their $596.7-million (or $1.7 million per episode) 
deal, and only produced 14 of the 30 additional episodes promised to 
fill out the WBD–Paramount contract. Paramount countersued WBD on April 
19, alleging the contract did not define a specified episode commitment 
for future seasons or required it to license made-for-streaming <i>South Park</i> movies to HBO Max. WBD and Paramount both claim they are owed $52 million in unpaid license fees.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>91<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>92<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>26
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/29th_Screen_Actors_Guild_Awards" title="29th Screen Actors Guild Awards">29th Screen Actors Guild Awards</a> are presented at the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Century_Plaza_Hotel" title="The Century Plaza Hotel">Fairmont Century Plaza</a> in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Century_City" title="Century City">Century City</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>, with notable winners including the motion picture <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Everything_Everywhere_All_At_Once" class="mw-redirect" title="Everything Everywhere All At Once">Everything Everywhere All At Once</a></i> (four awards) and TV series <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abbott_Elementary" title="Abbott Elementary">Abbott Elementary</a></i> and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_White_Lotus" title="The White Lotus">The White Lotus</a></i> (wins for comedy and drama ensembles, respectively).  The ceremony airs live on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netflix" title="Netflix">Netflix</a>'s <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a> channel, a one-year arrangement between <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Screen_Actors_Guild" title="Screen Actors Guild">SAG</a>
 and Netflix before the streamer, once its live-streaming capabilities 
are worked out, carries the ceremony exclusively beginning in 2024.  
(The SAG Awards' former broadcast homes, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TNT_(American_TV_network)" title="TNT (American TV network)">TNT</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TBS_(American_TV_channel)" title="TBS (American TV channel)">TBS</a>, announced in 2022 that they would no longer broadcast the ceremony.)
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>93<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-SAG_Move_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SAG_Move-95"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>94<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="March">March</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: March"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th>Date
</th>
<th>Event
</th>
<th>Source
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th>4
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Kids%27_Choice_Awards" title="2023 Kids' Choice Awards">2023 Kids' Choice Awards</a> airs on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nickelodeon" title="Nickelodeon">Nickelodeon</a> and was simulcast on six <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramount_Global" title="Paramount Global">Paramount</a>-owned sister networks (including the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nick_Jr." title="Nick Jr.">Nick Jr. Channel</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicktoons_(American_TV_channel)" title="Nicktoons (American TV channel)">Nicktoons</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TeenNick" title="TeenNick">TeenNick</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TV_Land" title="TV Land">TV Land</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MTV2" title="MTV2">MTV2</a>) from the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Theater" class="mw-redirect" title="Microsoft Theater">Microsoft Theater</a> in Los Angeles, with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nate_Burleson" title="Nate Burleson">Nate Burleson</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charli_D%27Amelio" title="Charli D'Amelio">Charli D'Amelio</a> (who won "Favorite Female Creator") as hosts. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Styles" title="Harry Styles">Harry Styles</a>
 won the most awards among all nominees with three each: for "Favorite 
Male Artist", "Favorite Global Music Star", and "Favorite Song" (for "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/As_It_Was" title="As It Was">As It Was</a>"). <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High_School_Musical:_The_Musical:_The_Series" title="High School Musical: The Musical: The Series">High School Musical: The Musical: The Series</a></i> (with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olivia_Rodrigo" title="Olivia Rodrigo">Olivia Rodrigo</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joshua_Bassett" title="Joshua Bassett">Joshua Bassett</a> winning both "Favorite Kids TV Star" categories) and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wednesday_(TV_series)" title="Wednesday (TV series)">Wednesday</a></i> (which won "Favorite Family TV Show" and "Favorite Female Family TV Star" for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jenna_Ortega" title="Jenna Ortega">Jenna Ortega</a>) were the top winners among TV nominees with two each.
