Other major winners include <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonic_the_Hedgehog_2_(film)" title="Sonic the Hedgehog 2 (film)">Sonic the Hedgehog 2</a></i> ("Favorite Movie"), <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SpongeBob_SquarePants" title="SpongeBob SquarePants">SpongeBob SquarePants</a></i> ("Favorite Animated Series"), and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adam_Sandler" title="Adam Sandler">Adam Sandler</a> ("King of Comedy Award"). Also on this day, Nickelodeon receives its first major rebrand in almost six years.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>96<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>97<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>98<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>99<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="3">8
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fremantle_(company)" title="Fremantle (company)">Fremantle</a>, the production company behind <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Price_Is_Right" title="The Price Is Right">The Price Is Right</a></i>, announces that the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a> game show will relocate from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a>' <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Television_City" title="Television City">Television City</a> to Haven Studios, a Fremantle-co-owned facility in nearby <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glendale,_California" title="Glendale, California">Glendale, California</a>,
 when its 52nd season begins taping in the summer. The game show has 
originated from Studio 33 at Television City (renamed in 1998 as the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Barker" title="Bob Barker">Bob Barker</a>
 Studio, in honor of the former longtime host) since premiering in 1972;
 its move, and the pending relocations of several other shows from the 
facility (among them <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Young_and_The_Restless" class="mw-redirect" title="The Young and The Restless">The Young and The Restless</a></i> and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_Time_with_Bill_Maher" title="Real Time with Bill Maher">Real Time with Bill Maher</a></i>), comes before the start of a $1.25 billion renovation of the property, which Hackman Capital Partners bought from CBS in 2018.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>100<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hulu" title="Hulu">Hulu</a> removes 34 <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a> stations operated by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinclair_Broadcast_Group" title="Sinclair Broadcast Group">Sinclair Broadcast Group</a> from its vMVPD service in 32 markets, after the streaming service reportedly declined Sinclair's offer to add <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_Channel" title="Tennis Channel">Tennis Channel</a>
 as part of a renewed agreement for the stations. Unlike the earlier 
FuboTV master agreement dispute between CBS and several of its affiliate
 operators (see January 30 entry), Hulu—which is majority owned by ABC 
parent <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disney" class="mw-redirect" title="Disney">Disney</a>—
did not substitute the affected Sinclair stations with a linear ABC 
national feed. (A feed was provided to the affected markets exclusively 
for the network's telecast of the 95th Academy Awards four days later.) 
The dispute lasted until April 21, when Hulu and Sinclair agreed to 
reinstate the affected stations through a new contract.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>101<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>102<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>103<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WLBT" title="WLBT">WLBT</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jackson,_Mississippi" title="Jackson, Mississippi">Jackson</a> removes longtime morning anchor and chief meteorologist Barbie Bassett (who is white), after she quoted the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snoop_Dogg" title="Snoop Dogg">Snoop Dogg</a>-coined slang, "Fo shizzle, my nizzle" ("nizzle" referring to the Black <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Term_of_endearment" title="Term of endearment">term of endearment</a> vernacular for "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nigger" title="Nigger">nigger</a>"), when a collaboration with another WLBT reporter was jokingly raised during the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gray_Television" class="mw-redirect" title="Gray Television">Gray</a>-
owned NBC affiliate's 11:00&nbsp;a.m. newscast, after a report on the 
introduction of a new wine to the rapper's Cali Wine Collection line. 
Although WLBT—which infamously had its license revoked by the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FCC" class="mw-redirect" title="FCC">FCC</a> in 1969 from original owner Lamar Life Insurance, due to the station's advocacy of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racial_segregation" title="Racial segregation">racial segregation</a> and omission of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_rights_movement" title="Civil rights movement">civil rights movement</a> coverage during <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC_News" title="NBC News">NBC News</a>
 broadcasts—has not formally disclosed Bassett's status, her biography 
was removed from its website. Bassett previously apologized for a 
similar incident in October 2022, in which she suggested reporter Carmen
 Poe (who is Black) ask her grandmother—whom Bassett referred to as "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mammy_stereotype" title="Mammy stereotype">grandmammy</a>"—for a pie recipe to get a scoop on a then-upcoming <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/College_GameDay_(football_TV_program)" title="College GameDay (football TV program)">ESPN College Gameday</a></i> telecast from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jackson_State_University" title="Jackson State University">Jackson State University</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>104<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>105<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>12
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/95th_Academy_Awards" title="95th Academy Awards">95th Academy Awards</a> airs on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a> from the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dolby_Theatre" title="Dolby Theatre">Dolby Theatre</a> in Hollywood, with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Kimmel" title="Jimmy Kimmel">Jimmy Kimmel</a> as host. <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Everything_Everywhere_All_at_Once" title="Everything Everywhere All at Once">Everything Everywhere All at Once</a></i> was the top winner with seven awards, including <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Best Picture</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Actress" title="Academy Award for Best Actress">Best Actress</a> (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michelle_Yeoh" title="Michelle Yeoh">Michelle Yeoh</a>, who became the first Asian woman to win the honor), <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actor" title="Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor">Best Supporting Actor</a> (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ke_Huy_Quan" title="Ke Huy Quan">Ke Huy Quan</a>), and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actress" title="Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress">Best Supporting Actress</a> (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamie_Lee_Curtis" title="Jamie Lee Curtis">Jamie Lee Curtis</a>). Other major winners included <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_Quiet_on_the_Western_Front_(2022_film)" title="All Quiet on the Western Front (2022 film)">All Quiet on the Western Front</a></i> with four awards (including Best International Feature Film) and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Whale_(2022_film)" title="The Whale (2022 film)">The Whale</a></i> with two (including <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brendan_Fraser" title="Brendan Fraser">Brendan Fraser</a> for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Actor" title="Academy Award for Best Actor">Best Actor</a>). The telecast was seen by an estimated 18.7 million viewers, up 12% from the previous year.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>106<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>107<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>108<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>109<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>110<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>111<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>112<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>113<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>13
</th>
<td>As part of a multi-year agreement that also extends their existing carriage contracts for the group's 40 CBS stations and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NewsNation" title="NewsNation">NewsNation</a>, Nexstar Media Group and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YouTube_TV" title="YouTube TV">YouTube TV</a> announce that the vMVPD service will add 59 Nexstar-operated stations serving 56 markets (consisting of 29 <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_CW" title="The CW">CW</a>, 26 <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MyNetworkTV" title="MyNetworkTV">MyNetworkTV</a> and four <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_station_(North_America)" class="mw-redirect" title="Independent station (North America)">independent stations</a>, including <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPIX" title="WPIX">WPIX</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>, KTLA/Los Angeles, WGN-TV/Chicago, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KRON" class="mw-redirect" title="KRON">KRON</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco" title="San Francisco">San Francisco</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPHL-TV" title="WPHL-TV">WPHL</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia" title="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a>, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WDVM-TV" title="WDVM-TV">WDVM</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WDCW" title="WDCW">WDCW</a>/
Washington, D.C.) to its lineup. The deal fills a major affiliate 
coverage gap for The CW on YouTube TV, as Nexstar was the largest group 
without a carriage deal for its CW stations (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_News_and_Stations" title="CBS News and Stations">CBS</a>
 and Sinclair Broadcast Group were the largest CW station operators to 
offer their affiliates on the service); it also expands local 
MyNetworkTV carriage on YTTV (beyond affiliates operated by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Television_Stations" title="Fox Television Stations">Fox</a> and Sinclair) for the first time.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>114<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>115<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">14
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diamond_Sports_Group" class="mw-redirect" title="Diamond Sports Group">Diamond Sports Group</a> files for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chapter_11_bankruptcy_protection" class="mw-redirect" title="Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection">Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection</a> with the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_District_Court_for_the_Southern_District_of_Texas" title="United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas">U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of Texas</a>. The operator of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bally_Sports" class="mw-redirect" title="Bally Sports">Bally Sports</a> group of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_sports_network" title="Regional sports network">regional sports networks</a>, which carry local broadcasts for nearly half of the teams in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA" class="mw-redirect" title="NBA">NBA</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NHL" class="mw-redirect" title="NHL">NHL</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MLB" class="mw-redirect" title="MLB">MLB</a>
 (42 teams in total across 19 channels), had been struggling to reduce 
around $8 billion in debt acquired through its 2019 purchase of the 
former <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Sports_Networks" title="Fox Sports Networks">Fox Sports Networks</a> from The Walt Disney Company. Diamond's financial health, which was impacted by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cord-cutting" title="Cord-cutting">cord-cutting</a>
 as well as carriage disputes earlier in the decade that significantly 
reduced Bally Sports' vMVPD distribution, became an issue after 
announcements that it had missed a $140 million payment to its lenders 
in February, and a scheduled rights payment to MLB's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arizona_Diamondbacks" title="Arizona Diamondbacks">Arizona Diamondbacks</a>
 on March 10. Diamond will separate from majority parent Sinclair 
Broadcast Group as part of the reorganization, and plans to continue to 
produce and air games. Diamond president Steve Rosenberg subsequently 
stepped down on March 20, succeeded by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CFO" class="mw-redirect" title="CFO">CFO</a> David DeVoe.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>116<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>117<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>118<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>119<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 2<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DirecTV" title="DirecTV">DirecTV</a> files a lawsuit against Nexstar Media Group, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mission_Broadcasting" title="Mission Broadcasting">Mission Broadcasting</a> and White Knight Broadcasting with the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._District_Court_for_the_Southern_District_of_New_York" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York">U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York</a>, accusing the groups of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Price_fixing" title="Price fixing">price fixing</a>
 through an "illegal conspiracy" to collectively bargain in 
retransmission fee negotiations using "sidecar" arrangements between 
Nexstar and the latter two companies meant to skirt FCC regulations 
(including its local station ownership caps). The suit is in relation to
 a broader carriage dispute involving 23 Mission and two White Knight 
stations that were removed from DirecTV, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DirecTV_Stream" title="DirecTV Stream">DirecTV Stream</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U-verse_TV" title="U-verse TV">U-verse TV</a> during separate negotiations in October 2022. District Judge <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P._Kevin_Castel" title="P. Kevin Castel">P. Kevin Castel</a> dismissed the antitrust lawsuit on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standing_(law)" title="Standing (law)">standing</a> grounds on March 20, 2024.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>125<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>126<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-auto3_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-12"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>127<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto2_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-13"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 3<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>15
</th>
<td><i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sports_Business_Journal" class="mw-redirect" title="Sports Business Journal">Sports Business Journal</a></i> reports that <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Gumbel" title="Greg Gumbel">Greg Gumbel</a> has signed a contract extension with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_Sports" title="CBS Sports">CBS Sports</a> that will allow the veteran sportscaster to remain studio host for its <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/College_Basketball_on_CBS" class="mw-redirect" title="College Basketball on CBS">NCAA basketball</a> coverage while stepping away from his role as play-by-play announcer for its <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL_on_CBS" title="NFL on CBS">NFL broadcasts</a>.
 Outside of the period when the network did not have the NFL (1994–97), 
Gumbel has been with CBS since 1990 and is the first African-American to
 handle play-by-play for the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl" title="Super Bowl">Super Bowl</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>128<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">17
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyra_Banks" title="Tyra Banks">Tyra Banks</a> discloses in an interview with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TMZ" title="TMZ">TMZ</a> that she will step down as co-host of <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dancing_with_the_Stars_(American_TV_series)" title="Dancing with the Stars (American TV series)">Dancing with the Stars</a></i> after three seasons to focus on her business and television production projects. Banks succeeded <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Bergeron" title="Tom Bergeron">Tom Bergeron</a> (who had hosted <i>DWTS</i> since its 2005 debut on ABC) and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erin_Andrews" title="Erin Andrews">Erin Andrews</a> as sole host of the reality competition series in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dancing_with_the_Stars_(American_season_29)" class="mw-redirect" title="Dancing with the Stars (American season 29)">2020</a>. On March 20, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Julianne_Hough" title="Julianne Hough">Julianne Hough</a>—
who served as a pro dancer from 2007 to 2009 and as a judge from 2014 to
 2017—was named to succeed Banks, alongside returning co-host <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfonso_Ribiero" class="mw-redirect" title="Alfonso Ribiero">Alfonso Ribiero</a>, who joined the series in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dancing_with_the_Stars_(American_season_31)" class="mw-redirect" title="Dancing with the Stars (American season 31)">2022</a> (coinciding with its move to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disney%2B" title="Disney+">Disney+</a>).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>129<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>130<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>131<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">NBC</a> and the post-production editing staff of <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live" title="Saturday Night Live">Saturday Night Live</a></i>
 announce a tentative labor agreement that averts a strike against the 
variety series that was set for April 1. The staff of 12–20 editors and 
film managers, who edit pre-taped sketches for <i>SNL</i>, unionized in October 2022, sent contract proposals to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBCUniversal" title="NBCUniversal">NBCUniversal</a> that December, and approved a strike authorization with the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_Picture_Editors_Guild" title="Motion Picture Editors Guild">Motion Picture Editors Guild</a>
 on January 23. The deal, whose ratification was announced on March 23, 
gives the team pay boosts, healthcare benefits, employer-paid meals, and
 accommodations for those who work long shifts with short turnarounds.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>132<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>133<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>134<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>135<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>18
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KCBS-TV" title="KCBS-TV">KCBS</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KCAL-TV" title="KCAL-TV">KCAL</a>/
Los Angeles weekend morning meteorologist Alissa Carlson Schwartz faints
 on-air just prior to presenting a weather segment during the CBS-owned 
duopoly's Saturday morning newscast. The rest of the broadcast was 
preempted following the incident, with both stations (which simulcast 
portions of the newscast) airing pre-recorded and paid programming in 
its place. Carlson—who, while employed at NBC affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KGET" class="mw-redirect" title="KGET">KGET</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bakersfield" class="mw-redirect" title="Bakersfield">Bakersfield</a>, was diagnosed with a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valvular_heart_disease" title="Valvular heart disease">heart valve leak</a>
 after vomiting on-set during a weather report in 2014—was treated for a
 head injury, and later revealed in a March 21 interview with <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_Mornings" title="CBS Mornings">CBS Mornings</a></i> that the fainting spell was induced by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vasovagal_syncope" class="mw-redirect" title="Vasovagal syncope">vasovagal syncope</a> likely triggered by dehydration.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>136<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>137<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>138<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>139<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>24
</th>
<td>Sinclair Broadcast Group lays off 30+ news department employees and cancels certain local newscasts produced by NBC affiliates <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPMI" class="mw-redirect" title="WPMI">WPMI</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile,_Alabama" title="Mobile, Alabama">Mobile</a> (operated under an <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_marketing_agreement" title="Local marketing agreement">SSA</a> with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deerfield_Media" title="Deerfield Media">Deerfield Media</a>) and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WEYI" class="mw-redirect" title="WEYI">WEYI</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saginaw" class="mw-redirect" title="Saginaw">Saginaw</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flint,_Michigan" title="Flint, Michigan">Flint</a> (operated under an SSA with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howard_Stirk_Holdings" class="mw-redirect" title="Howard Stirk Holdings">Howard Stirk Holdings</a>), Fox affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WACH" title="WACH">WACH</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Columbia,_South_Carolina" title="Columbia, South Carolina">Columbia</a>, and Fox/ABC affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WGXA" title="WGXA">WGXA</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macon,_Georgia" title="Macon, Georgia">Macon</a>, and shuts down the news department of ABC affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KAEF" class="mw-redirect" title="KAEF">KAEF</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arcata" class="mw-redirect" title="Arcata">Arcata</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eureka,_California" title="Eureka, California">Eureka, California</a>.
 WPMI cut more than 20 members of its approximately 30-person news 
staff, and discontinued its weekday morning and noon newscasts as well 
as the lifestyle program <i>Gulf Coast Today</i>; WEYI cut six 
production staffers, and cancels its weekday morning and weekend evening
 newscasts; WACH cancels its four-hour morning newscast; and WGXA cut 
nine production staffers, reduces its hour-long weeknight 5:00&nbsp;p.m.
 newscast to a half-hour and cancels its Sunday–Thursday 10:00&nbsp;p.m.
 newscast. On April 3, most of the affected stations replaced some or 
all of the affected newscasts with Sinclair's syndicated national 
newscast, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_National_Desk" title="The National Desk">The National Desk</a></i>
 (with WACH replacing the first hour of its morning newscast with a 
repeat of its 10:00&nbsp;p.m. newscast, and WPMI replacing its local 
midday programs with additional runs of <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Family_Feud" title="Family Feud">Family Feud</a></i>), while KAEF began simulcasting newscasts from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redding,_California" title="Redding, California">Redding</a> parent station <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KRCR" class="mw-redirect" title="KRCR">KRCR</a> (retaining two Eureka-based reporters to file reports for those broadcasts).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>140<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>141<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>142<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-tvnc-sinclaircuts_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tvnc-sinclaircuts-146"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>143<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 4<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>26
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Army" title="United States Army">United States Army</a> pauses its recently launched advertising campaign featuring on-screen narrator <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonathan_Majors" title="Jonathan Majors">Jonathan Majors</a>, which revives its classic "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Be_All_You_Can_Be" class="mw-redirect" title="Be All You Can Be">Be All You Can Be</a>"
 ad slogan, one day after the actor's arrest on misdemeanor domestic 
violence charges in connection to a March 24 domestic dispute, in which 
Majors allegedly physically assaulted a woman he was dating, resulting 
in her sustaining minor head and neck injuries. New ads in the campaign,
 which do not feature Majors, would be rolled out the following weekend.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>144<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>145<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>27
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chanel_West_Coast" title="Chanel West Coast">Chanel West Coast</a> announces her departure from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MTV" title="MTV">MTV's</a> <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ridiculousness_(TV_series)" title="Ridiculousness (TV series)">Ridiculousness</a></i> after signing a deal to develop, produce, and star in unscripted projects for MTV parent <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramount_Media_Networks" title="Paramount Media Networks">Paramount Media Networks</a> and its <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MTV_Entertainment_Group" class="mw-redirect" title="MTV Entertainment Group">MTV Entertainment Group</a> subsidiary. Chanel had co-presented the comedic <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clip_show" title="Clip show">clip show</a>, alongside <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steelo_Brim" title="Steelo Brim">Steelo Brim</a> and lead host <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rob_Dyrdek" title="Rob Dyrdek">Rob Dyrdek</a>, since its launch in 2011.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>146<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>28
</th>
<td>One day after <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Bachelor_(American_TV_series)" title="The Bachelor (American TV series)">The Bachelor</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Bachelor_(American_season_27)" class="mw-redirect" title="The Bachelor (American season 27)">27th season</a> concludes, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Fleiss" title="Mike Fleiss">Mike Fleiss</a> announces his departure from the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Bachelor_(franchise)" title="The Bachelor (franchise)"><i>Bachelor</i> franchise</a> he created and had produced since <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Bachelor_(American_season_1)" class="mw-redirect" title="The Bachelor (American season 1)">the first <i>Bachelor</i> season</a> on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a> in 2002. Claire Freeland, Jason Ehrlich, and Bennett Graebner are immediately tapped to oversee the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dating_game_show" title="Dating game show">dating game show</a> franchise, which also includes <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Bachelorette_(American_TV_series)" title="The Bachelorette (American TV series)">The Bachelorette</a></i> and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bachelor_in_Paradise_(American_TV_series)" title="Bachelor in Paradise (American TV series)">Bachelor in Paradise</a></i>. Though Fleiss, ABC, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warner_Bros._Television_Studios" title="Warner Bros. Television Studios">Warner Bros. Television Studios</a> (the franchise's producer) were tight-lipped as to the reason for his departure, a <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variety_(magazine)" title="Variety (magazine)">Variety</a></i>
 report later indicated that Fleiss was the subject of an investigation,
 conducted by an outside party, into allegations of bullying and 
racially discriminatory behaviors.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>147<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>148<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="April">April</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: April"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th>Date
</th>
<th>Event
</th>
<th>Source
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">2
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022%E2%80%9323_LSU_Tigers_women%27s_basketball_team" title="2022–23 LSU Tigers women's basketball team">LSU Tigers</a> defeat the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022%E2%80%9323_Iowa_Hawkeyes_women%27s_basketball_team" title="2022–23 Iowa Hawkeyes women's basketball team">Iowa Hawkeyes</a> to win the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_NCAA_Division_I_women%27s_basketball_championship_game" title="2023 NCAA Division I women's basketball championship game">championship</a> of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_NCAA_Division_I_women%27s_basketball_tournament" title="2023 NCAA Division I women's basketball tournament">2023 NCAA Division I women's basketball tournament</a>. Simulcasts of the game on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN2" title="ESPN2">ESPN2</a> drew a combined 9.9 million viewers, the largest ever television audience for a women's college basketball game.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>149<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_CMT_Music_Awards" title="2023 CMT Music Awards">2023 CMT Music Awards</a> airs on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a> from the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moody_Center" title="Moody Center">Moody Center</a> in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austin,_Texas" title="Austin, Texas">Austin, Texas</a>, with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kane_Brown" title="Kane Brown">Kane Brown</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kelsea_Ballerini" title="Kelsea Ballerini">Kelsea Ballerini</a> as hosts. In addition to co-hosting, Kane Brown won the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CMT_Music_Award_for_Video_of_the_Year" title="CMT Music Award for Video of the Year">Video of the Year</a> award for his collaboration with wife <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katelyn_Brown" class="mw-redirect" title="Katelyn Brown">Katelyn Brown</a>, "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thank_God_(Kane_Brown_and_Katelyn_Brown_song)" title="Thank God (Kane Brown and Katelyn Brown song)">Thank God</a>". <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jelly_Roll_(singer)" title="Jelly Roll (singer)">Jelly Roll</a> was the top winner of the night, with three awards (all for his single "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Son_of_a_Sinner" title="Son of a Sinner">Son of a Sinner</a>").
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>150<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>151<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="3">3
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022%E2%80%9323_UConn_Huskies_men%27s_basketball_team" title="2022–23 UConn Huskies men's basketball team">UConn Huskies</a> top the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022%E2%80%9323_San_Diego_State_Aztecs_men%27s_basketball_team" title="2022–23 San Diego State Aztecs men's basketball team">San Diego State Aztecs</a> in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_NCAA_Division_I_men%27s_basketball_championship_game" title="2023 NCAA Division I men's basketball championship game">title game</a> of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_NCAA_Division_I_men%27s_basketball_tournament" title="2023 NCAA Division I men's basketball tournament">2023 NCAA Division I men's basketball tournament</a>. The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a> broadcast attracted 14.693 million viewers, a record low for the championship event. The broadcast is also <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Nantz" title="Jim Nantz">Jim Nantz</a>'s last college basketball assignment for CBS; though he remains the network's lead play-by-play announcer for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL_on_CBS" title="NFL on CBS">NFL</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PGA_Tour_on_CBS" title="PGA Tour on CBS">PGA golf</a> events, Nantz steps back from college basketball after calling 32 consecutive tournaments for CBS and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turner_Sports" class="mw-redirect" title="Turner Sports">Turner Sports</a>. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ian_Eagle" title="Ian Eagle">Ian Eagle</a>
 will succeed Nantz as CBS' lead college basketball announcer in the 
2023–24 season. This also marks the first Men's Final Four to be 
overseen by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlie_Baker" title="Charlie Baker">Charlie Baker</a>, who was appointed president of the NCAA in December 2022 to succeed <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Emmert" title="Mark Emmert">Mark Emmert</a> (who announced his retirement in April of that year).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>152<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>153<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Emmert#cite_note-18" title="Mark Emmert">[18]</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Emmert#cite_note-17" title="Mark Emmert">[17]</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frontier_Communications" title="Frontier Communications">Frontier Communications</a> removes three networks—Newsmax Media-owned Newsmax TV, and Fuse Media-owned <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuse_(TV_channel)" title="Fuse (TV channel)">Fuse</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FM_(TV_channel)" class="mw-redirect" title="FM (TV channel)">FM</a>—
from its systems, after declining to negotiate new agreements with their
 respective parent companies. The dispute involving Newsmax comes two 
weeks after DirecTV ended a two-month dispute with the conservative news
 and commentary channel, and <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1154941027">.mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);clip-path:polygon(0px 0px,0px 0px,0px 0px);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}</style><span class="frac">4<span class="sr-only">+</span><span class="num">1</span>⁄<span class="den">2</span></span> months after Frontier dropped its archconservative competitor One America News Network in a similar dispute.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>154<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Idol" title="American Idol">American Idol</a></i> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Idol_(season_21)" class="mw-redirect" title="American Idol (season 21)">season 21</a>
 contestant Sara Beth Liebe abruptly quits during the Hollywood Week 
round, citing the need to be with her children. Liebe called out <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katy_Perry" title="Katy Perry">Katy Perry</a>
 on social media two weeks prior for a controversial "mom-shaming" joke 
that the singer made during her initial audition, in which she remarked 
that Liebe, after revealing she was a mother of three at age 25, had 
been "laying on the table too much."
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>155<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>5
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hearst_Television" title="Hearst Television">Hearst Television</a> announces it will purchase NBC affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WBBH" class="mw-redirect" title="WBBH">WBBH</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Myers" class="mw-redirect" title="Fort Myers">Fort Myers</a> from Waterman Broadcasting for $220.54 million, pending FCC approval. The purchase—which includes the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_marketing_agreement" title="Local marketing agreement">LMA</a> rights to Montclair Communications-owned ABC sister <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WZVN-TV" title="WZVN-TV">WZVN</a>—
marks the family-owned Waterman's exit from broadcasting (the group, 
originally founded in 1956 as a radio station operator, had owned WBBH 
since 1978), and will give Hearst its fifth station in Florida, 
alongside its existing properties in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orlando,_Florida" title="Orlando, Florida">Orlando</a> (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WESH" title="WESH">WESH</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WKCF" title="WKCF">WKCF</a>), <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Palm_Beach" class="mw-redirect" title="West Palm Beach">West Palm Beach</a> (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPBF" title="WPBF">WPBF</a>) and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tampa" class="mw-redirect" title="Tampa">Tampa</a> (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WMOR-TV" title="WMOR-TV">WMOR</a>). The sale was completed on June 30.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>156<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>157<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">12
</th>
<td>As part of a multi-year agreement that also extends their existing 
carriage contracts for the group's 25 CBS and 16 MyNetworkTV stations as
 well as <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comet_(TV_network)" title="Comet (TV network)">Comet</a>, Sinclair Broadcast Group and YouTube TV announce that the vMVPD service will add <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_Channel" title="Tennis Channel">Tennis Channel</a> and its companion AVOD streaming channel T2, and digital multicast networks <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charge!_(TV_network)" title="Charge! (TV network)">Charge!</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TBD_(TV_network)" title="TBD (TV network)">TBD</a> to its lineup, effective June 1. This would later be followed on July 19 by a similar deal between Sinclair and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hulu" title="Hulu">Hulu</a> to add the three networks as well as Comet to the service's vMVPD offering in January 2024.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>158<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>159<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PBS" title="PBS">PBS</a> and many of its member stations suspend activity on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">Twitter</a>
 after the social messaging platform labeled the service's accounts as 
"government-funded media." The designation had earlier been given to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NPR" title="NPR">NPR</a>,
 which suspended posts the day prior amid a broader dispute that began 
on April 4, when Twitter first relabeled the counterpart radio service 
under the "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_media" title="State media">state-affiliated media</a>"
 classification previously given only to news agencies influenced or 
controlled by autocratic governments. PBS and NPR, which are editorially
 independent, consider both labels to be misleading and meant to 
undermine their credibility; both <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_broadcasters" class="mw-redirect" title="Public broadcasters">public broadcasters</a>
 are funded primarily through donations from viewers as well as 
corporate and philanthropic donors, while government appropriations to 
the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corporation_for_Public_Broadcasting" title="Corporation for Public Broadcasting">Corporation for Public Broadcasting</a> account for &gt;1% of their overall funding. (Other public broadcasters, including the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBC/Radio-Canada" class="mw-redirect" title="CBC/Radio-Canada">CBC/Radio-Canada</a>, have also criticized or paused activity on Twitter after being assigned the label.)
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>160<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>161<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>162<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>163<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>13
</th>
<td>The studios of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WWMT" title="WWMT">WWMT</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalamazoo" class="mw-redirect" title="Kalamazoo">Kalamazoo</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Rapids" class="mw-redirect" title="Grand Rapids">Grand Rapids</a> were evacuated around 2:30&nbsp;p.m. ET, after a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenville,_Michigan" title="Greenville, Michigan">Greenville</a> man with a history of mental illness threatened to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suicide_attack" title="Suicide attack">kill himself with a bomb</a> he claimed to have in his backpack. (Authorities later confirmed that they only found an <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">iPhone</a>
 charger and wiring in the backpack.) The suspect—who initially said he 
was submitting a news tip—forced his way through the front door of the 
Sinclair-owned CBS/CW affiliate's lobby when chief engineer George 
Markle moved to barricade the suspect between both lobby doors, and 
helped evacuate station staff from the building. After two hours, the 
suspect surrendered to police and was taken to the Kalamazoo County 
Jail.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>164<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>165<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>166<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>16
</th>
<td>Due to a 90-minute delay over what is later revealed to be an overlooked technical bug, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netflix" title="Netflix">Netflix</a> aborts plans to live-stream the Season 4 reunion special of dating series <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Love_is_Blind_(TV_series)" class="mw-redirect" title="Love is Blind (TV series)">Love is Blind</a></i>. The special would have been the streamer's second-ever live event (after <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Rock:_Selective_Outrage" class="mw-redirect" title="Chris Rock: Selective Outrage">Chris Rock: Selective Outrage</a></i>, which ran without error on March 4). The reunion is recorded and released on a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadcast_delay" title="Broadcast delay">tape delay</a> the following day.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>167<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>168<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>169<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>18
</th>
<td>Avoiding a trial in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delaware_Superior_Court" title="Delaware Superior Court">Delaware Superior Court</a> that already had a jury empaneled and sworn in, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominion_Voting_Systems" title="Dominion Voting Systems">Dominion Voting Systems</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_News" title="Fox News">Fox News</a> announce a $787.5 million settlement agreement in the former company's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominion_Voting_Systems_v._Fox_News_Network" title="Dominion Voting Systems v. Fox News Network">defamation lawsuit</a> over the latter's airing of baseless claims that Dominion's voting machines switched votes cast for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election" title="2020 United States presidential election">2020 presidential election</a> to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a>,
 one of several conspiracy theories spread by Trump, his supporters and 
many conservative media outlets to explain his defeat by Biden. Dominion
 had been seeking $1.6 billion in damages. Though the settlement does 
not require them to apologize on-air, Fox News does acknowledge in a 
statement that "the Court's rulings [found] certain claims about 
Dominion to be false."
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>170<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>19
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_news_gathering" title="Electronic news gathering">news-gathering</a> helicopters of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Griffin_Media" title="Griffin Media">Griffin Media</a>'s two <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oklahoma" title="Oklahoma">Oklahoma</a> CBS affiliates sustain damage from a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supercell" title="Supercell">supercell</a> thunderstorm that <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tornado_outbreak_of_April_19%E2%80%9320,_2023" class="mw-redirect" title="Tornado outbreak of April 19–20, 2023">spawned at least nine tornadoes</a> across the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Oklahoma" title="Central Oklahoma">central section</a> of the state. While covering an EF3 tornado that caused extensive damage in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cole,_Oklahoma" title="Cole, Oklahoma">Cole</a>, three-inch hailstones knocked out the windshield of a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bell_407" title="Bell 407">Bell 407</a> operated by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oklahoma_City" title="Oklahoma City">Oklahoma City</a> flagship <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KWTV" class="mw-redirect" title="KWTV">KWTV</a>; pilot Jim Gardner and photographer Rich Kriegel, who were both on board, were not injured. An EF2 tornado which struck <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shawnee,_Oklahoma" title="Shawnee, Oklahoma">Shawnee</a> later that evening damaged the tail rotor and roof of a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bell_206" title="Bell 206">Bell 206 B3 JetRanger</a> operated by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tulsa" class="mw-redirect" title="Tulsa">Tulsa</a> sister <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KOTV" class="mw-redirect" title="KOTV">KOTV</a> (which was being housed in a hangar for maintenance and required inspection) at the city's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shawnee_Regional_Airport" title="Shawnee Regional Airport">airport</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>171<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>172<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">20
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WNBA" class="mw-redirect" title="WNBA">WNBA</a> announces a multi-year deal with the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._W._Scripps_Company" title="E. W. Scripps Company">E. W. Scripps Company</a> that will see <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ion_Television" title="Ion Television">Ion Television</a> air regular season <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doubleheader_(television)" title="Doubleheader (television)">doubleheaders</a>, along with regional telecasts (airing in early- or late-evening broadcast windows) carried on selected Ion <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Owned-and-operated_stations" class="mw-redirect" title="Owned-and-operated stations">O&amp;Os</a>, on Friday nights starting with the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_WNBA_season" title="2023 WNBA season">2023 season</a>.
 Ion's initial slate of 44 WNBA-produced games will air over 15 weeks 
from May 26 to September 8. The deal gives Ion its first national sports
 telecasts since a three-event <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFC" class="mw-redirect" title="UFC">UFC</a>
 preliminary fight deal in 2010–11, and marks the first rights deal ever
 signed by Scripps Sports, which was formed in December 2022 to acquire 
sports events for Ion and Scripps's local television stations.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>173<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>174<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>175<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>176<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Fox News announces it has parted ways with conservative commentator <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dan_Bongino" title="Dan Bongino">Dan Bongino</a>, who hosted the Saturday prime time show <i>Unfiltered</i> for the network as well as the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Nation" title="Fox Nation">Fox Nation</a> program <i>Canceled in the USA</i>.
 According to Bongino, the move was due to a breakdown in contract 
negotiations and not related to Fox's settlement with Dominion Voting 
Systems.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-BonginoOut1_181-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BonginoOut1-181"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>177<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BonginoOut2_182-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BonginoOut2-182"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>178<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>21
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramount_Global" title="Paramount Global">Paramount Global</a> agrees to a $167.5 million settlement of a case stemming from the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_merger_of_CBS_and_Viacom" title="2019 merger of CBS and Viacom">2019 merger of CBS Corporation and Viacom</a> filed by former CBS shareholders against some of the company's former officers and directors (including vice-chairperson <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shari_Redstone" title="Shari Redstone">Shari Redstone</a> and acting CEO <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Ianniello" title="Joseph Ianniello">Joseph Ianniello</a>) over alleged breaches of fiduciary duties related to the merger negotiation and approval.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>179<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>23
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBCUniversal" title="NBCUniversal">NBCUniversal</a> CEO <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeff_Shell" title="Jeff Shell">Jeff Shell</a>
 departs the company following a third-party investigation into a 
complaint relating to an inappropriate relationship that Shell had with a
 female employee. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comcast" title="Comcast">Comcast</a> president <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_J._Cavanagh" title="Michael J. Cavanagh">Michael J. Cavanagh</a> will assume management responsibilities for the division until a successor is appointed. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNBC" title="CNBC">CNBC</a> anchor and senior international correspondent <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hadley_Gamble" title="Hadley Gamble">Hadley Gamble</a>—who lodged the complaint alleging sexual harassment by Shell, and allegations of bullying and discrimination by members of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNBC_World" title="CNBC World">CNBC World</a>'s
 management team in March that led to investigations into both 
matters—would subsequently reach an agreement with NBCUniversal to 
depart the network on May 9.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>180<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>181<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="4">24
</th>
<td>Fox News parts ways with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tucker_Carlson" title="Tucker Carlson">Tucker Carlson</a>, permanently ending <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tucker_Carlson_Tonight" title="Tucker Carlson Tonight">Tucker Carlson Tonight</a></i>
 with the April 21 broadcast (which ended with the expectation that it 
would be back the following Monday). The dismissals of Carlson and 
senior executive producer Justin Wells—reportedly directed by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Corporation" title="Fox Corporation">Fox Corporation</a> executive chairman/CEO <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lachlan_Murdoch" title="Lachlan Murdoch">Lachlan Murdoch</a> and Fox News Media CEO <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suzanne_Scott" title="Suzanne Scott">Suzanne Scott</a> to Fox chairman <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rupert_Murdoch" title="Rupert Murdoch">Rupert Murdoch</a>—
are tied to a discrimination lawsuit by producer Abby Grossberg (who was
 fired in March, and would go on to settle the litigation for $12 
million on June 30), alleging she was subjected to bullying and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antisemitic" class="mw-redirect" title="Antisemitic">antisemitic</a>
 comments while working on the program, and was coerced by company 
lawyers to provide misleading testimonial answers in the Dominion Voting
 Systems defamation lawsuit settled six days prior. Private text 
messages that Carlson sent to colleagues (expressing skepticism of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempts_to_overturn_the_2020_United_States_presidential_election" title="Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election">election fraud claims</a>
 made by former president Donald Trump's attorneys, criticizing the 
network for "jeopardizing" its credibility by amplifying the claims, and
 revealing that he hated Trump "passionately") were among the internal 
messages made public through the Dominion lawsuit that were widely seen 
as exposing Fox to greater legal liability. <i>Carlson</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s former 8:00&nbsp;p.m. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_Time_Zone" title="Eastern Time Zone">ET</a> slot was temporarily filled by <i>Fox News Tonight</i>, which was hosted by a rotation of network personalities; <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jesse_Watters_Primetime" title="Jesse Watters Primetime">Jesse Watters Primetime</a></i> took over the hour on July 17, as part of a broader prime time realignment that also saw timeslot changes for <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Ingraham_Angle" title="The Ingraham Angle">The Ingraham Angle</a></i> and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gutfeld!" title="Gutfeld!">Gutfeld!</a></i> (with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laura_Ingraham" title="Laura Ingraham">Ingraham</a> being moved to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jesse_Watters" title="Jesse Watters">Watters</a>' former 7:00&nbsp;p.m. ET slot). Carlson would debut a conservative commentary video series on Twitter on June 6, prompting a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cease_and_desist" title="Cease and desist">cease and desist</a> notice issued by Fox News one week later, citing a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-compete_clause" title="Non-compete clause">non-compete clause</a> in his former contract that runs until early 2025.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-CarlsonOut1_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CarlsonOut1-186"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>182<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CarlsonOut2_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CarlsonOut2-187"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>183<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>184<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>185<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>186<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>187<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>188<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>189<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>190<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a> parts ways with anchor <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don_Lemon" title="Don Lemon">Don Lemon</a>, following a series of controversies over his on-air remarks and treatment of network colleagues, and an April 5 <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variety_(magazine)" title="Variety (magazine)">Variety</a></i> report that outlined allegations of mistreatment toward several former female colleagues—including <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nancy_Grace" title="Nancy Grace">Nancy Grace</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyra_Phillips" title="Kyra Phillips">Kyra Phillips</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soledad_O%27Brien" title="Soledad O'Brien">Soledad O'Brien</a>—and instances of "diva-like behavior" during his 17-year career at CNN. Lemon was earlier criticized for remarks about <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikki_Haley" title="Nikki Haley">Nikki Haley</a>, which were widely perceived as sexist, on the February 16 edition of <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN_This_Morning_(2022)" title="CNN This Morning (2022)">CNN This Morning</a></i>, suggesting the former <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> ambassador and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governor_of_South_Carolina" title="Governor of South Carolina">South Carolina governor</a> (who turned 51 the month prior) was not a viable presidential candidate because she "isn't in her <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_years" title="Prime years">prime</a>"—
referencing a comment Haley made during her declaratory speech the day 
prior that implied President Joe Biden and her rival for the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election" title="2024 United States presidential election">2024</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republican</a> nomination, Donald Trump (then 80 and 76, respectively), were too old to hold office.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>191<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>192<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>193<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>194<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 5<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company" title="The Walt Disney Company">The Walt Disney Company</a> conducts a second round of layoffs affecting hundreds of employees, including ABC Current Programming SVP Stacey Adams, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freeform_(TV_network)" class="mw-redirect" title="Freeform (TV network)">Freeform</a> programming development SVP Julie Jarmon, and Disney Branded Television unscripted programming VP Marc Buhaj, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/20th_Television" title="20th Television">20th Television</a> SVP and Current Programming co-chief Dana Sharpless; <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FiveThirtyEight" title="FiveThirtyEight">FiveThirtyEight</a> founder/CEO <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nate_Silver" title="Nate Silver">Nate Silver</a> will also depart at the end of his contract later this year as part of cuts to the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ABC_News_(United_States)" title="ABC News (United States)">ABC News</a> unit. The company will also combine the current programming and development teams of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disney_Television_Animation" title="Disney Television Animation">Disney Television Animation</a>, and dissolve digital content division 20th Digital Studio, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disney_Media_Distribution" class="mw-redirect" title="Disney Media Distribution">Disney Media Distribution</a>'s first-run syndication unit and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disney_Television_Studios" title="Disney Television Studios">Disney Television Studios</a>'s
 marketing division (marketing responsibilities for programs produced by
 its studio units will be handled by the company's television and 
streaming properties).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>195<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>196<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>197<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>198<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Concluding an expansion that began on April 1 (when it replaced 
overnight drama series and infomercials with repeats of its evening talk
 and analysis shows), <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NewsNation" title="NewsNation">NewsNation</a>
 permanently switches to a 24-hour all-news schedule on weekdays: the 
Nexstar-owned network debuts a four-hour rolling afternoon news block, <i>NewsNation Now</i> (replacing <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Police_procedural" title="Police procedural">crime dramas</a> in that slot), and an hour-long political news show, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Hill_(newspaper)" title="The Hill (newspaper)">The Hill</a></i> (a broadcast extension of the co-owned publication, replacing an hour of <i>NewsNation Rush Hour</i>). The expansion coincides with the unveiling of a new studio at its New York bureau in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daily_News_Building" title="Daily News Building">Daily News Building</a> (where co-operated CW affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPIX" title="WPIX">WPIX</a> also christened a separate studio on that date). Syndicated scripted series acquired before the former <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WGN_America" title="WGN America">WGN America</a> began its gradual format shift from entertainment to news in February 2021 (such as <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_Bloods_(TV_series)" class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" title="Blue Bloods (TV series)">Blue Bloods</a></i> and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Last_Man_Standing_(American_TV_series)" title="Last Man Standing (American TV series)">Last Man Standing</a></i>)
 and time-brokered programs will continue to air on weekends outside of 
prime time until late 2024, when NewsNation plans to switch to all-news 
programming full-time.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>199<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>200<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>201<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>25
</th>
<td>A man carrying an <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_guitar" title="Electric guitar">electric guitar</a> and a handwritten sign—reading "Free <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Billie_Eilish" title="Billie Eilish">Billie Eilish</a>", and referencing a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_web" title="Dark web">dark web</a> conspiracy theory regarding the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CIA" class="mw-redirect" title="CIA">CIA</a>'s infamous <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MKUltra" title="MKUltra">MKUltra</a> experimentation program and ex-<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illuminati" title="Illuminati">Illuminati</a> "insider" Donald Marshall—climbed onto a digital billboard on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KTLA" title="KTLA">KTLA</a>/Los Angeles's landmark auxiliary transmission tower outside its <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunset_Bronson_Studios" class="mw-redirect" title="Sunset Bronson Studios">Sunset Bronson Studios</a>
 facility. (The Nexstar-owned CW affiliate's promotional billboard was 
subsequently turned off temporarily for safety reasons.) The man 
descended from the tower after about three hours, as firefighters and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LAPD" class="mw-redirect" title="LAPD">LAPD</a> crisis negotiators sought to get him down an adjacent ladder. He was arrested on a suspicion of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trespassing" class="mw-redirect" title="Trespassing">trespassing</a> complaint.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>202<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>203<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="4">26
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facebook_Watch" title="Facebook Watch">Facebook Watch</a> announces the cancellation of <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_Table_Talk" title="Red Table Talk">Red Table Talk</a></i>,
 the streaming service's last remaining original program, with its 
producers seeking a new service for future episodes of the talk show. 
The move comes amid ongoing layoffs at Facebook Watch parent <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meta_Platforms" title="Meta Platforms">Meta Platforms</a>
 (which included that of Mina Lefevre, Facebook Watch's head of 
development and programming) and a shift in emphasis by Meta toward 
content for its <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horizon_Worlds" title="Horizon Worlds">Horizon Worlds</a></i> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_reality" title="Virtual reality">virtual reality</a> service.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-Deadline-04262023_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Deadline-04262023-209"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>204<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">ESPN</a> cut ties with baseball reporter <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marly_Rivera" title="Marly Rivera">Marly Rivera</a> for calling fellow reporter Ivón Gaete a "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cunt" title="Cunt">fucking cunt</a>" in a heated caught-on-tape exchange on April 18, after Rivera alleged Gaete tried to interview <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aaron_Judge" title="Aaron Judge">Aaron Judge</a>, despite the former having had been scheduled to interview the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Yankees" title="New York Yankees">New York Yankees</a> outfielder.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>205<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>206<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oklahoma_Governor" class="mw-redirect" title="Oklahoma Governor">Oklahoma Governor</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Stitt" title="Kevin Stitt">Kevin Stitt</a> vetoes H.B. 2820, a bill that would extend authorization for the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oklahoma_Educational_Television_Authority" title="Oklahoma Educational Television Authority">Oklahoma Educational Television Authority</a>, the state's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PBS" title="PBS">PBS</a>
 member network, through July 1, 2026. Although Stitt later alleged the 
veto was over objections to LGBTQ+ content on certain PBS programs that 
he claims "indoctrinat[es]" and "overly sexualizes" children (harkening 
rhetoric of a broader ongoing <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Culture_war" title="Culture war">culture war</a> over LGBTQ+ rights), the bill is one of over 20 measures (some passed unanimously by the state's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oklahoma_Legislature" title="Oklahoma Legislature">House and Senate</a>)
 that he elected to veto in a broader impasse with Senate leaders over 
his education and tax proposals—which, in addition to increasing 
education funding and teacher salaries, would also create a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/School_choice" title="School choice">voucher</a>-
like tax credit program. The veto of H.B. 2820—which, had it not 
received  the required two-thirds support of both legislative chambers 
to override it, would have resulted in OETA's agency authorization 
expiring on July 1 and the member network ceasing operations when its 
existing funding appropriations lapsed in July 2024—was overridden by 
the legislature on May 25 (the penultimate day of its 2023 session), 
passing the House, 73–23, and the Senate, 38–6.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>208<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>209<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>210<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 6<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
