<td>A <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red-tailed_hawk" title="Red-tailed hawk">red-tailed hawk</a> fatally collided with a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bell_206_JetRanger" class="mw-redirect" title="Bell 206 JetRanger">Bell 206 JetRanger</a> operated by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPLG" title="WPLG">WPLG</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami" title="Miami">Miami</a> as the helicopter flew over <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pembroke_Pines" class="mw-redirect" title="Pembroke Pines">Pembroke Pines</a> en route to cover a story during the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berkshire_Hathaway" title="Berkshire Hathaway">BH Media</a>-
owned ABC affiliate's noon newscast. Pilot Mark Lewis and photographer 
Joe Brennan were not injured, and the helicopter—which sustained damage 
to its cockpit window—landed safely.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>212<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>213<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="3">27
</th>
<td>Just shy of a year after announcing his departure, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Corden" title="James Corden">James Corden</a>  hosts <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Late_Late_Show_with_James_Corden" title="The Late Late Show with James Corden">The Late Late Show</a></i> for the 1,193rd and final time. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Will_Ferrell" title="Will Ferrell">Will Ferrell</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Styles" title="Harry Styles">Harry Styles</a> are the guests on the finale, which  also featured a pre-recorded farewell message from President <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a> and a dream sequence sketch that included appearances by fellow current and former late night hosts <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Colbert" title="Stephen Colbert">Stephen Colbert</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Fallon" title="Jimmy Fallon">Jimmy Fallon</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Kimmel" title="Jimmy Kimmel">Jimmy Kimmel</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seth_Meyers" title="Seth Meyers">Seth Meyers</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Letterman" title="David Letterman">David Letterman</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trevor_Noah" title="Trevor Noah">Trevor Noah</a>. The last episode of Corden's 8<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1154941027"><span class="frac"><span class="num">1</span>⁄<span class="den">2</span></span>-year run as host—which was preceded earlier that night by the show's final prime time <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carpool_Karaoke" title="Carpool Karaoke">Carpool Karaoke</a></i> special—also served as the series finale of the CBS <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Late_Late_Show_(American_talk_show)" title="The Late Late Show (American talk show)">late night talk franchise</a>, which debuted in January 1995 with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Snyder" title="Tom Snyder">Tom Snyder</a> as its original host. After airing reruns of <i>The Late Late Show</i> for the remainder of spring and summer, the timeslot was filled by reruns and unaired episodes of the comedy panel show <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comics_Unleashed" title="Comics Unleashed">Comics Unleashed</a></i> starting in September until mid-January of the next year.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>214<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>215<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>216<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>217<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>218<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Sinclair Broadcast Group announces it will cancel full-length newscasts and lay off all news department staff at CBS affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KTVL" title="KTVL">KTVL</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medford,_Oregon" title="Medford, Oregon">Medford, Oregon</a>, and CBS/Fox affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KPTH" title="KPTH">KPTH</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sioux_City" class="mw-redirect" title="Sioux City">Sioux City</a>, and discontinue partially outsourced newscasts on NBC affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WNWO" class="mw-redirect" title="WNWO">WNWO</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toledo,_Ohio" title="Toledo, Ohio">Toledo</a> (co-produced by CBS sister <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WSBT-TV" title="WSBT-TV">WSBT</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Bend" class="mw-redirect" title="South Bend">South Bend</a> since March 2017), CBS affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WGFL" title="WGFL">WGFL</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gainesville,_Florida" title="Gainesville, Florida">Gainesville, Florida</a> (co-produced by CBS sister <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPEC" title="WPEC">WPEC</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Palm_Beach" class="mw-redirect" title="West Palm Beach">West Palm Beach</a> since October 2019), and Fox affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KPTM" title="KPTM">KPTM</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omaha" class="mw-redirect" title="Omaha">Omaha</a> (co-produced by Fox sister <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KMPH-TV" title="KMPH-TV">KMPH</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fresno" class="mw-redirect" title="Fresno">Fresno</a> since 2013), effective May 12. <i>The National Desk</i>
 will replace newscasts on all five stations starting May 15. The cuts, 
as well as reductions in news production at five other stations (see 
March 24 entry), are believed to be related to the recent bankruptcy of 
Sinclair-controlled Bally Sports parent Diamond Sports Group.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>219<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>220<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>221<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>223<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-tvnc-sinclaircuts_146-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tvnc-sinclaircuts-146"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>143<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 7<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a> announces that <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dana_Bash" title="Dana Bash">Dana Bash</a> will be the new anchor for the weekday edition of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inside_Politics" title="Inside Politics">Inside Politics</a>, while <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_King_(journalist)" title="John King (journalist)">John King</a> who had anchored the program since its revival in 2014, would be moved to a reporting project for the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election" title="2024 United States presidential election">2024 presidential election</a>. Dash will continue to anchor <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_the_Union_(American_TV_program)" title="State of the Union (American TV program)">State of the Union</a> on Sundays with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jake_Tapper" title="Jake Tapper">Jake Tapper</a>. Dash's first Inside Politics broadcast aired on June 12.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>224<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>225<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>28
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoenix,_Arizona" title="Phoenix, Arizona">Phoenix</a>'s professional basketball teams, the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA" class="mw-redirect" title="NBA">NBA</a>'s <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoenix_Suns" title="Phoenix Suns">Suns</a> and the WNBA's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoenix_Mercury" title="Phoenix Mercury">Mercury</a>, reach agreements with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gray_Television" class="mw-redirect" title="Gray Television">Gray Television</a> to air their regionally televised games on independents <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KTVK" title="KTVK">KTVK</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KPHE-LD" class="mw-redirect" title="KPHE-LD">KPHE-LD</a>,
 and with interactive video provider Kiswe to livestream their games on 
team-specific subscription streaming services. The deal—which was slated
 to begin with a Mercury-<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minnesota_Lynx" title="Minnesota Lynx">Minnesota Lynx</a>
 preseason game on May 25 and last five years for the Suns and two for 
the Mercury—would see the Gray stations maintain exclusivity over 
certain Suns and Mercury games, feature team-related programs on KTVK 
and KPHE, and have the content distributed throughout <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arizona" title="Arizona">Arizona</a> across KTVK's translator network and Gray-owned KPHE repeaters in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tucson" class="mw-redirect" title="Tucson">Tucson</a> (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KOLD-TV" title="KOLD-TV">KOLD-DT5</a>) and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yuma,_Arizona" title="Yuma, Arizona">Yuma</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/El_Centro" class="mw-redirect" title="El Centro">El Centro</a> (soon-to-launch KAZS). The Suns and Mercury are the first major-league teams to end their television partnerships with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bally_Sports" class="mw-redirect" title="Bally Sports">Bally Sports</a> since the March 14 bankruptcy of parent Diamond Sports Group, whose <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bally_Sports_Arizona" title="Bally Sports Arizona">Bally Sports Arizona</a> has carried Suns and Mercury games since <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003-04_Phoenix_Suns_season" class="mw-redirect" title="2003-04 Phoenix Suns season">2003</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2006_Phoenix_Mercury_season" title="2006 Phoenix Mercury season">2006</a>, respectively. (The Suns were last on over-the-air local TV when the team ended its contract with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MyNetworkTV" title="MyNetworkTV">MyNetworkTV</a> O&amp;O <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KUTP" title="KUTP">KUTP</a> in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_Phoenix_Suns_season" title="2010–11 Phoenix Suns season">2011</a>.)
 U.S. Bankruptcy Court Judge Christopher Lopez, who is overseeing 
Diamond's bankruptcy proceedings, would void the Gray deal on May 10, on
 the basis that the Suns and Mercury violated rules that froze Diamond's
 rights with the teams and gave them a right of first refusal to match 
the deal, while in bankruptcy. Diamond effectively reversed course on 
July 13, declining to submit an offer matching the Gray deal to retain 
the Suns/Mercury rights before that day's deadline.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>226<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>227<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>228<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>229<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>230<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>231<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>232<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>233<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 8<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>30
</th>
<td>During <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN_on_ABC" title="ESPN on ABC">ABC</a>'s coverage of Game 1 in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Heat" title="Miami Heat">Miami Heat</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Knicks" title="New York Knicks">New York Knicks</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_NBA_playoffs" title="2023 NBA playoffs">playoff series</a>, a bumper shown during the telecast included stock footage with the original towers of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(1973%E2%80%932001)" title="World Trade Center (1973–2001)">World Trade Center</a> in the background. After complaints from viewers, ESPN said it "mistakenly used an old stock image and we apologize."
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>234<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="May">May</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: May"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th>Date
</th>
<th>Event
</th>
<th>Source
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">1
</th>
<td>Two days after the conclusion of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_NFL_draft" title="2023 NFL draft">2023 NFL draft</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xfinity" title="Xfinity">Xfinity</a> drops <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL_Network" title="NFL Network">NFL Network</a>
 from its systems after failing to reach a contract renewal agreement 
prior to its expiration. The blackout ends the following day, reportedly
 resolved after a phone discussion between NFL Commissioner <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Goodell" title="Roger Goodell">Roger Goodell</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comcast" title="Comcast">Comcast</a> CEO <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brian_L._Roberts" title="Brian L. Roberts">Brian Roberts</a> conducted the previous afternoon.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>235<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>As part of a multi-year agreement that also extends their existing 
carriage contracts for the company's 90 ABC, NBC, CBS and Fox stations 
and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NewsNation" title="NewsNation">NewsNation</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nexstar_Media_Group" title="Nexstar Media Group">Nexstar Media Group</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hulu" title="Hulu">Hulu</a> announce that the latter will begin carrying additional Nexstar-run stations serving 32 markets (consisting of 26 <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MyNetworkTV" title="MyNetworkTV">MyNetworkTV</a> and four <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_station_(North_America)" class="mw-redirect" title="Independent station (North America)">independent stations</a>, including <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WGN-TV" title="WGN-TV">WGN-TV</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago" title="Chicago">Chicago</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KRON" class="mw-redirect" title="KRON">KRON</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco" title="San Francisco">San Francisco</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPHL-TV" title="WPHL-TV">WPHL</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia" title="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WTTA" title="WTTA">WTTA</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tampa" class="mw-redirect" title="Tampa">Tampa</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Petersburg,_Florida" title="St. Petersburg, Florida">St. Petersburg</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KAUT" class="mw-redirect" title="KAUT">KAUT</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oklahoma_City" title="Oklahoma City">Oklahoma City</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WDVM-TV" title="WDVM-TV">WDVM</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hagerstown" class="mw-redirect" title="Hagerstown">Hagerstown</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>)
 to its vMVPD service's lineup. Although some of Nexstar's 29 CW 
affiliates were reportedly added to Hulu beginning in February, the 
terms of the deal do not specify whether carriage of other CW stations 
operated by Nexstar were included as part of the agreement.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>237<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>238<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>239<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">2
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Writers_Guild_of_America" title="Writers Guild of America">Writers Guild of America</a> commences a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Writers_Guild_of_America_strike" title="2023 Writers Guild of America strike">strike</a> against television and film studios, its first labor stoppage since <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_Writers_Guild_of_America_strike" title="2007–08 Writers Guild of America strike">2007</a> and the largest production stoppage for the American entertainment industry since <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_television_in_the_United_States" title="Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on television in the United States">2020</a>, after the union and the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alliance_of_Motion_Picture_and_Television_Producers" title="Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers">Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers</a>
 failed to agree on a new contract by the WGA's May 1 renewal deadline. 
The WGA sought increases in compensation and residuals, and greater 
protections for over-scale pay (citing a decline in pay despite the 
expansion of content with the rise of streaming services in recent years
 that effectively created a "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gig_worker" title="Gig worker">gig economy</a>"
 for unionized writers), staffing requirements for television shows to 
employ a certain number of writers for a specified period of time 
(regardless of need for specific episodes), curbs on mini-rooms (where 
groups of writers outline story breakdowns and write scripts), and 
restrictions on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chatbot" title="Chatbot">chatbot</a> scriptwriting. The strike immediately halted production of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Late_night_television_in_the_United_States" class="mw-redirect" title="Late night television in the United States">late night talk and variety shows</a>; and, just as how the Fall network schedules were impacted by the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1981_Writers_Guild_of_America_strike" title="1981 Writers Guild of America strike">1981</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1988_Writers_Guild_of_America_strike" title="1988 Writers Guild of America strike">1988</a>
 strikes in addition to being compounded by the concurring SAG–AFTRA 
strike that would begin on July 14, halted or delayed development and 
production of scripted series for the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023%E2%80%9324_United_States_network_television_schedule" title="2023–24 United States network television schedule">2023–24 network schedule</a>
 (resulting in unscripted programs, and acquired foreign, cable and 
streaming series occupying much of the Fall schedule), along with cable 
and streaming programs that have uncompleted episodes. At the outset, 
prime time network schedules were not significantly disrupted at the 
strike's commencement (after production on most scripted network shows 
for the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022%E2%80%9323_United_States_network_television_schedule" title="2022–23 United States network television schedule">2022–23 season</a>
 had already concluded). As well, some shows that employed 
paerticipating WGA members continued production, either without 
pre-written material (including talk shows <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_View_(talk_show)" class="mw-redirect" title="The View (talk show)">The View</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Kelly_Clarkson_Show" title="The Kelly Clarkson Show">The Kelly Clarkson Show</a></i> and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gutfeld!" title="Gutfeld!">Gutfeld!</a></i>) or using <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_core" title="Financial core">fi-core</a> and non-union writers to continue ongoing and planned storylines (as <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soap_opera" title="Soap opera">soap operas</a>
 had done during previous strikes). The WGA would declare the strike 
over effective at 12:01AM on September 27, three days after the Guild 
and AMPTP reached a tentative agreement that was approved by Guild 
leadership on September 26, and allowing its rank and file to return to 
work while they perform a ratification vote.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>240<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>241<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>242<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>243<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 9<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>A man fires an <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_rifle" title="Automatic rifle">automatic-style rifle</a> into a glass door panel outside the front lobby of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WHBQ-TV" title="WHBQ-TV">WHBQ</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memphis,_Tennessee" title="Memphis, Tennessee">Memphis</a>
 around 11:30&nbsp;a.m. CT. The suspect—who had a history of mental 
illness, and was in the midst of a mental episode that family and 
friends reportedly intended to seek help for that day—had earlier 
informed an employee of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/INSP_(TV_network)#Television_stations" title="INSP (TV network)">Imagicomm</a>-
owned Fox affiliate that he was carrying a gun while talking to them 
outside the studio's front gate. Employees were evacuated to a back 
parking lot for around 30 minutes as police secured the area; no one was
 injured. The suspect was arrested about two hours later at a nearby 
burger restaurant, where he was barricaded inside a bathroom and posted a
 <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facebook" title="Facebook">Facebook Live</a> video, in which he insisted on speaking with "news people" about alleged evidence into <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Police_corruption" title="Police corruption">corruption</a> in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memphis_Police_Department" title="Memphis Police Department">Memphis Police Department</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>244<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>245<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>246<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 10<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">4
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NHL" class="mw-redirect" title="NHL">NHL</a>'s <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vegas_Golden_Knights" title="Vegas Golden Knights">Vegas Golden Knights</a> sign a multi-year agreement with the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._W._Scripps_Company" title="E. W. Scripps Company">E. W. Scripps Company's</a> Scripps Sports division to air their regionally-televised games on Ion O&amp;O <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KMCC" title="KMCC">KMCC</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laughlin,_Nevada" title="Laughlin, Nevada">Laughlin</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Las_Vegas" title="Las Vegas">Las Vegas</a> (which will become an independent station). The deal, effective with the 2023–24 season, replaces <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AT%26T_SportsNet_Rocky_Mountain" title="AT&amp;T SportsNet Rocky Mountain">AT&amp;T SportsNet Rocky Mountain</a> as the Knights' television partner and expands the team's local relationship with Scripps (KMCC sister station <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KTNV" class="mw-redirect" title="KTNV">KTNV</a> has carried the Knights' preseason and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NHL_on_ABC" title="NHL on ABC">ABC-televised</a> regular season games since the team's inaugural <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_Vegas_Golden_Knights_season" title="2017–18 Vegas Golden Knights season">2017–18 season</a>,
 concurrent with its AT&amp;T SportsNet contract). Scripps will 
syndicate the Knights telecasts to stations across the team's broadcast 
territory, including the company's stations in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KIVI-TV" title="KIVI-TV">Boise</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KUPX-TV" title="KUPX-TV">Salt Lake City</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montana_Television_Network" title="Montana Television Network">Montana</a>. The Knights are the first major-league team to cut ties with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AT%26T_SportsNet" title="AT&amp;T SportsNet">AT&amp;T SportsNet</a> since its parent, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warner_Bros._Discovery" title="Warner Bros. Discovery">Warner Bros. Discovery</a>, announced its intent to exit the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_sports_network" title="Regional sports network">RSN</a> business.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-KMCC_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KMCC-257"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>247<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-tvnt-knights_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tvnt-knights-258"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>248<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-ktnv-knights_259-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ktnv-knights-259"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>249<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gray_Television" class="mw-redirect" title="Gray Television">Gray Television</a> fires <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Dakota_State_Capitol" title="South Dakota State Capitol">South Dakota State Capitol</a> reporter Austin Goss (who filed reports for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KOTA-TV" title="KOTA-TV">KOTA</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KEVN" class="mw-redirect" title="KEVN">KEVN</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rapid_City" class="mw-redirect" title="Rapid City">Rapid City</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KSFY" class="mw-redirect" title="KSFY">KSFY</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KDLT" class="mw-redirect" title="KDLT">KDLT</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sioux_Falls" class="mw-redirect" title="Sioux Falls">Sioux Falls</a>) following his arrest on charges of making "threatening, harassing or misleading contacts" tied to a January 23 <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prank_call" title="Prank call">prank call</a> he made to former <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Dakota_Senate" title="South Dakota Senate">South Dakota State Senator</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Dakota_Republican_Party" title="South Dakota Republican Party">Republican Party</a> chairman <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dan_Lederman" title="Dan Lederman">Dan Lederman</a> by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caller_ID_spoofing" title="Caller ID spoofing">spoofing</a> the personal cell phone number of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governor_of_South_Dakota" title="Governor of South Dakota">Governor</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kristi_Noem" title="Kristi Noem">Kristi Noem</a>, which a state investigation found that Goss may have obtained during "personal and professional" communications with her.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>250<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>5
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC_Sports_California" title="NBC Sports California">NBC Sports California</a> suspends veteran <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oakland_Athletics" title="Oakland Athletics">Oakland Athletics</a> play-by-play announcer <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glen_Kuiper" title="Glen Kuiper">Glen Kuiper</a>, after he appeared to refer to the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negro_Leagues_Baseball_Museum" title="Negro Leagues Baseball Museum">Negro Leagues Baseball Museum</a> as the "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nigger" title="Nigger">nigger</a> league museum" during the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pre-game_show" title="Pre-game show">pre-game show</a> for that night's away game against the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas_City_Royals" title="Kansas City Royals">Kansas City Royals</a> at <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kauffman_Stadium" title="Kauffman Stadium">Kauffman Stadium</a>. Kuiper apologized for the remarks—which he made while discussing a visit he and broadcast partner <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dallas_Braden" title="Dallas Braden">Dallas Braden</a>
 made to the museum earlier that day—following a commercial break at the
 top of the sixth inning. The A's denounced Kuiper's remarks in a 
statement on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">Twitter</a>, calling his use of the slur "unacceptable." Kuiper was fired by NBC Sports California on May 22.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>251<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>252<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>253<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>254<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>255<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>256<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>257<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>

<th>6
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coronation_of_Charles_III_and_Camilla" title="Coronation of Charles III and Camilla">coronation</a> of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_Charles_III" class="mw-redirect" title="King Charles III">King Charles III</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queen_Camilla" title="Queen Camilla">Queen Camilla</a> is televised on all major broadcast networks, cable news channels and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_America" title="BBC America">BBC America</a>.
 The ceremony was watched cumulatively by 10.9 million viewers according
 to Nielsen, with ABC's coverage leading all networks with 3.04 million 
viewers.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>258<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>259<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>

<tr>
<th>7
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_MTV_Movie_%26_TV_Awards" title="2023 MTV Movie &amp; TV Awards">2023 MTV Movie &amp; TV Awards</a> are broadcast on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MTV" title="MTV">MTV</a> and its sister networks, with <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scream_VI" title="Scream VI">Scream VI</a></i> (Best Movie) and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Last_of_Us_(TV_series)" title="The Last of Us (TV series)">The Last of Us</a></i> (Best Show) among the notable winners. Originally planned as a live ceremony (from the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barker_Hangar" class="mw-redirect" title="Barker Hangar">Barker Hangar</a> in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santa_Monica,_California" title="Santa Monica, California">Santa Monica, California</a>), the event airs instead as a prerecorded presentation in the wake of several attendees, and previously announced emcee <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drew_Barrymore" title="Drew Barrymore">Drew Barrymore</a>, withdrawing in solidarity with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Writers_Guild_of_America_strike" title="2023 Writers Guild of America strike">striking WGA members</a>,
 as well as plans by the Guild to picket the event. (Barrymore, who 
still appeared on the broadcast in pre-recorded skits, has agreed to 
host the ceremony in 2024.)
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>260<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>261<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>262<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>263<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>8
</th>
<td>Nexstar Media Group announces it will acquire independent station <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KUSI" class="mw-redirect" title="KUSI">KUSI</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Diego" title="San Diego">San Diego</a> from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McKinnon_Broadcasting" title="McKinnon Broadcasting">McKinnon Broadcasting</a> for $35 million. The deal would create a duopoly with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox</a> affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KSWB-TV" title="KSWB-TV">KSWB</a>
 (the first such duopoly in the San Diego market), and marks the 
family-owned McKinnon's exit from broadcasting (McKinnon, which was 
founded in 1962, had launched KUSI in 1982 and the station was its last 
television property following the 2010 sale of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KIII" title="KIII">KIII</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corpus_Christi,_Texas" title="Corpus Christi, Texas">Corpus Christi</a> to London Broadcasting Company). Nexstar plans to turn KUSI into a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_CW" title="The CW">CW</a> affiliate once its contract with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tegna,_Inc." class="mw-redirect" title="Tegna, Inc.">Tegna</a>-owned <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KFMB-TV" title="KFMB-TV">KFMB-DT2</a> (which runs through September 2026) expires or is terminated early.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>264<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>265<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>266<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>267<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 11<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>9
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramount_Media_Networks" title="Paramount Media Networks">Paramount Media Networks</a> announces it will shut down <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MTV_News" title="MTV News">MTV News</a>
 as part of broader layoffs and cost-cutting at the company, affecting 
25% of the company's U.S.-based staff. Launched in 1987 but affected by 
downsizing in its later years, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MTV" title="MTV">MTV</a>'s
 news and documentary division was noted for its coverage of music, 
politics, lifestyle, and pop culture that was geared toward the 
network's younger audiences. Paramount Global also announces the 
consolidation of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Showtime_Networks" title="Showtime Networks">Showtime Networks</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MTV_Entertainment_Studios" title="MTV Entertainment Studios">MTV Entertainment Studios</a>
 into a single "studio" unit, and the nine separate operations teams of 
the Paramount Media Networks cable channels into one portfolio group.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>268<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>269<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>10
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a>'s <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaitlan_Collins" title="Kaitlan Collins">Kaitlan Collins</a> moderated a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN_Republican_Town_Hall_with_Donald_Trump" title="CNN Republican Town Hall with Donald Trump">town hall</a> with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> at <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saint_Anselm_College" title="Saint Anselm College">Saint Anselm College</a> in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goffstown,_New_Hampshire" title="Goffstown, New Hampshire">Goffstown, New Hampshire</a>, in front of an audience primarily made of likely Republican primary voters. The former <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">president</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Republican_Party_presidential_primaries" title="2024 Republican Party presidential primaries">2024 Republican presidential candidate</a> made <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/False_or_misleading_statements_by_Donald_Trump" title="False or misleading statements by Donald Trump">numerous false claims</a> (including repeating voter fraud allegations in his <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempts_to_overturn_the_2020_United_States_presidential_election" title="Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election">2020 presidential election loss</a>); reiterated his support of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_U.S._Capitol_attack" class="mw-redirect" title="2021 U.S. Capitol attack">2021 U.S. Capitol attack</a>; credited himself for appointing three of the six <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Supreme_Court" class="mw-redirect" title="United States Supreme Court">Supreme Court</a> justices who overruled the landmark <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roe_v._Wade" title="Roe v. Wade">Roe v. Wade</a></i> abortion ruling in the 2022 <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dobbs_v._Jackson_Women%27s_Health_Organization" title="Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization">Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization</a></i> decision; and sidestepped questions about whom he supported in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="Russian invasion of Ukraine">Russian invasion of Ukraine</a> and if he supported a national abortion ban during the event. Warner Bros. Discovery CEO <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Zaslav" title="David Zaslav">David Zaslav</a> and CNN Global CEO <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Licht" title="Chris Licht">Chris Licht</a>
 defended the decision to hold the town hall; however, media observers, 
CNN staffers, and Trump critics across the political spectrum denounced 
it for appearing to "normalize" his candidacy—despite Trump being the 
subject of multiple criminal and civil cases (including federal and 
state investigations into his attempts to overturn the 2020 election, 
and a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._Jean_Carroll_vs._Donald_J._Trump" class="mw-redirect" title="E. Jean Carroll vs. Donald J. Trump">New York civil trial that concluded the day prior</a>, in which he was found liable of sexually abusing and defaming former <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elle_(magazine)" title="Elle (magazine)">Elle</a></i> columnist <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._Jean_Carroll" title="E. Jean Carroll">E. Jean Carroll</a>,
 remarks about whom Trump made during the event were amended into a 
separate defamation lawsuit against Trump, filed by Carroll in 2019, on 
May 22), and his tendency to make false claims and spread 
disinformation. In response to the event, legal commentator Tristan 
Snell said he would no longer appear on CNN under its current 
leadership. The town hall was watched by 3.1 million viewers according 
to Nielsen, lower than that of the network's July 2022 town hall with 
President <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a> (3.7 million).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>270<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>271<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>272<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>273<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>274<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">15
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WideOpenWest" class="mw-redirect" title="WideOpenWest">WideOpenWest</a> announces it will discontinue its in-house pay television services, Ultra TV (a traditional pay-TV service relying on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QAM_(television)" title="QAM (television)">QAM</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_protocol_television" class="mw-redirect" title="Internet protocol television">IP</a>-based <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Set-top_box" title="Set-top box">set-top boxes</a> that launched in 2011) and WOW TV+ (an IPTV service using <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Android_TV" title="Android TV">Android TV</a>
 infrastructure that launched in March 2020), and migrate its remaining 
video customers—totaling 117,100 subscribers as of Q1 2023, a 6.2% 
decline from Q4 2022—to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YouTube_TV" title="YouTube TV">YouTube TV</a>, under a partnership that wil see the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alphabet_Inc." title="Alphabet Inc.">Alphabet</a>-owned vMVPD provider be offered as part of WOW!'s Internet bundle, beginning that Summer.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>275<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>276<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>278<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 12<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Country singer <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reba_McEntire" title="Reba McEntire">Reba McEntire</a>, who earlier served as an advisor in the Knockout rounds for the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Voice_(American_season_23)" class="mw-redirect" title="The Voice (American season 23)">23rd season</a> of <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Voice_(American_TV_series)" title="The Voice (American TV series)">The Voice</a></i>, was announced to succeed outgoing coach <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blake_Shelton" title="Blake Shelton">Blake Shelton</a>—
the last of the NBC music competition series' four original coaches, who
 earlier announced his departure prior to the Season 23 premiere—for the
 <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Voice_(American_season_24)" class="mw-redirect" title="The Voice (American season 24)">24th season</a>. The semifinals, which followed a real-time voting structure without an "Instant Save" feature for the first time since <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Voice_(American_season_5)" class="mw-redirect" title="The Voice (American season 5)">Season 5</a>,
 saw both artists coached by Shelton, Grace West and NOVIAS, advancing 
to the following week's final round; both artists would go on to lose to
 eventual winner <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gina_Miles_(singer)" title="Gina Miles (singer)">Gina Miles</a>, who was coached by former <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One_Direction" title="One Direction">One Direction</a> member and debuting coach <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niall_Horan" title="Niall Horan">Niall Horan</a>, making him the series' tenth overall winning coach and the third coach to win on their first attempt.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>279<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>280<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>281<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>282<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">17
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mission_Broadcasting" title="Mission Broadcasting">Mission Broadcasting</a> announces it will acquire MyNetworkTV affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WADL_(TV)" title="WADL (TV)">WADL</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Clemens,_Michigan" title="Mount Clemens, Michigan">Mount Clemens, Michigan</a> from Adell Broadcasting Corp. for $75 million. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clinton_Township,_Macomb_County,_Michigan" title="Clinton Township, Macomb County, Michigan">Clinton Township</a>-based Adell, which signed on WADL in May 1989, will retain ownership of religious broadcaster <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Word_Network" title="The Word Network">The Word Network</a> and radio station <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WFDF_(AM)" title="WFDF (AM)">WFDF</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farmington_Hills" class="mw-redirect" title="Farmington Hills">Farmington Hills</a>.
 Upon closure, Mission intends to contract with partner company Nexstar 
Media Group to provide operational services for WADL, which it planned 
to turn into <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Detroit" title="Detroit">Detroit</a>'s affiliate of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_CW" title="The CW">The CW</a> (a network majority owned by Nexstar); the station briefly affiliated with the network on September 1 (replacing <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WKBD" class="mw-redirect" title="WKBD">WKBD</a>), before moving to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._W._Scripps_Company" title="E. W. Scripps Company">Scripps</a>-owned <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WMYD" title="WMYD">WMYD</a>
 due to a dispute between Adell and Mission/Nexstar over their 
affiliation contract. The sale was approved eleven months later on April
 23, 2024; however because of issues concerning Nexstar's management of 
Mission-owned <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPIX" title="WPIX">WPIX</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>
 (which resulted in a $1.82-million fine, and a requirement for Mission 
to sell the station to Nexstar or an independent third-party to comply 
with FCC ownership rules that the LMA's structure had purportedly 
violated due to attributable interests in the latter's involvement with 
WPIX), the approval was conditioned on Nexstar not being involved in 
financing Mission's purchase of the station, Mission enforcing limits to
 performance bonuses and ad revenues provided to Nexstar under any LMA 
between the two groups, the station limiting carriage of 
Nexstar-provided programming to no more than 15% of the station's weekly
 programming time (a clause normally applied to local programming 
provided by a station operator under LMA rules that likely constrains 
WADL from carrying the full CW schedule as intended, particularly as 
Scripps plans to drop it from WMYD in September 2024 as part of a 
chain-wide disaffiliation from the network), and that any SSA cannot 
include an option for Nexstar to purchase WADL outright.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>283<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-sale_296-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sale-296"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>284<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-lma_297-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lma-297"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>285<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>286<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>287<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>288<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a> announces that <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaitlan_Collins" title="Kaitlan Collins">Kaitlan Collins</a> will become the new permanent host in the weeknight 9:00&nbsp;p.m. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_Time_Zone" title="Eastern Time Zone">ET</a> timeslot, vacant since the December 2021 firing of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Cuomo" title="Chris Cuomo">Chris Cuomo</a> (see December 4). <i>The Source with Kaitlan Collins</i> debuted on July 9, which replaced the <i>CNN Tonight</i>, later <i>CNN PrimeTime</i> guest host rotation in place from the beginning of December 2021 to May 2023.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>289<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>19
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citadel_Communications" title="Citadel Communications">Citadel Communications</a> announces that it will sell independent station <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WSNN-LD" title="WSNN-LD">WSNN-LD</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarasota,_Florida" title="Sarasota, Florida">Sarasota, Florida</a> to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nexstar_Media_Group" title="Nexstar Media Group">Nexstar Media Group</a>
 for $1 million. The transaction, which is expected to be completed by 
the end of the year, will combine the station with Nexstar's existing 
Tampa–St. Petersburg duopoly of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WFLA-TV" title="WFLA-TV">WFLA</a>
 (NBC) and WTTA (MyNetworkTV), and marks Citadel's exit from 
broadcasting; the company—which acquired WSNN in 2009—had owned nine 
major-network stations in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midwest" class="mw-redirect" title="Midwest">Midwest</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_England" title="New England">New England</a> (including current Nexstar properties <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WHBF-TV" title="WHBF-TV">WHBF</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rock_Island,_Illinois" title="Rock Island, Illinois">Rock Island</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davenport,_Iowa" title="Davenport, Iowa">Davenport</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KCAU" class="mw-redirect" title="KCAU">KCAU</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sioux_City" class="mw-redirect" title="Sioux City">Sioux City</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WIVT" title="WIVT">WIVT</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binghamton" class="mw-redirect" title="Binghamton">Binghamton</a>) at various points from its founding in 1982 until 2019. The sale was finalized on July 20.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>290<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>292<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>293<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>22
</th>
<td>Fifteen months to the date after it was first announced, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tegna_Inc." title="Tegna Inc.">Tegna</a> announces it has terminated its deal to be acquired by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hedge_fund" title="Hedge fund">hedge fund</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_General" title="Standard General">Standard General</a>.
 The $8.6-billion deal, which was originally slated to be completed in 
the second half of 2022, had faced regulatory hurdles (the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FCC" class="mw-redirect" title="FCC">FCC</a>'s Media Bureau had designated the deal for a hearing by an <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Administrative_law_judge" title="Administrative law judge">administrative law judge</a>
 in February), scrutiny from lawmakers and labor unions concerned over 
job losses (in part because the deal did not address conflicts with 
stations operated by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cox_Media_Group" title="Cox Media Group">Cox Media Group</a>—whose majority owner, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apollo_Global_Management" title="Apollo Global Management">Apollo Global Management</a>,
 helped finance the deal—in four markets), and a deadline for Standard 
General to arrange financing for the deal on this date. As a result of 
the deal's termination, Tegna (which owns and operates 68 stations in 54
 markets) announces a share repurchase plan and the collection of a $136
 million termination fee from Standard General.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>294<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>295<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>296<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>23
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netflix" title="Netflix">Netflix</a>
 begins cracking down on unauthorized password sharing between 
subscribers and non-paying customers in the U.S. by introducing an 
$8/month "extra member" option to permit access to users who do not live
 in the account holder's household, and intending to block devices 
attempting to access a user's Netflix account without paying over a 
certain timeframe. Netflix initially tested the "extra member" 
program—which resulted in account cancellations in countries where 
paid-sharing has been implemented—to primary account holders in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Costa_Rica" title="Costa Rica">Costa Rica</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a> in 2022, and formally commenced paid-sharing in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand" title="New Zealand">New Zealand</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portugal</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> In February 2023.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>297<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>298<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 13<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>24
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gray_Television" class="mw-redirect" title="Gray Television">Gray Television</a> files a lawsuit in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eleventh_Circuit_Court_of_Appeals" class="mw-redirect" title="Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals">Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals</a> that requests to vacate a $518,283 fine issued by the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FCC" class="mw-redirect" title="FCC">FCC</a>
 in July 2021 (which was upheld on appeal in a 3–1 vote by the FCC Media
 Bureau in October 2022), pertaining to a July 2020 non-license asset 
deal between Gray and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GCI_(company)" class="mw-redirect" title="GCI (company)">Denali Media Holdings</a> that saw the former acquire and transfer the CBS affiliation rights for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anchorage" class="mw-redirect" title="Anchorage">Anchorage</a> from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KTVA" title="KTVA">KTVA</a> (now a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rewind_TV" title="Rewind TV">Rewind TV</a> affiliate) to Gray-owned KYES (now <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KAUU" title="KAUU">KAUU</a>). Because Gray already owned NBC affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KTUU" class="mw-redirect" title="KTUU">KTUU</a>, the FCC considered the transaction as equivalent to purchasing a second top-four station in violation of FCC <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duopoly_(broadcasting)" title="Duopoly (broadcasting)">duopoly</a>
 regulations. Gray—which acquired KAUU (then a lower-rated MyNetworkTV 
affiliate) in 2016—contends the FCC had no authority to regulate the 
affiliation purchase as it did not involve a license transfer, that its 
regulation of a "functional equivalent" to the agency's Top-4 Rule via 
the fine exceeds the agency's regulatory authority, and that the fine 
violates the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Amendment" class="mw-redirect" title="First Amendment">First Amendment</a> by penalizing Gray's programming decisions without furthering a "legitimate" government interest.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>299<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>300<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>301<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>29
</th>
<td>Silver Chalice acquires majority control of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stadium_(sports_network)" title="Stadium (sports network)">Stadium</a> from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinclair_Broadcast_Group" title="Sinclair Broadcast Group">Sinclair Broadcast Group</a> (which co-founded the broadcast/streaming sports network with the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_White_Sox" title="Chicago White Sox">Chicago White Sox</a> subsidiary in 2017, as a reconfiguration of Sinclair's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Sports_Network" title="American Sports Network">American Sports Network</a>
 syndication service). Sinclair cites that the decision to sell its 
controlling stake in Stadium was due to insufficient viewership to 
justify continued financing, refuting a report by <i>Front Office Sports</i> disclosing the purchase that it was tied to financial issues related to the recent bankruptcy of its <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diamond_Sports_Group" class="mw-redirect" title="Diamond Sports Group">Diamond Sports Group</a>
 unit. Stadium will maintain its affiliation agreements with 
Sinclair-run stations, while Sinclair will continue to supply some 
programming for the network.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>302<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>303<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>30
</th>
<td>One week after failing to make a rights payment before the end of its fee grace period, Diamond Sports Group informs the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Diego_Padres" title="San Diego Padres">San Diego Padres</a> that it will no longer provide financing to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bally_Sports_San_Diego" title="Bally Sports San Diego">Bally Sports San Diego</a> that would enable the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_sports_network" title="Regional sports network">regional sports network</a> to continue paying fees to the team. The Padres' local television rights consequently reverted to the team and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> following that evening's game against <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Marlins" title="Miami Marlins">Miami</a>
 (the first of a three-game away series), marking the first instance 
since Diamond's March 14 bankruptcy filing that it returned the local 
MLB broadcast rights to a franchise. The league took over production of 
the Padres' regional telecasts starting with the May 31 Padres–Marlins 
game, and began carrying them on alternate channels on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cox_Communications" title="Cox Communications">Cox</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectrum_(brand)" title="Spectrum (brand)">Spectrum</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U-verse" class="mw-redirect" title="U-verse">U-verse</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DirecTV" title="DirecTV">DirecTV</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fubo" class="mw-redirect" title="Fubo">Fubo</a> within the team's home market, along with, for the first time ever, a blackout-free, direct-to-consumer option via <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MLB.tv" class="mw-redirect" title="MLB.tv">MLB.tv</a>. Game announcers <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don_Orsillo" title="Don Orsillo">Don Orsillo</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Grant_(baseball)" title="Mark Grant (baseball)">Mark Grant</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Scanlan" title="Bob Scanlan">Bob Scanlan</a> will remain on the broadcasts as they are directly employed by the Padres.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>304<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>305<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 14<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="June">June</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: June"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th>Date
</th>
<th>Event
</th>
<th>Source
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th>4
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chuck_Todd" title="Chuck Todd">Chuck Todd</a> announces that he will stepping down as moderator of <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meet_the_Press" title="Meet the Press">Meet the Press</a></i>
 after nine years. Todd's tenure as moderator, which would end on 
September 10, saw the NBC program launch into other ventures (including 
the NBC News Now extension show <i>Meet The Press Now</i>, which Welker co-hosts and had originally debuted on MSNBC in 2015 as <i>MTP Daily</i>,
 weekly podcasts and a documentary film festival), and Todd himself 
facing criticism from some viewers and media critics for not pushing 
back against false statements made by guests (particularly those made by
 former president <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_presidency_of_Donald_Trump" title="First presidency of Donald Trump">his administration</a>'s officials, and his archconservative supporters in political leadership). Todd will be succeeded as <i>MTP</i> moderator on September 17 by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC_News" title="NBC News">NBC News</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_House" title="White House">White House</a> correspondent <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kristen_Welker" title="Kristen Welker">Kristen Welker</a>, who will move from the co-anchor chair at <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weekend_Today" title="Weekend Today">Saturday Today</a></i> to become the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunday_morning_talk_show" title="Sunday morning talk show">political talk show</a>'s first female moderator (since co-creator <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martha_Rountree" title="Martha Rountree">Martha Rountree</a>'s 1947–53 tenure as its original host), as well as the first <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Person_of_color" title="Person of color">person of color</a> to regularly serve as the program's moderator (Welker is of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiracial_people" title="Multiracial people">mixed</a> Black–Caucasian heritage).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>306<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>307<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>308<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>6
</th>
<td><i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Forum_of_Fargo-Moorhead" title="The Forum of Fargo-Moorhead">The Forum of Fargo-Moorhead</a></i> reports that <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_River_Broadcasting" title="Red River Broadcasting">Red River Broadcasting</a> has exercised an option to terminate the sale of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox</a> affiliates <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KQDS-TV" title="KQDS-TV">KQDS</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duluth" class="mw-redirect" title="Duluth">Duluth</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superior,_Wisconsin" title="Superior, Wisconsin">Superior</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KVRR" title="KVRR">KVRR</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fargo,_North_Dakota" title="Fargo, North Dakota">Fargo</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moorhead,_Minnesota" title="Moorhead, Minnesota">Moorhead</a> to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forum_Communications" class="mw-redirect" title="Forum Communications">Forum Communications</a>. The $24-million deal, first announced in November 2021, was dependent on the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FCC" class="mw-redirect" title="FCC">FCC</a> approving a waiver of ownership rules prohibiting the combination of two full-power "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Three_television_networks" class="mw-redirect" title="Big Three television networks">Big Four</a>" outlets in the same market, in order to allow a duopoly between KVRR and Forum-owned <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a> affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WDAY-TV" title="WDAY-TV">WDAY</a>.
 The FCC, which has only once approved such a "Big Four" duopoly (in 
2019), had not yet considered the Fargo waiver. (Forum, which also owns <i>The Forum</i> and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duluth_News_Tribune" title="Duluth News Tribune">News Tribune</a></i>
 newspapers in the respective cities, would have had no such issues in 
Duluth as it has no existing television properties in that market.)
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>309<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>310<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 15<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">7
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warner_Bros._Discovery" title="Warner Bros. Discovery">Warner Bros. Discovery</a> announces the departure of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Licht" title="Chris Licht">Chris Licht</a> as CEO of its <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN_Global" class="mw-redirect" title="CNN Global">CNN Global</a>
 division after just over one year. Licht had already ceded operational 
control of the network to WBD Chief Corporate Operating Officer David 
Leavy in the fallout from the Donald Trump town hall meeting, though the
 ouster came in the aftermath of the June 2 publication of a 
less-than-flattering <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Atlantic" title="The Atlantic">Atlantic</a></i> article documenting Licht's short but tumultuous tenure at CNN.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>311<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>312<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>313<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Actor <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jay_Johnston" title="Jay Johnston">Jay Johnston</a> is arrested by the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FBI" class="mw-redirect" title="FBI">FBI</a> for his alleged involvement in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/January_6_United_States_Capitol_attack" title="January 6 United States Capitol attack">January 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol</a>. The comedian/actor (known for his roles in <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mr._Show_with_Bob_and_David" title="Mr. Show with Bob and David">Mr. Show with Bob and David</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sarah_Silverman_Program" title="The Sarah Silverman Program">The Sarah Silverman Program</a></i> and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob%27s_Burgers" title="Bob's Burgers">Bob's Burgers</a></i>) was charged by the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Department_of_Justice" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Department of Justice">U.S. Department of Justice</a> on counts that include <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_disorder" title="Civil disorder">civil disorder</a>, entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disorderly_conduct" title="Disorderly conduct">disorderly or disruptive conduct</a> in a restricted building or grounds, and impeding passage through Capitol property.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>314<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>11
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/76th_Tony_Awards" title="76th Tony Awards">76th Tony Awards</a> air on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramount%2B" title="Paramount+">Paramount+</a> from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York</a>'s <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Palace" title="United Palace">United Palace</a>, with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ariana_DeBose" title="Ariana DeBose">Ariana DeBose</a> as host. Notable winners included <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kimberly_Akimbo" title="Kimberly Akimbo">Kimberly Akimbo</a></i> (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Award_for_Best_Musical" title="Tony Award for Best Musical">Best Musical</a>), <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leopoldstadt_(play)" title="Leopoldstadt (play)">Leopoldstadt</a></i> (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Award_for_Best_Play" title="Tony Award for Best Play">Best Play</a>), and the first two non-binary performers to win acting awards (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Harrison_Ghee" title="J. Harrison Ghee">J. Harrison Ghee</a> for <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Some_Like_It_Hot_(musical)" title="Some Like It Hot (musical)">Some Like It Hot</a></i> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_Newell" title="Alex Newell">Alex Newell</a> for <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shucked" title="Shucked">Shucked</a></i>). The ceremony and telecast were initially postponed on May 12 after organizers for the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tonys" class="mw-redirect" title="Tonys">Tonys</a> were denied a waiver request from the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Writers_Guild_of_America" title="Writers Guild of America">Writers Guild of America</a> to use pre-written material during the Guild's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Writers_Guild_of_America_strike" title="2023 Writers Guild of America strike">strike</a> against the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alliance_of_Motion_Picture_and_Television_Producers" title="Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers">Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers</a>
 (both CBS and Paramount+ are AMPTP members). But by May 16, organizers 
agree to ceremony alterations—including refraining from using a script 
and placing an emphasis on live performances from Tony-nominated 
shows—thus allowing the event to proceed without a WGA waiver or picket 
line.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>315<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>316<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>317<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
