<tr>
<th rowspan="3">12
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denver_Nuggets" title="Denver Nuggets">Denver Nuggets</a> defeat the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Heat" title="Miami Heat">Miami Heat</a>, 94–89, in Game 5 of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_NBA_Finals" title="2023 NBA Finals">2023 NBA Finals</a>
 to win their first championship in franchise history; the Nuggets, in 
their first-ever Finals appearance, defeated the Heat in four of five 
games in the best-of-seven series; ABC carried the NBA Finals 
exclusively for the 21st consecutive year. This year's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_NBA_playoffs" title="2023 NBA playoffs">NBA playoffs</a>, which began on April 15 (and were televised on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_on_TNT" title="NBA on TNT">TNT</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_on_ESPN" title="NBA on ESPN">ESPN</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_on_ABC" title="NBA on ABC">ABC</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_TV" title="NBA TV">NBA TV</a>—
with each team's regional broadcaster also televising local coverage of 
First Round games, except for most weekend games that ABC televised 
nationally), saw ESPN/ABC carry the Western Conference Finals and TNT 
carry the Eastern Conference Finals, per the alternating exclusivity 
rotation under the NBA's contracts with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN_Inc." title="ESPN Inc.">ESPN Inc.</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warner_Bros._Discovery_Sports" class="mw-redirect" title="Warner Bros. Discovery Sports">Warner Bros. Discovery Sports</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>318<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>319<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>320<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 16<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Sajak" title="Pat Sajak">Pat Sajak</a> announced on social media that he would retire as host of <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wheel_of_Fortune_(American_game_show)" title="Wheel of Fortune (American game show)">Wheel of Fortune</a></i>
 at the conclusion of its 41st season in mid-2024; he will remain with 
the program thereafter as a consultant. Sajak has hosted the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony_Pictures_Television" title="Sony Pictures Television">Sony</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_Media_Ventures" title="CBS Media Ventures">CBS</a>-distributed game show since December 1981, when he succeeded <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chuck_Woolery" title="Chuck Woolery">Chuck Woolery</a>
 on the now-defunct network version (Sajak would  leave that version in 
January 1989, six months prior to its move from NBC to CBS, to host his 
own <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Pat_Sajak_Show" title="The Pat Sajak Show">late-night talk show</a>
 for the latter network), and began hosting the syndicated version when 
it debuted in September 1983. On June 27, it was announced that <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryan_Seacrest" title="Ryan Seacrest">Ryan Seacrest</a> will succeed Sajak as host for the 2024–25 season.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>321<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>322<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HFPA" class="mw-redirect" title="HFPA">HFPA</a> was rebranded to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_Globe_Foundation" title="Golden Globe Foundation">Golden Globe Foundation</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-GGF_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GGF-17"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">13
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vegas_Golden_Knights" title="Vegas Golden Knights">Vegas Golden Knights</a> defeat the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florida_Panthers" title="Florida Panthers">Florida Panthers</a>, 9–3, in Game 5 of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Stanley_Cup_Finals" title="2023 Stanley Cup Finals">2023 Stanley Cup Finals</a> to win their first championship in franchise history; the Golden Knights, which began play in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NHL" class="mw-redirect" title="NHL">NHL</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_Vegas_Golden_Knights_season" title="2017–18 Vegas Golden Knights season">six years</a> prior, defeated the Panthers in four of five games in the best-of-seven series. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NHL_on_TNT" title="NHL on TNT">TNT, TBS and TruTV</a>
 simulcasted this year's Stanley Cup Finals, per the alternating 
rotation under the NHL's contracts with ESPN Inc. and Warner Bros. 
Discovery Sports. It marked both the first time that the three networks 
carried the championship series and the first time since <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1994_Stanley_Cup_Finals" title="1994 Stanley Cup Finals">1994</a> (when it was carried nationally by ESPN and regionally by New York City-based <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MSG_Network" title="MSG Network">MSG</a>) that the Finals aired exclusively on cable in the U.S. This year's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Stanley_Cup_playoffs" title="2023 Stanley Cup playoffs">Stanley Cup playoffs</a> began on April 17, and was televised on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NHL_on_ABC" title="NHL on ABC">ABC</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NHL_on_ESPN" title="NHL on ESPN">ESPN, ESPN2</a>,
 TBS and TNT, with each franchise's regional broadcaster also televising
 local coverage of First Round games (except for weekend games that ABC 
televised nationally).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>323<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>324<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 17<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Sports analyst/commentator <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shannon_Sharpe" title="Shannon Sharpe">Shannon Sharpe</a> announces he will be leaving the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FS1" class="mw-redirect" title="FS1">FS1</a> morning sports talk show <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skip_and_Shannon:_Undisputed" class="mw-redirect" title="Skip and Shannon: Undisputed">Skip and Shannon: Undisputed</a></i>,
 which he has co-hosted since its debut in September 2016, following 
that day's broadcast. It was then announced that the show would take a 
hiatus until August 28 due to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Sports" title="Fox Sports">Fox Sports</a> failing to find a new debate partner with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skip_Bayless" title="Skip Bayless">Skip Bayless</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>325<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>326<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>327<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>20
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA" class="mw-redirect" title="NBA">NBA</a>'s <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Utah_Jazz" title="Utah Jazz">Utah Jazz</a> signs a multi-year agreement with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinclair_Broadcast_Group" title="Sinclair Broadcast Group">Sinclair Broadcast Group</a> to broadcast their regionally televised games and other team-specific programs on the company's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salt_Lake_City" title="Salt Lake City">Salt Lake City</a> duopoly of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KUTV" title="KUTV">KUTV</a> (CBS) and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KJZZ-TV" title="KJZZ-TV">KJZZ</a> (independent), effective with the league's 2023–24 season; the stations replace Warner Bros. Discovery-owned <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AT%26T_SportsNet_Rocky_Mountain" title="AT&amp;T SportsNet Rocky Mountain">AT&amp;T SportsNet Rocky Mountain</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Root_Sports_Northwest" title="Root Sports Northwest">Root Sports Northwest</a>
 as the Jazz's regional television partners. The deal also marks the 
team's return to KJZZ, which previously held over-the-air telecast 
rights to Jazz games from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1993%E2%80%9394_Utah_Jazz_season" title="1993–94 Utah Jazz season">1993</a> to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008%E2%80%9309_Utah_Jazz_season" title="2008–09 Utah Jazz season">2009</a>. Team owner <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryan_Smith_(businessman)" title="Ryan Smith (businessman)">Ryan Smith</a>'s
 holding company, Smith Entertainment Group, also starts a new in-house 
production division, SEG Media, to produce the telecasts, which will 
also be carried on a new subscription streaming service scheduled to 
launch in October. Game announcers <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Craig_Bolerjack" title="Craig Bolerjack">Craig Bolerjack</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thurl_Bailey" title="Thurl Bailey">Thurl Bailey</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holly_Rowe" title="Holly Rowe">Holly Rowe</a> will remain on the broadcasts as they are directly employed by the Jazz.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-Salt230620_345-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salt230620-345"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>328<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>329<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 18<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>21
</th>
<td>Television presenter <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geraldo_Rivera" title="Geraldo Rivera">Geraldo Rivera</a> announces he has quit the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_News" title="Fox News">Fox News</a> talk show <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Five_(talk_show)" title="The Five (talk show)">The Five</a></i>,
 which he has co-hosted since January 2022. On June 29, the same day his
 final episode was scheduled to air, Rivera announced that he would be 
leaving Fox News entirely after having quit the program; he later 
alleged in a July 13 appearance on <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_View_(talk_show)" class="mw-redirect" title="The View (talk show)">The View</a></i> that a "toxic [work] relationship" with an unnamed <i>Five</i> co-host led to his departure.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>330<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>331<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>332<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>23
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KQED_(TV)" title="KQED (TV)">KQED 9/San Francisco</a>'s <i>KQED Newsroom</i> ends after 55 years on television. KQED News continues on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KQED-FM" title="KQED-FM">KQED 88.5 FM</a>, online, and social media platforms.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>333<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>27
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roku" title="Roku">Roku</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_Sports" title="CBS Sports">CBS Sports</a> announce a multi-year deal to become the exclusive American media partners for the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formula_E" title="Formula E">Formula E</a>
 electric motorsport series. The deal marks the first sports rights 
agreement for Roku and expands CBS's existing relationship with the 
promotion; Roku will stream 11 races per season on the Roku Channel and 
CBS will carry five races per season that will also be streamed on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramount%2B" title="Paramount+">Paramount+</a>,
 with all races carried by the two streaming services being accessible 
through Roku's live-streaming sports aggregation platform.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>334<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>28
</th>
<td>As part of a multi-year agreement that also extends their existing carriage contract for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL_Network" title="NFL Network">NFL Network</a> and expands its distribution to co-owned DirecTV Stream and U-verse, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Football_League" title="National Football League">NFL Media</a> and DirecTV announce that the latter will add <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL_RedZone" title="NFL RedZone">NFL RedZone</a>
 to the lineups of its subscription television services. The addition of
 RedZone will allow DirecTV subscribers to continue to view regional NFL
 broadcasts not carried within their home market in some capacity, after
 the league's December 2022 deal with Google to distribute the package 
to YouTube TV and YouTube Primetime Channels customers resulted in 
DirecTV losing residential carriage rights to the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL_Sunday_Ticket" title="NFL Sunday Ticket">NFL Sunday Ticket</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Out-of-market_sports_package" title="Out-of-market sports package">out-of-market sports package</a> following the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_NFL_season" title="2022 NFL season">2022 season</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>335<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-leaguepass_356-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-leaguepass-356"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 19<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>29
</th>
<td>Nexstar Media Group fires <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/News_director" title="News director">news director</a> Stanton Tang and assistant news director Amy Fox from NBC affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WOOD-TV" title="WOOD-TV">WOOD</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Rapids" class="mw-redirect" title="Grand Rapids">Grand Rapids</a>, following an internal investigation into a leaked memo urging reporters and producers to cover fewer stories on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Michigan" title="West Michigan">West Michigan</a>-area <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pride_Month" title="Pride Month">Pride Month</a> events because of criticism from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservatism_in_the_United_States" title="Conservatism in the United States">conservative</a>
 viewers over related stories aired earlier that month on its newscasts.
 Tang—who, in the memo, had asked reporters to only cover Pride events 
if considered newsworthy and to pursue viewpoints reflecting "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Both_sides" class="mw-redirect" title="Both sides">both sides</a>" of the story—had also been accused by station journalists of having his own <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Right-wing_politics" title="Right-wing politics">right</a>-
leaning views influence editorial decisions (occasionally sending links 
to Twitter posts from conservative news outlets and commentators as 
story ideas in emails to reporters), and of fostering a hostile work 
environment within the news department (including pressuring and getting
 into intense arguments with journalists that caused some to take <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sick_leave" title="Sick leave">sick leave</a> due to mental anguish, and discouraging them from voting in the 2022 Michigan <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Michigan_gubernatorial_election" title="2022 Michigan gubernatorial election">gubernatorial</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections_in_Michigan" title="2022 United States House of Representatives elections in Michigan">U.S. House</a> primaries, only to later acknowledge he voted in that election, in possible violation of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voter_intimidation" class="mw-redirect" title="Voter intimidation">voter intimidation</a>
 laws); prior complaints about Tang's workplace conduct allegedly went 
unaddressed when brought up to WOOD general manager Julie Brinks and to 
Nexstar management. News producers Luke Stier and Madeline Odle were 
also terminated for leaking information about the memo to local media 
and broadcast industry outlets. Veteran television executive Steven 
Ackermann was appointed as interim news director on June 30.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>338<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>339<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>30
</th>
<td>In what the network describes as a move meant to "identify additional cost savings," <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">ESPN</a> lays off about 20 on-air personalities. The notable names confirmed on this date to be exiting include <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_on_ESPN" title="NBA on ESPN">NBA</a> analysts <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jalen_Rose" title="Jalen Rose">Jalen Rose</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeff_Van_Gundy" title="Jeff Van Gundy">Jeff Van Gundy</a>; NFL studio analysts <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Hasselbeck" title="Matt Hasselbeck">Matt Hasselbeck</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keyshawn_Johnson" title="Keyshawn Johnson">Keyshawn Johnson</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rob_Ninkovich" title="Rob Ninkovich">Rob Ninkovich</a>, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Young" title="Steve Young">Steve Young</a>; <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL" class="mw-redirect" title="NFL">NFL</a> draft expert <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Todd_McShay" title="Todd McShay">Todd McShay</a>; boxing analyst and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/This_Just_In_with_Max_Kellerman" class="mw-redirect" title="This Just In with Max Kellerman">This Just In</a></i> host <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Kellerman" title="Max Kellerman">Max Kellerman</a>; college football analyst <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Pollack" title="David Pollack">David Pollack</a>; college basketball analyst <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaPhonso_Ellis" title="LaPhonso Ellis">LaPhonso Ellis</a>; veteran reporter/host <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suzy_Kolber" title="Suzy Kolber">Suzy Kolber</a>; and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SportsCenter" title="SportsCenter">SportsCenter</a></i> anchors <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neil_Everett" title="Neil Everett">Neil Everett</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashley_Brewer" title="Ashley Brewer">Ashley Brewer</a>.
 It is the third round of layoffs this year at ESPN, following two waves
 affecting behind-the-scenes staffers earlier in the Spring.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>340<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>341<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="July">July</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: July"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th>Date
</th>
<th>Event
</th>
<th>Source
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th>1
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hawaiian_Telcom" title="Hawaiian Telcom">Hawaiian Telcom</a> removes the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honolulu" title="Honolulu">Honolulu</a> duopoly of Fox/CW affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KHON-TV" title="KHON-TV">KHON</a> and MyNetworkTV affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KHII-TV" title="KHII-TV">KHII</a>, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NewsNation" title="NewsNation">NewsNation</a> from its systems across the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">state</a>
 after failing to renew an agreement with Nexstar Media Group that 
expired on June 30. The provider filed an FCC complaint on July 6, 
asking for the commission to rule Nexstar's failure to continue the 
channels' carriage as a violation of good-faith negotiation rules for 
each day since the previous contract lapsed. Hawaiian Telcom, which 
noted the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hawaiian_Islands" title="Hawaiian Islands">Islands</a>' <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volcanic_island" title="Volcanic island">volcanic and mountainous terrain</a>
 prevents many residents from receiving KHON/KHII over-the-air and 
alleged that the group sought to increase fees to carry the channels by 
80%, accused Nexstar of withholding <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retransmission_consent" title="Retransmission consent">consent</a>
 by not responding to its request to extend negotiations by one 
week—forcing it to remove the channels—until immediately before the 
agreement expired. The parties reached a multi-year agreement to restore
 KHON/KHII (along with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rewind_TV" title="Rewind TV">Rewind TV</a>-
affiliated KHON-DT4) and NewsNation to Hawaiian Telcom's lineup on July 
20, although the provider stated it would not drop the Nexstar complaint
 (which it amended the day before to allege the group had unraveled an 
earlier version of the deal on July 17, demanding Hawaiian Telcom 
rescind the complaint and not file future FCC complaints against 
Nexstar).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>342<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>343<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>344<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 20<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>2
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DirecTV" title="DirecTV">DirecTV</a>
 removes 159 stations owned by Nexstar Media Group after the two parties
 fail to reach a new carriage agreement. The impasse results in the 
complete loss of stations operated by Nexstar and its partner companies (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mission_Broadcasting" title="Mission Broadcasting">Mission Broadcasting</a>
 and White Knight Broadcasting) from the DirecTV satellite service, 
DirecTV Stream and U-verse, amid an existing contractual and legal 
dispute between DirecTV and Nexstar dating to October 2022, concerning 
alleged collective bargaining influence by the three station groups in 
retransmission fee negotiations that prompted the earlier removal of 
Mission and White Knight's respective stations from the company's 
television services (see March 14 entry). In a July 18 FCC letter, 
DirecTV accused CW majority owner Nexstar of forcing Sinclair Broadcast 
Group to remove 21 affiliates (all based in markets where both groups 
operate stations, and leaving subscribers of the vMVPD service in those 
areas unable to view CW programs) from DirecTV Stream on July 12; 
Nexstar countered that DirecTV Stream continued to carry Sinclair's CW 
stations without renewing a prior agreement that expired in November 
2022. A gradual restoration of the Nexstar stations to DirecTV would 
begin on September 17, with the companies announcing a new multi-year 
carriage deal the next day.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>345<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>346<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>347<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>348<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">10
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charter_Communications" title="Charter Communications">Charter Communications</a> announces it will begin offering a reduced-cost tier of its <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectrum_(brand)" title="Spectrum (brand)">Spectrum</a>
 TV Select cable package that will exclude regional and many national 
sports networks featured in its standard basic tier (including its own <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectrum_Sports" title="Spectrum Sports">Spectrum Sports</a>
 channels in areas where Charter also operates an RSN). The Spectrum 
Select Signature tier—which will gradually launch across most of its 
footprint beginning in late Summer, alongside the renamed Spectrum 
Select Plus expanded tier—will be marketed primarily to non-sports fans,
 and is intended to limit cord-cutting among existing subscribers. The 
company also plans to launch a subscription streaming service for its 
Spectrum Sports channels, which will be available at no extra charge to 
Select Plus subscribers. Concurrently, Charter announces a new carriage 
agreement with DirecTV for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectrum_SportsNet" title="Spectrum SportsNet">Spectrum SportsNet</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SportsNet_LA" class="mw-redirect" title="SportsNet LA">SportsNet LA</a>,
 which lowers the required coverage rates for the two Los Angeles-based 
networks under terms similar to recent deals that saw the company reduce
 coverage mandates for owned or third-party regional sports networks 
carried on its systems (RSNs usually require carriage by at least 80% of
 a provider's regional subscribers); Charter intends to impose similar 
provisions for its Spectrum Sports RSNs in future negotiations with 
other providers, enabling them to reduce programming costs subsidized by
 their customers.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>349<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>350<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>351<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 21<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saima_Mohsin" title="Saima Mohsin">Saima Mohsin</a>, who served as an international correspondent for the network from 2013 to 2017, sues CNN for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racial_discrimination" title="Racial discrimination">racial discrimination</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wrongful_termination" class="mw-redirect" title="Wrongful termination">wrongful termination</a>. The journalist (who became a freelance presenter for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sky_News" title="Sky News">Sky News</a>
 in 2022) suffered severe tissue damage after a cameraman accompanying 
her on assignment accidentally drove over her foot while covering the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israel-Palestine_conflict" class="mw-redirect" title="Israel-Palestine conflict">Israel-Palestine conflict</a> in 2014. Moshin—who is <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Pakistani" class="mw-redirect" title="British Pakistani">British Pakistani</a>—
alleges that the network refused to provide adequate accommodations for 
her injury, which left her unable to do more physically demanding 
reporting work, and denied her request to move to an anchor role 
(alleging an executive said she didn't "have the look we are looking 
for") and other on-air opportunities in favor of white American 
correspondents.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>352<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>13
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlantic_Coast_Conference" title="Atlantic Coast Conference">Atlantic Coast Conference</a>
 announces a four-year deal with The CW, under which the network will 
broadcast a total of 50 ACC college football and basketball games 
(initially consisting of 13 football, 28 men's basketball and nine 
women's basketball games) each season through the 2026–27 academic year.
 <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raycom_Sports" title="Raycom Sports">Raycom Sports</a>—which sublicenses the ACC television rights from ESPN, and terminated a preceding <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ACC_on_Regional_Sports_Networks" title="ACC on Regional Sports Networks">national broadcast deal</a> with Bally Sports on June 15—will produce the telecasts. Starting with a September 9 non-conference football game between the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Panthers" title="Pittsburgh Panthers">Pittsburgh Panthers</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_12" class="mw-redirect" title="Big 12">Big 12</a> member <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Bearcats" title="Cincinnati Bearcats">Cincinnati Bearcats</a>,
 The CW will air two ACC football games each Saturday during the Fall 
(in the afternoon and prime time), and Saturday afternoon men's 
basketball doubleheaders and Sunday afternoon women's basketball games 
from December to February.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>353<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>354<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>355<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 22<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">15
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAG-AFTRA" title="SAG-AFTRA">SAG-AFTRA</a> commenced a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_SAG-AFTRA_strike" title="2023 SAG-AFTRA strike">strike</a>
 against television and film studios, after the union and the Alliance 
of Motion Picture and Television Producers failed to agree on a new 
contract after their previous agreement expired on June 30. This marks 
the first time that actors have initiated a labor dispute since the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1980_actors_strike" title="1980 actors strike">1980 actors strike</a>.
 With the concurrent Writers Guild of America strike, this was also the 
first time that actors and writers have walked out simultaneously since 
1960. Similar to the WGA, SAG-AFTRA cited several issues, including 
economic fairness, residuals, regulating the use of artificial 
intelligence, and alleviating the burdens of the industry-wide shift to 
self-taping. In addition to impacting film and television productions, 
actors could not take part in promotional work, such as <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Press_junket" class="mw-redirect" title="Press junket">press junkets</a>, film premieres, and other events such as <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Diego_Comic-Con" title="San Diego Comic-Con">San Diego Comic-Con</a>.
 Journalists and performers employed under the SAG-AFTRA National Code 
of Fair Practice for Network Television Broadcasting contract (a 
separate agreement negotiated between the union, major broadcast 
networks and other producers which currently runs through July 2024) 
were not affected, allowing news programs, most talk, variety, game and 
reality shows, soap operas, sports and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Promo_(media)" title="Promo (media)">promos</a>
 to continue production with SAG-AFTRA members covered by that 
agreement. The strike ended on November 9 after a new agreement with the
 AMPTP was reached.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>356<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>357<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>358<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>359<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>360<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Supreme_Court" title="New York Supreme Court">New York Supreme Court</a> rules in favor of DirecTV in a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breach_of_contract" title="Breach of contract">breach of contract</a> lawsuit filed by the company in November 2021 against Nexstar Media Group, involving a 2015 carriage renewal agreement for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WDVM-TV" title="WDVM-TV">WDVM</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hagerstown,_Maryland" title="Hagerstown, Maryland">Hagerstown, Maryland</a> (then-NBC affiliate WHAG). The suit alleged that Nexstar did not give DirecTV adequate notice that the station would become an <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_station_(North_America)" class="mw-redirect" title="Independent station (North America)">independent</a>
 once its affiliation contract with NBC expired in July 2016, resulting 
in the satellite provider  overpaying to carry a station that would no 
longer be a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Three_television_networks" class="mw-redirect" title="Big Three television networks">Big Four</a>
 affiliate. (As part of an effort at the time to reduce affiliate 
duplication in certain markets, NBC parent Comcast elected to 
disaffiliate from WHAG—a decision that was disclosed publicly by Nexstar
 in February 2016—due to perceived competition with nearby O&amp;O <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WRC-TV" title="WRC-TV">WRC</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>)
 The court ruled that Nexstar overcharged DirecTV by basing its carriage
 fee rate for WDVM on its prior NBC affiliation, and ordered the 
broadcaster to repay "several million dollars" worth of excess fees that
 DirecTV paid during the contract term (plus interest).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>361<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>362<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>363<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 23<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>17
</th>
<td>Four days after its release, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CMT_(American_TV_channel)" title="CMT (American TV channel)">CMT</a> removes the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_video" title="Music video">music video</a> for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jason_Aldean" title="Jason Aldean">Jason Aldean</a>'s single "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Try_That_in_a_Small_Town" title="Try That in a Small Town">Try That in a Small Town</a>" from its <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotation_(music)" title="Rotation (music)">rotation</a>,
 amid controversy over the song's lyrics and the video's themes. The 
scrutiny pertained to the lyrics being interpreted by some listeners as 
evocative of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vigilantism" title="Vigilantism">vigilantism</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lynching" title="Lynching">lynchings</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sundown_town" title="Sundown town">sundown towns</a> (the former interpretation also drawing criticism as Aldean performed at the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Route_91_Harvest" title="Route 91 Harvest">Route 91 Harvest</a> music festival during the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Las_Vegas_shooting" title="2017 Las Vegas shooting">October 2017 Las Vegas mass shooting</a>); the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maury_County" class="mw-redirect" title="Maury County">Maury County</a> Courthouse in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Columbia,_Tennessee" title="Columbia, Tennessee">Columbia, Tennessee</a>, where the video was filmed, being the site of several incidents of racial violence (including a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lynching_of_Henry_Choate" title="Lynching of Henry Choate">1927 lynching</a> and the city's 1946 race riots); and the juxtaposition of the lyrics and excerpts of news footage from the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Floyd_protests" title="George Floyd protests">2020 race riots</a>
 (including lootings and violent clashes between protesters and 
officers) interspersed in the video. Aldean responded to the criticism 
on Twitter, asserting the song was meant to represent "the feeling of a 
community that I had growing up, where we took care of our neighbors, 
regardless of differences of background or belief."
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>364<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>365<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>366<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>367<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>368<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 24<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">18
</th>
<td>Diamond Sports Group files separate lawsuits against majority owner Sinclair Broadcast Group and senior creditor <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JP_Morgan" class="mw-redirect" title="JP Morgan">JP Morgan</a>
 that seek to receive compensation for Sinclair's preferred equity 
repayment to the investment firm. Sinclair completed its $1.025-billion 
worth of equity repayments to JP Morgan in February for its preferred 
interest in Diamond that it acquired as part of the group's 2019 
purchase of the former <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Sports_Regional_Networks" class="mw-redirect" title="Fox Sports Regional Networks">Fox Sports Regional Networks</a> from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disney" class="mw-redirect" title="Disney">Disney</a>.
 Diamond accuses Sinclair of manipulating the payment schedule so that 
JPMorgan was nearly made completely whole on its investment, even though
 it knew the former's bankruptcy would wipe out its equity in the 
subsidiary,
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>370<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>After Diamond Sports Group receives bankruptcy court approval of its
 motion (filed on June 22, with the intent of terminating the contract 
effective June 30) to surrender its contract with the team, the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arizona_Diamondbacks" title="Arizona Diamondbacks">Arizona Diamondbacks</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> assume the regional television rights to the former's games from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bally_Sports_Arizona" title="Bally Sports Arizona">Bally Sports Arizona</a>, starting with that night's game against the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlanta_Braves" title="Atlanta Braves">Atlanta Braves</a>. The telecasts will be carried on alternate channels on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cox_Communications" title="Cox Communications">Cox</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectrum_(brand)" title="Spectrum (brand)">Spectrum</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xfinity" title="Xfinity">Xfinity</a>, DirecTV, DirecTV Stream, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fubo" class="mw-redirect" title="Fubo">Fubo</a> and other providers within the team's regional territory, along with a blackout-free livestream on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MLB.tv" class="mw-redirect" title="MLB.tv">MLB.tv</a>
 (with all games scheduled through July 23 available free to stream 
using MLB login credentials on the respective websites and apps of the 
MLB and the Diamondbacks). Due to the earlier departures of the NBA's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoenix_Suns" title="Phoenix Suns">Suns</a> and WNBA's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoenix_Mercury" title="Phoenix Mercury">Mercury</a> from the network (see April 28 entry), the loss of the Diamondbacks from the network leaves the NHL's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arizona_Coyotes" title="Arizona Coyotes">Arizona Coyotes</a>
 as the only major Phoenix-area sports franchise that maintains a 
broadcasting relationship with Bally Sports Arizona. Game announcers <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Berthiaume" title="Steve Berthiaume">Steve Berthiaume</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Brenly" title="Bob Brenly">Bob Brenly</a> will remain on the broadcasts as they are directly employed by the Diamondbacks.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>371<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>372<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>373<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>374<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 25<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>23
</th>
<td>Preceding that day's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN%2B" title="ESPN+">ESPN+</a> broadcast of a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friendly_match" class="mw-redirect" title="Friendly match">friendly match</a> between <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AC_Milan" title="AC Milan">AC Milan</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_Madrid_CF" title="Real Madrid CF">Real Madrid CF</a> at the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rose_Bowl_(stadium)" title="Rose Bowl (stadium)">Rose Bowl</a> in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pasadena,_California" title="Pasadena, California">Pasadena, California</a>, ESPN <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soccer" class="mw-redirect" title="Soccer">soccer</a> analyst <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaka_Hislop" title="Shaka Hislop">Shaka Hislop</a>
 fainted on-air while co-hosting the pre-match show with play-by-play 
analyst Dan Thomas. The retired professional soccer star later regained 
consciousness and was treated by stadium medical personnel, later 
describing the incident as "awkward" and was seeking medical opinion on 
the cause of his collapse.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>375<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>376<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>377<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>28
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NASCAR" title="NASCAR">NASCAR</a> announces a seven-year deal with The CW to broadcast <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xfinity_Series" class="mw-redirect" title="Xfinity Series">Xfinity Series</a> races exclusively on the network starting in 2025. The deal—which replaces <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NASCAR_on_NBC" title="NASCAR on NBC">NBC, USA Network</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NASCAR_on_Fox" title="NASCAR on Fox">Fox Sports</a>
 as the second-tier circuit's broadcast partners—will see The CW air 33 
live races each year as well as weekend practice and qualifying events, 
with additional content being made available on The CW's streaming apps 
and digital platforms; NASCAR Productions, the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stock_car" class="mw-redirect" title="Stock car">stock car</a>
 racing league's in-house production unit, will handle production 
responsibilities for the race telecasts and other ancillary content. The
 deal will mark the first time that all Xfinity Series races will be 
available exclusively on American broadcast television.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>378<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>379<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>380<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 26<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="August">August</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: August"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th>Date
</th>
<th>Event
</th>
<th>Source
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th>2
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Goldberg" title="Jeffrey Goldberg">Jeffrey Goldberg</a> is named moderator of <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Week" title="Washington Week">Washington Week</a></i> effective August 11, coinciding with <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Atlantic" title="The Atlantic">The Atlantic</a></i> (where Goldberg has served as editor-in-chief since 2016) joining <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> PBS member station <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WETA-TV" title="WETA-TV">WETA</a> and NewsHour Productions, LLC as an editorial partner of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PBS" title="PBS">PBS</a> political affairs program, which will accordingly be retitled <i>Washington Week with The Atlantic</i>. Goldberg succeeds <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yamiche_Alcindor" title="Yamiche Alcindor">Yamiche Alcindor</a>, who stepped down from the role on February 24, primarily to focus on her job as Washington correspondent for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC_News" title="NBC News">NBC News</a> (various journalists have served as guest moderators since Alcindor's departure).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>381<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>382<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>4
</th>
<td><i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Days_of_Our_Lives" title="Days of Our Lives">Days of Our Lives</a></i> producer <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corday_Productions" title="Corday Productions">Corday Productions</a> announces the departure of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peacock_(streaming_service)" title="Peacock (streaming service)">Peacock</a> soap opera's longtime co-executive producer/director <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_Alarr" title="Albert Alarr">Albert Alarr</a>,
 with senior producer Janet Spellman-Drucker replacing him as co-EP and 
the company announcing it will be "implementing additional <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_resources" title="Human resources">HR</a> protocols." Alarr's departure comes in the aftermath of an investigation conducted by <i>Days</i> distributor <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony_Pictures_Television" title="Sony Pictures Television">Sony Pictures Television</a> (outlined in a July 25 <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deadline_Hollywood" title="Deadline Hollywood">Deadline Hollywood</a></i>
 report) that revealed Alarr had allegedly fostered a toxic work 
environment on the program, and had been verbally and physically abusive
 toward staffers (namely female staffers, who allege incidents of 
inappropriate comments and physical contact by Alarr). Though Corday 
Productions reportedly gave a written warning to Alarr (who denied the 
allegations against him) and ordered him to undergo training, his 
continued presence on <i>Days</i> led to on-set tensions among those aware of the investigation, with cast members petitioning for Alarr's ouster.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>383<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>384<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>385<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">9
</th>
<td><i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Brother_(American_TV_series)" title="Big Brother (American TV series)">Big Brother</a></i> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Brother_25_(American_season)" title="Big Brother 25 (American season)">season 25</a> contestant Luke Valentine is removed from the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramount%2B" title="Paramount+">Paramount+</a> reality show one day after uttering the N-word in a conversation, a violation of the show's code of conduct.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>386<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC_News" title="NBC News">NBC News</a></i> announces that <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laura_Jarrett" title="Laura Jarrett">Laura Jarrett</a> will join <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Alexander_(journalist)" title="Peter Alexander (journalist)">Peter Alexander</a> as the new co-anchor of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Today_(American_TV_program)" title="Today (American TV program)">Saturday Today</a>, and the show will move back to Studio 1A at <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rockefeller_Plaza" class="mw-redirect" title="Rockefeller Plaza">Rockefeller Plaza</a> in New York. Jarrett is succeeding <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kristen_Welker" title="Kristen Welker">Kristen Welker</a>, who is moving to succeed <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chuck_Todd" title="Chuck Todd">Chuck Todd</a> as the new moderator of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meet_The_Press" class="mw-redirect" title="Meet The Press">Meet The Press</a> (see June 4 entry). Jarrett's first Saturday Today broadcast alongside Alexander aired on September 9.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>387<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>388<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>10
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academy_of_Television_Arts_%26_Sciences" title="Academy of Television Arts &amp; Sciences">Academy of Television Arts &amp; Sciences</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox</a> formally announce that the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/75th_Primetime_Emmy_Awards" title="75th Primetime Emmy Awards">75th Primetime Emmy Awards</a>
 will be pushed back from its original planned date of September 18 
until January 15, 2024. The rescheduling, due to the ongoing <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Writers_Guild_of_America_strike" title="2023 Writers Guild of America strike">Writers Guild</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_SAG-AFTRA_strike" title="2023 SAG-AFTRA strike">SAG-AFTRA</a> strikes, mark the first postponement of a Primetime Emmy ceremony since 2001, when the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11 attacks</a> and ensuing start of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%932021)" title="War in Afghanistan (2001–2021)">war in Afghanistan</a> pushed the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/53rd_Primetime_Emmy_Awards" title="53rd Primetime Emmy Awards">53rd Primetime Emmys</a> from September to November. (The related <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/75th_Primetime_Creative_Arts_Emmy_Awards" title="75th Primetime Creative Arts Emmy Awards">Creative Arts Emmys</a> will also move from September to the weekend of January 6–7, 2024.)
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>389<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">15
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sage_Steele" title="Sage Steele">Sage Steele</a> announces that she has left <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">ESPN</a> after settling her lawsuit against the network and its parent, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company" title="The Walt Disney Company">The Walt Disney Company</a>. Steele, who had been with ESPN since 2007 and had anchored <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SportsCenter" title="SportsCenter">SportsCenter</a></i> and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_Countdown" title="NBA Countdown">NBA Countdown</a></i>, had sued ESPN and Disney in 2022, alleging the network had "sidelined" her after she criticized the network's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19" title="COVID-19">COVID-19</a> vaccination policy and questioned the ethnicity of former U.S. President <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>390<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nielsen_Media_Research" title="Nielsen Media Research">Nielsen Media Research</a>
 reports that for the first time since it started its monthly gauge in 
2021, the combined share of broadcast and cable network viewing during 
July was less than half of all total TV usage (49.6%).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>391<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>20
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spain_women%27s_national_football_team" title="Spain women's national football team">Spain</a> defeats <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/England_women%27s_national_football_team" title="England women's national football team">England</a>, 1–0, in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup_final" title="2023 FIFA Women's World Cup final">the final</a> of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup" title="2023 FIFA Women's World Cup">2023 FIFA Women's World Cup</a>. The tournament, which began on July 20, was televised by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Sports_(United_States)" title="Fox Sports (United States)">Fox Sports</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telemundo" title="Telemundo">Telemundo</a> respectively in English (on Fox and FS1) and Spanish (on Telemundo and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universo_(TV_network)" class="mw-redirect" title="Universo (TV network)">Universo</a>),
 with all games streamed on the Fox Sports app and Peacock. The networks
 and streaming platforms carried a primarily late night and early 
morning schedule of games—with only five matches being held during prime
 time—due to the tournament being played across nine cities in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand" title="New Zealand">New Zealand</a> (12–16 hours ahead of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_Time_Zone" title="Eastern Time Zone">Eastern Daylight Time</a>, depending on each game's corresponding host venue).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-usarights_418-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-usarights-418"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>392<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-foxrights_419-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-foxrights-419"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>393<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>394<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>395<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>23
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_News" title="Fox News">Fox News</a> hosts the first of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Republican_Party_presidential_debates" class="mw-redirect" title="2024 Republican Party presidential debates">2024 Republican Party presidential debates</a> at <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiserv_Forum" title="Fiserv Forum">Fiserv Forum</a> in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milwaukee" title="Milwaukee">Milwaukee</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wisconsin" title="Wisconsin">Wisconsin</a>, which will also host the GOP's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Republican_National_Convention" title="2024 Republican National Convention">nominating convention</a>. Eight candidates appear on the stage—<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doug_Burgum" title="Doug Burgum">Doug Burgum</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Christie" title="Chris Christie">Chris Christie</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ron_DeSantis" title="Ron DeSantis">Ron DeSantis</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikki_Haley" title="Nikki Haley">Nikki Haley</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asa_Hutchinson" title="Asa Hutchinson">Asa Hutchinson</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Pence" title="Mike Pence">Mike Pence</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vivek_Ramaswamy" title="Vivek Ramaswamy">Vivek Ramaswamy</a>, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Scott" title="Tim Scott">Tim Scott</a>—the lowest number of candidates for the first <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_presidential_debates" title="Republican Party presidential debates">Republican debate</a> stage since <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Republican_Party_presidential_debates_and_forums" title="2012 Republican Party presidential debates and forums">2012</a>. The relatively low number was due to strict <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Committee" title="Republican National Committee">RNC</a>
 requirements that any participants have at least 40,000 individual 
donors and poll above 1% in either three national polls or two national 
polls and one state poll. (By comparison, high candidate numbers caused 
both the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Republican_Party_presidential_debates_and_forums" title="2016 Republican Party presidential debates and forums">2016 GOP</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Democratic_Party_presidential_debates" title="2020 Democratic Party presidential debates">2020 Democratic</a> debates to be spread out over two nights.) Thanks to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2024_Republican_Party_presidential_primaries" class="mw-redirect" title="Opinion polling for the 2024 Republican Party presidential primaries">not meeting polling requirements</a> or refusing to sign a loyalty pledge to back the eventual nominee, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryan_Binkley" title="Ryan Binkley">Ryan Binkley</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larry_Elder" title="Larry Elder">Larry Elder</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Will_Hurd" title="Will Hurd">Will Hurd</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perry_Johnson_(businessman)" title="Perry Johnson (businessman)">Perry Johnson</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francis_Suarez" title="Francis Suarez">Francis Suarez</a>, and former president <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> did not attend; Trump, the polling frontrunner, instead appears in a pre-taped interview with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tucker_Carlson" title="Tucker Carlson">Tucker Carlson</a> that aired as <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Counterprogramming_(television)" title="Counterprogramming (television)">counterprogramming</a> to the debate on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">X</a> (formerly Twitter).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>396<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>397<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>398<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>399<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>30
</th>
<td>Two months after the ouster of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Licht" title="Chris Licht">Chris Licht</a> (see June 7 entry), <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warner_Bros._Discovery" title="Warner Bros. Discovery">Warner Bros. Discovery</a> announces the hire of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Thompson_(media_executive)" title="Mark Thompson (media executive)">Mark Thompson</a> as <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a>'s new chief executive officer; Thompson is previously known for his tenures as director general of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a> and CEO of <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>400<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>31
</th>
<td>The cable networks and TV stations owned by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company" title="The Walt Disney Company">The Walt Disney Company</a> (including <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disney_Channel" title="Disney Channel">Disney Channel</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freeform_(TV_channel)" title="Freeform (TV channel)">Freeform</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Geographic_(American_TV_channel)" title="National Geographic (American TV channel)">National Geographic</a>, the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FX_Networks" title="FX Networks">FX</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">ESPN</a> networks, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a> O&amp;O stations), are dropped from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charter_Communications" title="Charter Communications">Charter Communications</a>' <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectrum_(brand)" title="Spectrum (brand)">Spectrum</a>
 cable systems due to an unresolved carriage dispute. The two companies 
would announce a new agreement on September 11, one that allows 
customers who subscribe to certain Spectrum packages access to the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disney%2B" title="Disney+">Disney+</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN%2B" title="ESPN+">ESPN+</a>
 streaming services (and, when it launches, ESPN's direct-to-consumer 
service), but also allows Charter to drop carriage of Freeform, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FXX" title="FXX">FXX</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FX_Movie_Channel" title="FX Movie Channel">FXM</a>, and smaller Disney- and Nat Geo-branded channels.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>401<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>402<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="September">September</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: September"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th>Date
</th>
<th>Event
</th>
<th>Source
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th>2
</th>
<td>Producers of <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Love_%26_Hip_Hop:_Atlanta" title="Love &amp; Hip Hop: Atlanta">Love &amp; Hip Hop: Atlanta</a></i> announce that cast member <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erica_Mena" title="Erica Mena">Erica Mena</a> will not return to the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VH1" title="VH1">VH1</a>
 reality show for its next season, its 12th, after a Season 11 episode 
(which originally aired on August 29) captured Mena directing a slur at 
castmate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spice_(musician)" title="Spice (musician)">Spice</a> during an argument (and table-flipping incident) between the two women.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>403<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>5
</th>
<td>Citing a desire to focus on his "health, family, and faith," <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Mortensen" title="Chris Mortensen">Chris Mortensen</a> announces on social media he retired from his <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL" class="mw-redirect" title="NFL">NFL</a> reporting role at <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">ESPN</a> after the network's coverage of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_NFL_draft" title="2023 NFL draft">the league's player draft</a>
 in April. Mortensen had been a mainstay of ESPN's pro football coverage
 since joining the network in 1991, and appeared in his "insider" role 
on draft broadcasts, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunday_NFL_Countdown" title="Sunday NFL Countdown">Sunday NFL Countdown</a></i>, and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SportsCenter" title="SportsCenter">SportsCenter</a></i>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>404<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">8
</th>
<td>Stations owned and operated by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hearst_Television" title="Hearst Television">Hearst Television</a> (37 stations covering 27 markets) are dropped from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dish_Network" title="Dish Network">Dish Network</a> due to an impasse in retransmission negotiations between the two sides.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>405<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_News" title="Fox News">Fox News</a>
 fires senior executive John Finley following an investigation into a 
violation of the company's conduct standards. Finley's 20-year tenure at
 Fox included serving as executive producer of <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hannity" title="Hannity">Hannity</a></i> and helping to develop other Fox News signature shows (including <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outnumbered_(American_TV_program)" title="Outnumbered (American TV program)">Outnumbered</a></i> and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Five_(talk_show)" title="The Five (talk show)">The Five</a></i>) as well as the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Nation" title="Fox Nation">Fox Nation</a> streaming service.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>406<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>12
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_MTV_Video_Music_Awards" title="2023 MTV Video Music Awards">2023 MTV Video Music Awards</a> airs on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MTV" title="MTV">MTV</a> and its related digital and linear platforms from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newark,_New_Jersey" title="Newark, New Jersey">Newark's</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prudential_Center" title="Prudential Center">Prudential Center</a>. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicki_Minaj" title="Nicki Minaj">Nicki Minaj</a> serves as host, with notable winners including <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shakira" title="Shakira">Shakira</a> (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Jackson_Video_Vanguard_Award" title="Michael Jackson Video Vanguard Award">Michael Jackson Video Vanguard Award</a>), <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_Combs" title="Sean Combs">Diddy</a> (Global Icon Award), Minaj herself (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Best_Hip-Hop_Video" class="mw-redirect" title="Best Hip-Hop Video">Best Hip-Hop Video</a> for "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Freaky_Girl" title="Super Freaky Girl">Super Freaky Girl</a>"), and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taylor_Swift" title="Taylor Swift">Taylor Swift</a> (a night-leading 9 awards, including her 2nd consecutive <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MTV_Video_Music_Award_for_Video_of_the_Year" title="MTV Video Music Award for Video of the Year">Video of the Year</a>, and record-extending 4th overall, for "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-Hero_(song)" title="Anti-Hero (song)">Anti-Hero</a>").
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>407<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>14
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morgan_Murphy_Media" title="Morgan Murphy Media">Morgan Murphy Media</a> announces it will acquire three TV stations in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michigan" title="Michigan">Michigan</a> from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Marks_Group" title="The Marks Group">The Marks Group</a>: <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WBKP" title="WBKP">WBKP</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calumet,_Michigan" title="Calumet, Michigan">Calumet</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WBUP" title="WBUP">WBUP</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ishpeming" class="mw-redirect" title="Ishpeming">Ishpeming</a> (affiliated with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_CW" title="The CW">The CW</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a> respectively and simulcasting each network on both stations across the market over subchannels), and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WBKB-TV" title="WBKB-TV">WBKB-TV</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alpena,_Michigan" title="Alpena, Michigan">Alpena</a> (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">NBC</a>/ABC/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox</a>). The $12 million deal, which also includes radio properties in the western <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_Peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Upper Peninsula">Upper Peninsula</a>, is expected to close at the end of the year pending regulatory approval.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>408<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>18
</th>
<td>Amid the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Hollywood_labor_disputes" title="2023 Hollywood labor disputes">2023 Hollywood labor disputes</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL_on_ABC" title="NFL on ABC">ABC</a> announces that it will simulcast <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">ESPN's</a> <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monday_Night_Football" title="Monday Night Football">Monday Night Football</a></i> during each week of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_NFL_season" title="2023 NFL season">2023 NFL season</a>. This marks the first time a full season of <i>Monday Night Football</i> has aired on ABC since <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_NFL_season" title="2005 NFL season">2005</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>409<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">21
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WWE" title="WWE">WWE</a> announces that its Friday night showcase <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SmackDown" class="mw-redirect" title="SmackDown">SmackDown</a></i> will leave <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox</a> for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USA_Network" title="USA Network">USA Network</a> in October 2024 as part of a new deal with USA owner <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBCUniversal" title="NBCUniversal">NBCUniversal</a> that also includes a series of WWE prime time specials airing on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">NBC</a> beginning in the 2024–2025 TV season. <i>SmackDown</i> previously aired between 2016 and 2019 on USA, which currently also carries <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monday_Night_Raw" class="mw-redirect" title="Monday Night Raw">Monday Night Raw</a></i> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NXT_(WWE_brand)" title="NXT (WWE brand)">NXT</a> telecasts under separate deals that end in September 2024.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>410<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rupert_Murdoch" title="Rupert Murdoch">Rupert Murdoch</a> announces he will step down as chairman of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Corporation" title="Fox Corporation">Fox Corporation</a> and sister company <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/News_Corp" title="News Corp">News Corp</a> in November. Murdoch's son, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lachlan_Murdoch" title="Lachlan Murdoch">Lachlan Murdoch</a>, will become sole chairman of both companies at that time, while the elder Murdoch, who founded the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox</a> television network in 1986 and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_News" title="Fox News">Fox News</a> in 1996, will retain a "chairman emeritus" role.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>411<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>26
</th>
