<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_McManus_(television_executive)" title="Sean McManus (television executive)">Sean McManus</a> announces he will retire from the chairman role at <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_Sports" title="CBS Sports">CBS Sports</a>
 in April 2024, with David Berson replacing him. McManus, who has been 
with CBS since 1996 and has been its sports division's chairman since 
2011, is noted for securing several sports rights deals for the network 
(most notably the 1998 return of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL" class="mw-redirect" title="NFL">NFL</a> after a four-year hiatus); he also concurrently served as president of both CBS Sports and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_News" title="CBS News">CBS News</a> from 2005 to 2011.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>412<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>27
</th>
<td>The second <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Republican_Party_presidential_debates_and_forums" title="2024 Republican Party presidential debates and forums">2024 Republican Party presidential debate</a> takes place at the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Reagan_Presidential_Library" title="Ronald Reagan Presidential Library">Ronald Reagan Presidential Library</a> in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simi_Valley,_California" title="Simi Valley, California">Simi Valley, California</a>. The event is conducted by and aired on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_News" title="Fox News">Fox News</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Univision" title="Univision">Univision</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>413<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>414<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>28
</th>
<td>The inaugural edition of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/People%27s_Choice_Country_Awards" class="mw-redirect" title="People's Choice Country Awards">People's Choice Country Awards</a>, the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Country_music" title="Country music">country music</a>-focused offshoot of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/People%27s_Choice_Awards" title="People's Choice Awards">People's Choice Awards</a>, airs on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">NBC</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peacock_(streaming_service)" title="Peacock (streaming service)">Peacock</a> from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nashville,_Tennessee" title="Nashville, Tennessee">Nashville's</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Ole_Opry" title="Grand Ole Opry">Grand Ole Opry House</a>. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Little_Big_Town" title="Little Big Town">Little Big Town</a> serves as hosts of a ceremony that includes notable winners <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morgan_Wallen" title="Morgan Wallen">Morgan Wallen</a> (The People's Artist), <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jelly_Roll_(singer)" title="Jelly Roll (singer)">Jelly Roll</a> (four awards, including Male Artist and New Artist) and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lainey_Wilson" title="Lainey Wilson">Lainey Wilson</a> (three awards, including Female Artist).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-441" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-441"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>415<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="October">October</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: October"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th>Date
</th>
<th>Event
</th>
<th>Source
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">5
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roy_Wood_Jr." title="Roy Wood Jr.">Roy Wood Jr.</a> announces he will not return to <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Daily_Show" title="The Daily Show">The Daily Show</a></i> when it returns from the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Writers_Guild_of_America_strike" title="2023 Writers Guild of America strike">WGA strike</a> on October 16. Wood had been a correspondent on the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comedy_Central" title="Comedy Central">Comedy Central</a> program since 2015 and had been regarded as a candidate for the permanent host role following <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trevor_Noah" title="Trevor Noah">Trevor Noah</a>'s departure (Wood, in an interview with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NPR" title="NPR">NPR</a>, indicated he would still consider such a role if the network extended it to him).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>416<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NHL%27s" class="mw-redirect" title="NHL's">NHL's</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arizona_Coyotes" title="Arizona Coyotes">Arizona Coyotes</a> announce they have agreed to end their relationship with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bally_Sports_Arizona" title="Bally Sports Arizona">Bally Sports Arizona</a>, and that the team has reached a multi-year deal with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scripps_Sports" title="Scripps Sports">Scripps Sports</a> to carry Coyote games on Scripps-owned <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KNXV-TV" title="KNXV-TV">KNXV-DT2</a> in Phoenix as well as <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KGUN-TV" title="KGUN-TV">KGUN-DT2</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tucson" class="mw-redirect" title="Tucson">Tucson</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KUPX-TV" title="KUPX-TV">KUPX-TV</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KSTU" title="KSTU">KSTU-DT2</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salt_Lake_City" title="Salt Lake City">Salt Lake City</a>.
 The Coyotes were the last remaining Arizona pro sports team with a 
contract with Bally Sports Arizona, after the network ceded <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arizona_Diamondbacks" title="Arizona Diamondbacks">Arizona Diamondbacks</a> rights back to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> (see July 18, 2023, entry) and the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">NBA's</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoenix_Suns" title="Phoenix Suns">Phoenix Suns</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women%27s_National_Basketball_Association" title="Women's National Basketball Association">WNBA's</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoenix_Mercury" title="Phoenix Mercury">Mercury</a> signed new deals with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gray_Television" class="mw-redirect" title="Gray Television">Gray Television</a> (see April 28, 2023, entry).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>417<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>10
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barry_Melrose" title="Barry Melrose">Barry Melrose</a> announces he is stepping down from his hockey analyst role at <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">ESPN</a> due to his being diagnosed with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parkinson%27s_disease" title="Parkinson's disease">Parkinson's disease</a>. A former player and coach (most notably coach of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles_Kings" title="Los Angeles Kings">Los Angeles Kings</a>), Melrose had been a popular part of ESPN's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NHL" class="mw-redirect" title="NHL">NHL</a> and collegiate hockey coverage since 1994.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>418<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>13
</th>
<td>In the wake of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israel-Hamas_war" class="mw-redirect" title="Israel-Hamas war">Israel-Hamas war</a> that began on October 7, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MSNBC" title="MSNBC">MSNBC</a> temporarily removes Muslim hosts <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ayman_Mohyeldin" title="Ayman Mohyeldin">Ayman Mohyeldin</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mehdi_Hasan" title="Mehdi Hasan">Mehdi Hasan</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ali_Velshi" title="Ali Velshi">Ali Velshi</a>
 from anchoring duties, with their shows temporarily being replaced by 
ongoing coverage of the war during the weekend. Their shows returned to 
air the following weekend.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-445" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-445"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>419<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>17
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramount_Global" title="Paramount Global">Paramount Global</a> announces that it will shutter <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Showtime_(TV_network)" title="Showtime (TV network)">Showtime's</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Showtime_(TV_network)#Sports_programming" title="Showtime (TV network)">sports division</a>
 at the end of the year, with all sports content within the company, and
 any content that may air on Showtime, expected to be produced by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_Sports" title="CBS Sports">CBS Sports</a> beginning in 2024. Showtime Sports launched in 1986 and has been known for its coverage of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">boxing</a> (primarily under the <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Showtime_Championship_Boxing" title="Showtime Championship Boxing">Showtime Championship Boxing</a></i> and <i>ShoBox: The New Generation</i> banners) and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mixed_martial_arts" title="Mixed martial arts">mixed martial arts</a> (namely the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellator_MMA" title="Bellator MMA">Bellator MMA</a> promotion) on both the Showtime network and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pay-per-view" title="Pay-per-view">pay-per-view</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-446" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-446"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>420<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="November">November</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: November"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th>Date
</th>
<th>Event
</th>
<th>Source
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">1
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company" title="The Walt Disney Company">The Walt Disney Company</a> announces it will acquire the remaining 33% in the streaming service <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hulu" title="Hulu">Hulu</a> that it does not already own from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBCUniversal" title="NBCUniversal">NBCUniversal</a>. The $8.61&nbsp;billion deal is expected to close in 2024.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-447" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-447"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>421<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Colbert" title="Stephen Colbert">Stephen Colbert</a> reveals that <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taylor_Tomlinson" title="Taylor Tomlinson">Taylor Tomlinson</a> will host <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/After_Midnight_(TV_series)" title="After Midnight (TV series)">After Midnight</a></i>, a new program that will follow his <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Late_Show_with_Stephen_Colbert" title="The Late Show with Stephen Colbert">Late Show</a></i> on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a>' late night schedule beginning in early 2024.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>422<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>7
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WWE" title="WWE">WWE</a> announces that its Tuesday night program <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WWE_NXT" title="WWE NXT">NXT</a></i> will move from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USA_Network" title="USA Network">USA Network</a> to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_CW" title="The CW">The CW</a>, as part of a five-year deal that starts in October 2024.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-449" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-449"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>423<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">8
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/57th_Annual_Country_Music_Association_Awards" title="57th Annual Country Music Association Awards">57th Annual Country Music Association Awards</a> airs on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a> from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nashville" class="mw-redirect" title="Nashville">Nashville</a>'s <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bridgestone_Arena" title="Bridgestone Arena">Bridgestone Arena</a>, with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luke_Bryan" title="Luke Bryan">Luke Bryan</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peyton_Manning" title="Peyton Manning">Peyton Manning</a> as hosts.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-450" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>424<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC_News" title="NBC News">NBC News</a> airs the third <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Republican_Party_presidential_debates_and_forums" title="2024 Republican Party presidential debates and forums">2024 Republican Party presidential debate</a> from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami" title="Miami">Miami</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-451" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-451"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>425<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-452" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-452"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>426<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>9
</th>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Women%27s_Soccer_League" title="National Women's Soccer League">National Women's Soccer League</a> announces four-year media deals with incumbent <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_Sports" title="CBS Sports">CBS Sports</a> as well as <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">ESPN</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Video" class="mw-redirect" title="Prime Video">Prime Video</a>, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scripps_Sports" title="Scripps Sports">Scripps Sports</a>.
 The deals, which will bring $60 million in rights fees to the league 
per year (40 times what the previous deal with CBS had brought in), will
 include matches on CBS's and ESPN's respective on-air and streaming 
platforms, Friday night games on Prime Video, and Saturday night 
doubleheaders on Scripps-owned <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ion_Television" title="Ion Television">Ion Television</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-453" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-453"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>427<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>15
</th>
<td>Giving no initial reason for doing so, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Univision" title="Univision">Univision</a> news anchor <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Le%C3%B3n_Krauze" title="León Krauze">León Krauze</a> announces his departure from the Spanish-language network. Krauze had co-anchored the network's late-night newscast, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noticiero_Univision" title="Noticiero Univision">Noticiero Univision Edición Nocturna</a></i>, since January 2022, and had spent the prior 10 years as news anchor for Univision's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/O%26O" class="mw-redirect" title="O&amp;O">O&amp;O</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KMEX-DT" title="KMEX-DT">KMEX-DT</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-454" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-454"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>428<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>23
</th>
<td>The 97th <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macy%27s_Thanksgiving_Day_Parade" title="Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade">Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade</a> broadcast attracts a record TV audience for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">NBC</a>, with 28.5 million total viewers watching the event on NBC or <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peacock_(streaming_service)" title="Peacock (streaming service)">Peacock</a> (22.3 million for the live morning broadcast alone).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-455" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-455"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>429<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>26
</th>
<td>The live broadcast of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL_RedZone" title="NFL RedZone">NFL RedZone</a> channel is interrupted by a fire alarm inside the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL_Network" title="NFL Network">NFL Network</a> studio in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inglewood,_California" title="Inglewood, California">Inglewood, California</a>; the alarm, which turns out to be a false one, forces host <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Hanson" title="Scott Hanson">Scott Hanson</a> and the channel's production crew to temporarily evacuate the studio (viewers would see coverage of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buffalo_Bills" title="Buffalo Bills">Buffalo Bills</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles" title="Philadelphia Eagles">Philadelphia Eagles</a> game in the interim).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-456" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-456"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>430<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>29
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NASCAR" title="NASCAR">NASCAR</a> announces seven-year deals for its top-tier <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cup_Series" class="mw-redirect" title="Cup Series">Cup Series</a>, beginning in 2025, with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Sports" title="Fox Sports">Fox Sports</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC_Sports" title="NBC Sports">NBC Sports</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Video" class="mw-redirect" title="Prime Video">Prime Video</a>, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TNT_(American_TV_network)" title="TNT (American TV network)">TNT Sports</a>.
 The deals will see incumbents Fox and NBC carry an equal number of 14 
races each season, but also see new partners Prime Video and TNT not 
only split a mid-season package of 10 races but also exclusively carry 
practice and qualifying sessions for every Cup Series race.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-457" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-457"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>431<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="3">30
</th>
<td>Bailey Cable TV, a TV/internet provider serving small towns in southwestern <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mississippi" title="Mississippi">Mississippi</a> and eastern <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louisiana" title="Louisiana">Louisiana</a>, closes operations and disconnects service to customers without advance warning.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-458" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-458"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>432<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>After the two sides fail to reach a retransmission agreement before a 5PM (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Time" class="mw-redirect" title="Pacific Time">Pacific Time</a>) deadline, 66 stations (in 52 markets) owned by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tegna_Inc." title="Tegna Inc.">Tegna Inc.</a> are removed from the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DirecTV" title="DirecTV">DirecTV</a> satellite service. The signals would be restored on January 13, 2024, after Tegna and DirecTV reach a new agreement.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-459" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-459"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>433<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-460" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-460"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>434<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>In what the network bills as "The Great <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_states_and_blue_states" title="Red states and blue states">Red vs. Blue State</a> Debate," <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_Hannity" title="Sean Hannity">Sean Hannity</a> moderates a debate on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_News" title="Fox News">Fox News</a> between two state governors with confirmed or rumored <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">presidential</a> aspirations, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_governors_of_Florida" title="List of governors of Florida">Florida</a> Republican <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ron_DeSantis" title="Ron DeSantis">Ron DeSantis</a> (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ron_DeSantis_2024_presidential_campaign" title="Ron DeSantis 2024 presidential campaign">who was seeking the GOP nomination for president</a> in 2024) and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governor_of_California" title="Governor of California">California</a> Democrat <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gavin_Newsom" title="Gavin Newsom">Gavin Newsom</a> (who's been regarded as possibly contending for his party's nomination in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2028_United_States_presidential_election" title="2028 United States presidential election">2028</a>).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-461" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-461"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>435<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="December">December</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: December"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Date
</th>
<th>Event
</th>
<th>Source
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th>1
</th>
<td>Six months after the company terminated a proposed sale of the stations to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forum_Communications" class="mw-redirect" title="Forum Communications">Forum Communications</a> (see June 6 entry), <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_River_Broadcasting" title="Red River Broadcasting">Red River Broadcasting</a> enters into an agreement to sell <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox</a> affiliates <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KVRR" title="KVRR">KVRR</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fargo,_North_Dakota" title="Fargo, North Dakota">Fargo</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moorhead,_Minnesota" title="Moorhead, Minnesota">Moorhead</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KQDS-TV" title="KQDS-TV">KQDS</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duluth" class="mw-redirect" title="Duluth">Duluth</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superior,_Wisconsin" title="Superior, Wisconsin">Superior</a>
 to Coastal Television Broadcasting Company; the stations are Red 
River's last remaining TV properties, and the transaction, which is 
subject to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FCC" class="mw-redirect" title="FCC">FCC</a> approval, is later priced at $18.1 million.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-462" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-462"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>436<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-463" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-463"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>437<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">6
</th>
<td>The five major commercial broadcast networks (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_CW" title="The CW">The CW</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox</a>, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">NBC</a>) begin their prime-time schedules by simulcasting an "in memoriam" tribute card to the legendary producer <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norman_Lear" title="Norman Lear">Norman Lear</a>, who died the previous day.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-464" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-464"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>438<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>The fourth <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Republican_Party_presidential_debates_and_forums" title="2024 Republican Party presidential debates and forums">2024 Republican Party presidential debate</a> is held in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tuscaloosa" class="mw-redirect" title="Tuscaloosa">Tuscaloosa</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alabama" title="Alabama">Alabama</a>, airing on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NewsNation" title="NewsNation">NewsNation</a> and simulcast on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_CW" title="The CW">The CW</a>. It's the first national news program for the latter network since its 2022 purchase by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nexstar_Media_Group" title="Nexstar Media Group">Nexstar Media Group</a>, and it becomes the last of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_over-the-air_television_networks" title="List of United States over-the-air television networks">five major English-language commercial broadcast networks in the United States</a> to offer news programming.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-465" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-465"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>439<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-466" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-466"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>440<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>7
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_Prime_Video" title="Amazon Prime Video">Amazon Prime Video</a> announces it has reached an agreement to carry <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Premier_Boxing_Champions" title="Premier Boxing Champions">Premier Boxing Champions</a>
 events beginning in 2024, both pay-per-view events available to 
purchase on streaming, cable, and satellite, as well as additional bouts
 and ancillary programming available to Prime Video subscribers only. 
The deal, which is projected to feature 12-14 events in its first year, 
replaces PBC's relationship with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Showtime_(TV_network)" title="Showtime (TV network)">Showtime</a> in the wake of that cable network's exit from sports productions (see October 17 entry).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-467" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-467"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>441<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">15
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayim_Bialik" title="Mayim Bialik">Mayim Bialik</a> announced that she was fired from <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeopardy!" title="Jeopardy!">Jeopardy!</a></i> Bialik had shared hosting duties on the syndicated game show with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ken_Jennings" title="Ken Jennings">Ken Jennings</a>, who has been the show's sole host since May (after Bialik stepped back in support of the show's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Writers_Guild_of_America_strike" title="2023 Writers Guild of America strike">striking writers</a>) and will go forward in that same capacity.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-468" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-468"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>442<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-469" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-469"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>443<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/50th_Daytime_Emmy_Awards" title="50th Daytime Emmy Awards">50th Daytime Emmy Awards</a>, the first major showbiz award event since the resolution of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Hollywood_labor_disputes" title="2023 Hollywood labor disputes">2023 Hollywood labor disputes</a> (it had been rescheduled from June 16 due to the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Writers_Guild_of_America_strike" title="2023 Writers Guild of America strike">WGA strike</a>), air on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a> from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a>' <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westin_Bonaventure_Hotel" title="Westin Bonaventure Hotel">Westin Bonaventure Hotel</a>. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Frazier" title="Kevin Frazier">Kevin Frazier</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nischelle_Turner" title="Nischelle Turner">Nischelle Turner</a> host the ceremony that sees such notable winners as <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Hospital" title="General Hospital">General Hospital</a></i> (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daytime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Drama_Series" title="Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Drama Series">Outstanding Drama Series</a>), <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Kelly_Clarkson_Show" title="The Kelly Clarkson Show">The Kelly Clarkson Show</a></i> (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daytime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Daytime_Talk_Series" title="Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Daytime Talk Series">Outstanding Talk Series</a>), and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Susan_Lucci" title="Susan Lucci">Susan Lucci</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maury_Povich" title="Maury Povich">Maury Povich</a> (Lifetime Achievement Awards).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-470" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-470"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>444<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-471" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-471"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>445<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-472" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-472"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>446<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>16
</th>
<td><i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudolph_the_Red-Nosed_Reindeer_(TV_special)" title="Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer (TV special)">Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frosty_the_Snowman_(TV_special)" title="Frosty the Snowman (TV special)">Frosty the Snowman</a></i>, and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frosty_Returns" title="Frosty Returns">Frosty Returns</a></i> all aired on CBS for the final time on December 16, 2023. <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frosty_Returns" title="Frosty Returns">Frosty Returns</a></i> is not available on any streaming service since 2023, but is exclusively available only on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DVD" title="DVD">DVD</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blu-ray" title="Blu-ray">Blu-ray</a>. <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frosty_the_Snowman_(TV_special)" title="Frosty the Snowman (TV special)">Frosty the Snowman</a></i> and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudolph_the_Red-Nosed_Reindeer_(TV_special)" title="Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer (TV special)">Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer</a></i> both moved to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">NBC</a> on December 5, 2024, and December 6, 2024, respectively.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-473" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-473"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>447<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-474" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-474"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>448<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>19
</th>
<td>A helicopter operated by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/O%26O" class="mw-redirect" title="O&amp;O">O&amp;O</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPVI-TV" title="WPVI-TV">WPVI-TV</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia" title="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a> crashes in a wooded area in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Township,_Burlington_County,_New_Jersey" title="Washington Township, Burlington County, New Jersey">Washington Township, Burlington County, New Jersey</a>, killing pilot Monroe Smith and camera operator Christopher Dougherty.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-475" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-475"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>449<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>26
</th>
<td>Stating the need remains to continue ensuring competition and diversity of viewpoint, the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FCC" class="mw-redirect" title="FCC">FCC</a>
 announces in its quadrennial ownership review that it will uphold 
restrictions that forbid common ownership of two of the four major TV 
networks, and strengthen rules that forbid one entity from owning every 
TV station in a single market (with case-specific requests for ownership
 of more than one of a market's top-four stations still considered). 
Broadcasters had lobbied for the loosening of station ownership rules, 
citing loss of audience share to streaming services.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-476" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-476"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>450<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>28
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altice_USA" title="Altice USA">Altice USA</a> announces it has sold <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheddar_(TV_channel)" title="Cheddar (TV channel)">Cheddar</a>, the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Millennials" title="Millennials">millennial-targeting</a> business news channel, to the media company Archetype; the financial terms are undisclosed.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-477" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-477"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>451<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>29
</th>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramount_Global" title="Paramount Global">Paramount</a>-owned over-the-air network <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dabl" title="Dabl">Dabl</a> receives a major rebrand. The network also transitions into broadcasting <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_sitcom" title="Black sitcom">Black sitcoms</a>, after four years of airing lifestyle-oriented programs.
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Television_shows">Television shows</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Television shows"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Shows_debuting_in_2023">Shows debuting in 2023</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Shows debuting in 2023"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1236090951">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .hatnote{display:none!important}}</style><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_2023_American_television_debuts" title="List of 2023 American television debuts">List of 2023 American television debuts</a></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Shows_changing_networks">Shows changing networks</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Shows changing networks"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<table class="wikitable sortable jquery-tablesorter">

<thead><tr>
<th class="headerSort" tabindex="0" role="columnheader button" title="Sort ascending">Show</th>
<th class="headerSort" tabindex="0" role="columnheader button" title="Sort ascending">Moved from</th>
<th class="headerSort" tabindex="0" role="columnheader button" title="Sort ascending">Moved to</th>
<th class="headerSort" tabindex="0" role="columnheader button" title="Sort ascending">Source
</th></tr></thead><tbody>
<tr>
<td><i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Love_%26_Hip_Hop:_Atlanta" title="Love &amp; Hip Hop: Atlanta">Love &amp; Hip Hop: Atlanta</a></i>
</td>
<td rowspan="2"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VH1" title="VH1">VH1</a>
</td>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Entering_syndication_in_2023">Entering syndication in 2023</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Entering syndication in 2023"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>A list of programs (current or canceled) that have accumulated enough
 episodes (between 65 and 100) or seasons (three or more) to be eligible
 for off-network syndication and/or basic cable runs.
</p>

<th>Notes</th>
