<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Networks_and_services">Networks and services</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Networks and services"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Launches">Launches</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Launches"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th style="text-align:center; width:125px">Network
</th>
<th style="text-align:center; width:130px">Type
</th>
<th style="text-align:center; width:60px">Launch date
</th>
<th style="text-align:center; width:500px">Notes
</th>
<th style="text-align:center; width:30px">Sources
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_News_(streaming_service)" class="mw-redirect" title="CBS News (streaming service)">CBS News</a> Detroit
</td>
<td>OTT streaming
</td>
<td>January 23
</td>
<td>On December 14, 2021, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_News_and_Stations" title="CBS News and Stations">CBS News and Stations</a> announced that it would launch CBS News Detroit, a hybrid news department utilizing resources from their <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Detroit" title="Detroit">Detroit</a> duopoly of CBS O&amp;O <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WWJ-TV" title="WWJ-TV">WWJ-TV</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_CW" title="The CW">CW</a> O&amp;O <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WKBD-TV" title="WKBD-TV">WKBD-TV</a>,
 which relaunched in-house news operations for the first time since 
their previous effort was discontinued in December 2002; the news 
department and streaming channel was originally planned to launch in the
 second or third quarter of 2022, but was delayed until January due to 
pandemic-related broadcast equipment supply issues. CBS News Detroit 
launched with the news operation on January 23 (see that date's entry in
 the "Events" section), initially offering supplemental national content
 from the CBS News streaming service for much of its schedule, outside 
of simulcasts of WWJ's initial two weeknight newscasts and a half-hour 
streaming-exclusive extension of its early evening edition. 
Collectively, CBS News Detroit is expected to eventually produce 137 
hours per week of live news programming (40 hours of which consists of 
WWJ/WKBD news simulcasts), along with national CBS News streaming 
content.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-vty-cbsnewsdetroit_30-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vty-cbsnewsdetroit-30"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CBS_News_Streaming_757-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CBS_News_Streaming-757"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>728<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-bc-cbsnewsdetroit_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bc-cbsnewsdetroit-33"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-freep-cbsnewsdetroit_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-freep-cbsnewsdetroit-34"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>The Cowgirl Channel
</td>
<td>Cable/satellite and OTT streaming
</td>
<td>February 5
</td>
<td>A spinoff of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Cowboy_Channel" title="The Cowboy Channel">The Cowboy Channel</a>,
 the Rural Media Group-owned network focuses on content dedicated to 
women in western sports. Programming includes live professional rodeo 
and other western sporting events (including <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barrel_racing" title="Barrel racing">barrel racing</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breakaway_roping" title="Breakaway roping">breakaway roping</a>
 and women's ranch rodeo events), and western-themed lifestyle content 
(such as fashion and home design programs). The Cowgirl Channel was 
initially available on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dish_Network" title="Dish Network">Dish Network</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sling_TV" title="Sling TV">Sling TV</a>,
 along with live streaming and VOD content being made available on its 
sister network's dedicated OTT streaming service, Cowboy Channel+.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-758" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-758"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>729<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-759" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-759"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>730<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_Sports_Golazo_Network" class="mw-redirect" title="CBS Sports Golazo Network">CBS Sports Golazo Network</a>
</td>
<td>OTT streaming
</td>
<td>April 11
</td>
<td>A soccer-focused OTT network from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_Sports" title="CBS Sports">CBS Sports</a>, the network (which is based out of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stamford,_Connecticut" title="Stamford, Connecticut">Stamford, Connecticut</a>) features a new weekday morning snow called <i>Morning Footy,</i> live studio programming for the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League" title="UEFA Champions League">UEFA Champions League</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NWSL" class="mw-redirect" title="NWSL">NWSL</a>, breaking news programming and select live matches from CBS's soccer properties.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-760" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-760"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>731<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-761" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-761"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>732<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-762" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-762"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>note 30<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectrum_News" title="Spectrum News">Spectrum News+</a>
</td>
<td>OTT streaming
</td>
<td>April 17
</td>
<td>A national cable/streaming news channel operated by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charter_Communications" title="Charter Communications">Charter Communications</a>-owned <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectrum_(brand)" title="Spectrum (brand)">Spectrum Networks</a>, the network features reports from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectrum_News" title="Spectrum News">Spectrum News</a>' 30+ regional cable news channels (such as <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_1" class="mw-redirect" title="New York 1">New York 1</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bay_News_9" title="Bay News 9">Bay News 9</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectrum_News_13" title="Spectrum News 13">Spectrum News 13</a>
 and the Spectrum News 1 networks), as well as national and 
international headlines, weather coverage, special reports and selected 
original programming from various Spectrum News regional channels. The 
network—which initially offered a 24-hour rolling news schedule on 
weekdays, with plans to expand its weekend programming to a 24-hour 
schedule as well by Summer—was available at launch to Spectrum 
residential cable customers, the Spectrum News mobile app, and connected
 TV apps for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roku" title="Roku">Roku</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_TV" title="Apple TV">Apple TV</a> devices.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-763" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-763"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>733<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-764" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-764"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>734<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Court_TV" title="Court TV">Court TV</a> Legendary Trials
</td>
<td rowspan="2">OTT streaming
</td>
<td rowspan="2">July 17
</td>
<td rowspan="2">The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._W._Scripps_Company" title="E. W. Scripps Company">E. W. Scripps Company</a>'s <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scripps_Networks" title="Scripps Networks">Scripps Networks</a> unit launched two ad-supported streaming channels—initially available on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_Freevee" title="Amazon Freevee">Amazon Freevee</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fubo" class="mw-redirect" title="Fubo">Fubo</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plex_Inc." class="mw-redirect" title="Plex Inc.">Plex</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xumo_Play" class="mw-redirect" title="Xumo Play">Xumo Play</a>—
serving as extension services of namesake digital multicast networks 
Court TV and Laff. Court TV Legendary Trials features four-hour blocks 
of archival, high-profile court cases from the network's library (dating
 to its initial 1991–2005 existence as a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TruTV" title="TruTV">cable channel</a>),
 featuring commentary and analysis from current Court TV anchors, while 
Laff More features classic sitcoms and unscripted comedy programs from 
the 1950s to the 1990s (including many series shown on the linear Laff 
network) as well as comedy films.
</td>
<td rowspan="2"><sup id="cite_ref-765" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-765"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>735<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laff_(TV_network)" title="Laff (TV network)">Laff</a> More
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>CNN Max
</td>
<td>OTT streaming
</td>
<td>September 27
</td>
<td>On August 24, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warner_Bros._Discovery" title="Warner Bros. Discovery">Warner Bros. Discovery</a> announced that it would incorporate live news into company's streaming service <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_(streaming_service)" title="Max (streaming service)">Max</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-766" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-766"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>736<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crunchyroll_Channel" class="mw-redirect" title="Crunchyroll Channel">Crunchyroll Channel</a>
</td>
<td>OTT streaming
</td>
<td>October 11
</td>
<td>On October 4, Sony announced it would launch the Crunchyroll Channel as a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_ad-supported_streaming_television" title="Free ad-supported streaming television">free ad-supported streaming television</a> (FAST) network under a partnership between <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crunchyroll" title="Crunchyroll">Crunchyroll</a> and its sister channel, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_Show_Network" title="Game Show Network">Game Show Network</a>. The linear service launched on October 11 for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Roku_Channel" title="The Roku Channel">The Roku Channel</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LG" title="LG">LG</a> Channels, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vizio" title="Vizio">Vizio</a> WatchFree+ platforms. The channel later became available on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_Freevee" title="Amazon Freevee">Amazon Freevee</a> on October 17, and on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pluto_TV" title="Pluto TV">Pluto TV</a> on February 5, 2024. The initial programming lineup featured Japanese and English versions of anime titles such as <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horimiya" class="mw-redirect" title="Horimiya">Horimiya</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ranking_of_Kings" title="Ranking of Kings">Ranking of Kings</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moriarty_the_Patriot" title="Moriarty the Patriot">Moriarty the Patriot</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psycho-Pass" title="Psycho-Pass">Psycho-Pass</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arifureta:_From_Commonplace_to_World%27s_Strongest" class="mw-redirect" title="Arifureta: From Commonplace to World's Strongest">Arifureta: From Commonplace to World's Strongest</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sugar_Apple_Fairy_Tale" title="Sugar Apple Fairy Tale">Sugar Apple Fairy Tale</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/To_Your_Eternity" title="To Your Eternity">To Your Eternity</a></i>, and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Code_Geass" title="Code Geass">Code Geass</a></i>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-767" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-767"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>737<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-768" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-768"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>738<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-769" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-769"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>739<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-770" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-770"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>740<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Nest_(TV_network)" title="The Nest (TV network)">The Nest</a>
</td>
<td>OTA multicast
</td>
<td>October 30
</td>
<td>Five months after selling controlling interest in the sports-oriented Stadium to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silver_Chalice" class="mw-redirect" title="Silver Chalice">Silver Chalice</a> (see May 29 entry), <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinclair_Broadcast_Group" title="Sinclair Broadcast Group">Sinclair Broadcast Group</a>
 converts Stadium's OTA channel space into a network of "comfort food 
programming" (Sinclair's term) that features reruns of home improvement,
 true crime, reality and celebrity-driven shows.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-771" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-771"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>741<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-772" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-772"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>742<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>NBCUniversal AVOD networks<br>(27 channels)
</td>
<td>OTT streaming
</td>
<td rowspan="2">TBD
</td>
<td>On June 29, NBCUniversal announced it would launch 27 thematic 
ad-supported streaming channels—initially available on Xumo Play (owned 
by corporate parent <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comcast" title="Comcast">Comcast</a>)
 and Amazon Freevee—consisting of content from the company's programming
 library, and programs sourced from its linear broadcast and cable 
channels. The networks consist of eight generalized programming services
 (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reality_television" title="Reality television">reality</a>-focused <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bravo_(American_TV_network)" title="Bravo (American TV network)">Bravo</a> Vault; true crime networks <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxygen_(TV_network)" title="Oxygen (TV network)">Oxygen</a> True Crime Archives and American Crimes; entertainment news and reviews channel <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a>; <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TNBC" title="TNBC">TNBC</a>,
 featuring sitcoms originated on the 1992–2002 NBC Saturday morning 
block and other family-oriented comedies; and themed entertainment 
channels Universal Action, Universal Crime, Universal Monsters and 
Universal Westerns), two sports channels (sports news and talk service <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC_Sports" title="NBC Sports">NBC Sports</a>; and GolfPass, an extension of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golf_Channel" title="Golf Channel">Golf Channel</a> featuring news and features programs, and the linear network's original magazine and instructional programs), four <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telemundo" title="Telemundo">Telemundo</a>-
based Spanish-language channels (romance-focused entertainment network 
Historias de Amor; Lo Mejor de Telemundo, featuring selected original 
reality series, dramas and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telenovela" title="Telenovela">telenovelas</a> from the network; <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_cable_news" title="United States cable news">24-hour streaming news</a> service <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noticias_Telemundo" title="Noticias Telemundo">Noticias Telemundo</a> Ahora; and entertainment and sports news service Telemundo al Día), and 13 series-specific channels (devoted to the <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keeping_Up_with_the_Kardashians" title="Keeping Up with the Kardashians">Keeping Up with the Kardashians</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_Housewives" class="mw-redirect" title="Real Housewives">Real Housewives</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Top_Chef" title="Top Chef">Top Chef</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Million_Dollar_Listing" title="Million Dollar Listing">Million Dollar Listing</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bad_Girls_Club" title="Bad Girls Club">Bad Girls Club</a></i> and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saved_by_the_Bell" title="Saved by the Bell">Saved by the Bell</a></i> franchises, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live" title="Saturday Night Live">Saturday Night Live</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Little_House_on_the_Prairie_(TV_series)" title="Little House on the Prairie (TV series)">Little House on the Prairie</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock_Presents" title="Alfred Hitchcock Presents">Alfred Hitchcock Presents</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lassie_(1954_TV_series)" title="Lassie (1954 TV series)">Lassie</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Lone_Ranger_(TV_series)" title="The Lone Ranger (TV series)">The Lone Ranger</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Made_in_Chelsea" title="Made in Chelsea">Made in Chelsea</a></i> and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murder,_She_Wrote" title="Murder, She Wrote">Murder, She Wrote</a></i>).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-773" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-773"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>743<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Now TV
</td>
<td>vMVPD streaming
</td>
<td>On May 23, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comcast" title="Comcast">Comcast</a> announced that it would launch an American version of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Now_(Sky)" class="mw-redirect" title="Now (Sky)">Now</a>, the vMVPD streaming service operated by its <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sky_Group" title="Sky Group">Sky Group</a> division in the United Kingdom and Europe, which will be available to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xfinity" title="Xfinity">Xfinity</a> Internet customers through the Xfinity Stream app on supported devices (including <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xfinity_Flex" title="Xfinity Flex">Xfinity Flex</a>, Fire TV, iOS and Android devices), and via casting through <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AirPlay" title="AirPlay">AirPlay</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Chromecast" class="mw-redirect" title="Google Chromecast">Google Chromecast</a>. The discount service will initially feature a lineup of around 40 channels from companies that include <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A%26E_Networks" title="A&amp;E Networks">A&amp;E Networks</a>; <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AMC_Networks" title="AMC Networks">AMC Networks</a>; <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allen_Media_Group" title="Allen Media Group">Allen Media Group</a>; <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crown_Media_Holdings" class="mw-redirect" title="Crown Media Holdings">Crown Media Holdings</a>; <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_American_Media" title="Great American Media">Great American Media</a>; <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony_Pictures_Television" title="Sony Pictures Television">Sony Pictures Television</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warner_Bros._Discovery" title="Warner Bros. Discovery">Warner Bros. Discovery</a> (including A&amp;E, Discovery Channel, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_(American_TV_network)" class="mw-redirect" title="History (American TV network)">History</a>, AMC, Lifetime, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_American_Family" title="Great American Family">Great American Family</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hallmark_Channel" title="Hallmark Channel">Hallmark Channel</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_Show_Network" title="Game Show Network">Game Show Network</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Weather_Channel" title="The Weather Channel">The Weather Channel</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Food_Network" title="Food Network">Food Network</a>), and over 20 free ad-supported television (FAST) channels operated by NBC, Sky and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xumo_Play" class="mw-redirect" title="Xumo Play">Xumo Play</a> (such as NBC News Now and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sky_News" title="Sky News">Sky News</a>), as well as complimentary access to the ad-supported version of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peacock_(streaming_service)" title="Peacock (streaming service)">Peacock</a>'s
 premium tier (which Comcast will cease offering separately at no 
additional charge to subscribers of Xfinity's Internet tiers on June 
26).
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-774" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-774"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>744<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-775" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-775"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>745<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Conversions_and_rebrandings">Conversions and rebrandings</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Conversions and rebrandings"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th style="text-align:center; width:125px">Old network<br>name
</th>
<th style="text-align:center; width:125px">New network<br>name
</th>
<th style="text-align:center; width:130px">Type
</th>
<th style="text-align:center; width:60px">Conversion date
</th>
<th style="text-align:center; width:500px">Notes
</th>
<th style="text-align:center; width:30px">Source
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>Newsy
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scripps_News" title="Scripps News">Scripps News</a>
</td>
<td>OTA multicast and OTT streaming
</td>
<td>January 1
</td>
<td>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._W._Scripps_Company" title="E. W. Scripps Company">E. W. Scripps Company</a>
 announced on September 29, 2022, that it would rebrand Newsy as Scripps
 News, a rebranding that is part of a broader corporate reorganization 
of Scripps' national news services—including its <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> bureau and the Scripps Local Media unit's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denver" title="Denver">Denver</a>-based national desk—into a singular division under the same name. The move comes <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1154941027"><span class="frac">1<span class="sr-only">+</span><span class="num">1</span>⁄<span class="den">2</span></span>
 years after a previous rebrand that saw Newsy expand its weekday live 
news and original news/interview programming, coinciding with the 
network's transition from a cable to an OTA multicast distribution 
model. (Scripps-owned <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Court_TV" title="Court TV">Court TV</a>—
which offers a weekday block of trial coverage and crime-related news 
programming—remains under the oversight of the company's president of 
network news, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kate_O%27Brian" title="Kate O'Brian">Kate O'Brian</a>,
 who is executive vice president of the new division.) At the start of 
June, Scripps's traditional broadcast stations began to carry a daily 
hour of Scripps news programming, replacing the hour formerly held by 
the internally-produced <i>The List</i> and <i>The Upside</i>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-776" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-776"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>746<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Epix
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MGM%2B" title="MGM+">MGM+</a>
</td>
<td>OTT streaming and cable/satellite
</td>
<td>January 15
</td>
<td>On September 28, 2022, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer" title="Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer">Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer</a>
 announced that it would rebrand Epix and its companion OTT streaming 
service Epix Now as MGM+ on January 15, 2023, as part of a broader 
effort to realign the service with the MGM brand and as a 
streaming-first platform with accompanying linear channel offerings. The
 rebranded service's three linear multiplex channels were renamed 
accordingly: Epix 2 as MGM+ Hits, Epix Hits as MGM+ Marquee and Epix 
Drive-In as MGM+ Drive-In.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-777" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-777"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>747<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Decades
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catchy_Comedy" title="Catchy Comedy">Catchy Comedy</a>
</td>
<td>OTA multicast and vMVPD streaming
</td>
<td>March 27
</td>
<td>On February 13, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weigel_Broadcasting" title="Weigel Broadcasting">Weigel Broadcasting</a>
 announced that it would rebrand Decades as Catchy Comedy on March 27, 
as part of the classic television network's broader shift from a general
 entertainment format towards classic sitcoms. The rebranded network's 
schedule features a thematic block format on weekdays (featuring 
family-oriented sitcoms in the morning, female-driven sitcoms in 
daytime, comedies from the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norman_Lear" title="Norman Lear">Norman Lear</a>
 library in prime time, and "smart" comedies in late night), while the 
weekend "Decades Binge" block was rebranded as "The Catchy Binge," 
focusing on binge-style marathons of various classic comedies.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-778" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-778"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>748<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Classic Reruns TV
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NOST" title="NOST">NOST</a>
</td>
<td>OTA multicast and OTT streaming
</td>
<td>April 3
</td>
<td>On April 3, Classic Broadcasting rebranded Classic Reruns TV as 
NOST:  The Nostalgia Network, shifting the network's format from classic
 television series to older licensed and public domain movies from the 
1940s through the early 1980s. The rebranded network's schedule 
incorporates thematic film blocks, including westerns on midday 
weekdays, a nightly "Primetime Spotlight" presentation, weekly "matinee"
 films on Saturday mornings, and the science fiction and horror movie 
showcase <i>Lord Blood-Rah's Nerve Wrackin' Theatre</i> on Saturday nights.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-779" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-779"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>749<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>HBO Max
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_(streaming_service)" title="Max (streaming service)">Max</a>
</td>
<td>OTT streaming
</td>
<td>May 23
</td>
<td>On April 12, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warner_Bros._Discovery" title="Warner Bros. Discovery">Warner Bros. Discovery</a> announced it would relaunch HBO Max as Max, featuring content from HBO Max's and much of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discovery%2B" title="Discovery+">Discovery+</a>'s libraries (including original content as well as content from various WBD brands such as <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warner_Bros." title="Warner Bros.">Warner Bros.</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Line_Cinema" title="New Line Cinema">New Line Cinema</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discovery_Channel" title="Discovery Channel">Discovery Channel</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HGTV" title="HGTV">HGTV</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Food_Network" title="Food Network">Food Network</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cartoon_Network" title="Cartoon Network">Cartoon Network</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warner_Bros._Animation" title="Warner Bros. Animation">Warner Bros. Animation</a>).
 Originally announced on August 4, 2022, the combined service was 
originally planned to operate on Discovery+'s existing app 
infrastructure and utilize that service's technical operations (as HBO 
Max ran on the infrastructure originally designed to support the smaller
 content selection and less intensive technical demands of the 
predecessor <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HBO_Go" title="HBO Go">HBO Go</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HBO_Now" title="HBO Now">HBO Now</a>
 services); however, WBD abandoned plans to fully integrate the services
 on February 23, choosing to maintain Discovery+ as a standalone 
platform due to the higher price point for Max, while incorporating much
 of the service's content library into Max. In addition to maintaining 
HBO Max's ad-free and ad-supported tiers at their existing price points 
(with user profiles, watch histories and other settings being ported to 
the relaunched service), Max included a tertiary "Ultimate" ad-free tier
 that features an expanded catalog of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4K_resolution" title="4K resolution">4K UHD</a> content (previously available to lower-tier subscribers) and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dolby_Atmos" title="Dolby Atmos">Dolby Atmos</a> surround sound.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-780" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-780"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>750<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-781" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-781"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>751<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-782" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-782"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>752<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-783" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-783"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>753<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-784" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-784"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>754<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>LX News
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC_LX_Home" title="NBC LX Home">NBC LX Home</a>
</td>
<td>OTA multicast and OTT streaming
</td>
<td>August
</td>
<td>Approximately 40 staffers at LX News were told on May 3 that <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBCUniversal" title="NBCUniversal">NBCUniversal</a>
 would be "winding down" the service, with a closure date expected in 
mid-2023 and employees being considered for other positions within the 
NBCU portfolio. LX News featured news/lifestyle features and longform 
content geared toward <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gen_Z" class="mw-redirect" title="Gen Z">Gen Z</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Millennial" class="mw-redirect" title="Millennial">millennial</a> audiences. Following the rebrand, NBC LX Home now airs <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LXTV" title="LXTV">LXTV</a> produced lifestyle programs.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-785" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-785"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>755<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-786" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-786"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>756<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>NBC Sports Washington
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monumental_Sports_Network" title="Monumental Sports Network">Monumental Sports Network</a>
</td>
<td rowspan="3"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_sports_network" title="Regional sports network">Regional sports network</a>
</td>
<td>September 12
</td>
<td>In August 2022, Monumental Sports &amp; Entertainment purchased NBC Sports Washington from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBCUniversal" title="NBCUniversal">NBCUniversal</a>. Monumental owns the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Wizards" title="Washington Wizards">Washington Wizards</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Capitals" title="Washington Capitals">Washington Capitals</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Mystics" title="Washington Mystics">Washington Mystics</a>,
 all of which have television rights agreements with the network. In 
June 2023, Monumental announced plans to rebrand the network in 
September 2023.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-787" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-787"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>757<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MSE_Completes_Acquisition_788-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MSE_Completes_Acquisition-788"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>758<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>AT&amp;T SportsNet Pittsburgh
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SportsNet_Pittsburgh" title="SportsNet Pittsburgh">SportsNet Pittsburgh</a>
</td>
<td>October 2
</td>
<td>On August 31, 2023, the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins" title="Pittsburgh Penguins">Pittsburgh Penguins</a> announced its intent to purchase <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AT%26T_SportsNet_Pittsburgh" class="mw-redirect" title="AT&amp;T SportsNet Pittsburgh">AT&amp;T SportsNet Pittsburgh</a> and rebrand it as SportsNet Pittsburgh on October 2. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NESN" title="NESN">NESN</a>, which is owned by Penguins owner <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fenway_Sports_Group" title="Fenway Sports Group">Fenway Sports Group</a>, operates the network. The purchase comes after <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AT%26T_SportsNet" title="AT&amp;T SportsNet">AT&amp;T SportsNet</a> owner <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warner_Bros._Discovery" title="Warner Bros. Discovery">Warner Bros. Discovery</a> announced in February they were leaving the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_sports_network" title="Regional sports network">regional sports network</a> business.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-sportsnet_789-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sportsnet-789"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>759<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>AT&amp;T SportsNet Southwest
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_City_Home_Network" title="Space City Home Network">Space City Home Network</a>
</td>
<td>October 3
</td>
<td>On September 16, 2023, the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Houston_Chronicle" title="Houston Chronicle">Houston Chronicle</a> reported that the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Houston_Astros" title="Houston Astros">Houston Astros</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Houston_Rockets" title="Houston Rockets">Houston Rockets</a> planned to purchase <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AT%26T_SportsNet_Southwest" class="mw-redirect" title="AT&amp;T SportsNet Southwest">AT&amp;T SportsNet Southwest</a> and rebrand it as Space City Home Network prior to the start of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023%E2%80%9324_Houston_Rockets_season" title="2023–24 Houston Rockets season">2023–24 Houston Rockets season</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-790" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-790"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>760<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-791" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-791"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>761<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dabl" title="Dabl">Dabl</a>
</td>
<td><i>same</i>
</td>
<td>OTA multicast
</td>
<td>December 29
</td>
<td>On December 21, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramount_Global" title="Paramount Global">Paramount Global</a> announced that it would rebrand Dabl as an African American-oriented network, focusing on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sitcom" title="Sitcom">sitcoms</a> that features a predominantly black cast from the 1990s to the 2000s. As part of the rebrand, its OTT streaming network on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pluto_TV" title="Pluto TV">Pluto TV</a> was discontinued.
</td>
<td>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Closures">Closures</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Closures"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th style="text-align:center; width:125px">Network
</th>
<th style="text-align:center; width:130px">Type
</th>
<th style="text-align:center; width:60px">End date
</th>
<th style="text-align:center; width:500px">Notes
</th>
<th style="text-align:center; width:30px">Sources
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL_RedZone#DirecTV_Red_Zone_Channel" title="NFL RedZone">DirecTV Red Zone Channel</a>
</td>
<td>Satellite
</td>
<td>January 8
</td>
<td>In December 2022, with the announcement that rights to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL_Sunday_Ticket" title="NFL Sunday Ticket">NFL Sunday Ticket</a> moved from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DirecTV" title="DirecTV">DirecTV</a>
 exclusively to YouTube (though it continues to carry the service for 
commercial and hospitality establishments under a subcontract), it was 
confirmed that the service would not produce its own equivalent, and 
would simply distribute the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL_Network" title="NFL Network">NFL Network</a>-produced <i>RedZone</i>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-792" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-792"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>762<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PeopleTV" class="mw-redirect" title="PeopleTV">PeopleTV</a>
</td>
<td>OTT streaming
</td>
<td>January 31
</td>
<td>On January 24, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dotdash_Meredith" title="Dotdash Meredith">Dotdash Meredith</a> began notifying carriers of the streaming entertainment news and lifestyle channel (which include vMVPD providers <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philo_(company)" title="Philo (company)">Philo</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FuboTV" title="FuboTV">FuboTV</a>, and AVOD streaming services <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tubi" title="Tubi">Tubi</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_Now" title="Local Now">Local Now</a>, DistroTV, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stirr" title="Stirr">Stirr</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xumo_Play" class="mw-redirect" title="Xumo Play">Xumo Play</a>) that it would shut down PeopleTV, a spin-off of the entertainment magazine, effective January 31.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-793" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-793"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>763<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TrueReal" title="TrueReal">TrueReal</a>
</td>
<td>OTA multicast
</td>
<td>March 27
</td>
<td>On March 10, the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._W._Scripps_Company" title="E. W. Scripps Company">E. W. Scripps Company</a> announced that it would discontinue TrueReal, effective March 27, and fold selected programming from its lineup (such as <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Storage_Wars" title="Storage Wars">Storage Wars</a></i> and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parking_Wars" title="Parking Wars">Parking Wars</a></i>) into the schedule of sister multicast network <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defy_TV" class="mw-redirect" title="Defy TV">Defy TV</a>; both networks had featured reruns of unscripted programming from the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A%26E_Networks" title="A&amp;E Networks">A&amp;E Networks</a>
 library, and had targeted different audiences in the 25-54 age group 
(TrueReal for women, Defy towards men), since jointly launching in July 
2021. Scripps leased TrueReal's transponder space to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jewelry_Television" title="Jewelry Television">Jewelry Television</a>, which filled the network's subchannel placements on Scripps- and Inyo Broadcast Holdings-owned stations.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-auto_794-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-794"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>764<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VRV_(streaming_service)" title="VRV (streaming service)">VRV</a>
</td>
<td>OTT streaming
</td>
<td>May 8
</td>
<td>On April 3, Crunchyroll, LLC announced that the anime, speculative 
fiction and gaming-centered streaming service would cease operating as a
 standalone service and integrate much of its content with the parent 
company's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crunchyroll" title="Crunchyroll">namesake service</a>,
 effective May 3; existing VRV subscriptions (including watch histories 
and queues) migrated to the Crunchyroll Premium service. The dissolution
 of VRV—launched in November 2016 as a joint venture between <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AT%26T" title="AT&amp;T">AT&amp;T</a> and the Chernin Group, and consisting of content from Crunchyroll and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mondo_Media" title="Mondo Media">Mondo Media</a>
 in addition to the premium tier VRV Select—is part of a broader 
consolidation of Crunchyroll, LLC's international anime streaming 
platforms (including <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Funimation" title="Funimation">Funimation</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wakanim" title="Wakanim">Wakanim</a>) into the existing Crunchyroll platform, which <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony_Pictures" title="Sony Pictures">Sony Pictures</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aniplex" title="Aniplex">Aniplex</a> acquired from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WarnerMedia" title="WarnerMedia">WarnerMedia</a> in August 2021.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-795" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-795"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>765<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bally_Sports_Arizona" title="Bally Sports Arizona">Bally Sports Arizona</a>
</td>
<td rowspan="2"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_sports_network" title="Regional sports network">Regional sports network</a>
</td>
<td>October 21
</td>
<td>On October 13, Bally Sports Arizona announced on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">Twitter</a> that it was shutting down. The network had lost the rights to its three professional sports teams due to its parent company's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diamond_Sports_Group#Bankruptcy" class="mw-redirect" title="Diamond Sports Group">ongoing bankruptcy</a>.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-796" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-796"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>766<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SportsNet_Rocky_Mountain" class="mw-redirect" title="SportsNet Rocky Mountain">SportsNet Rocky Mountain</a>
</td>
<td rowspan="4">December 31
</td>
<td>On September 5, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Denver_Post" title="The Denver Post">The Denver Post</a></i>
 reported that AT&amp;T SportsNet Rocky Mountain had notified its 
employees that the network would shut down at the end of the year. 
October 6 was the last day of work for full-time employees.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-797" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-797"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>767<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stadium_College_Sports" title="Stadium College Sports">Stadium College Sports</a>
</td>
<td>Cable network
</td>
<td>With Sinclair's sale of their stake in Stadium in full to Silver 
Chalice and the Stadium network being replaced over-the-air with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Nest_(TV_network)" title="The Nest (TV network)">The Nest</a>, Stadium College Sports was quietly and ultimately shut down on December 31, 2023.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-798" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-798"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>768<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circle_(TV_network)" class="mw-redirect" title="Circle (TV network)">Circle</a>
</td>
<td rowspan="2">OTA multicast
</td>
<td>On November 10, Gray Television announced that it would discontinue 
broadcast operations of Circle Network after December 31, with 
programming transitioning to streaming and other digital distribution 
platforms.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-799" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-799"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>769<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twist_(TV_network)" title="Twist (TV network)">Twist</a>
</td>
<td>In a video uploaded to Vimeo on November 15, Tegna announced that it
 planned to shut down Twist. The network, which launched on April 5, 
2021, featured reruns of reality programming aimed at women in the 25–34
 age group, sourced from the NBCUniversal library.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-800" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-800"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>770<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-801" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-801"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>771<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Television_stations">Television stations</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Television stations"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Station_launches">Station launches</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Station launches"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th>Date
</th>
<th>Market
</th>
<th>Station
</th>
<th>Channel
</th>
<th>Affiliation
</th>
<th>Notes
</th>
<th>Source
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="4">February 9
</td>
<td rowspan="4'"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fargo,_North_Dakota" title="Fargo, North Dakota">Fargo</a>-<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Forks,_North_Dakota" title="Grand Forks, North Dakota">Grand Forks, North Dakota</a>
</td>
<td rowspan="4"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KNGF" title="KNGF">KNGF</a>
</td>
<td>27.1
</td>
<td>BEK Sports
</td>
<td rowspan="4">Channel 27 in Grand Forks was formerly occupied by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KCPM_(TV)" title="KCPM (TV)">KCPM</a>,
 whose license was canceled on March 9, 2020, for failure to transmit 
from authorized facilities for the past 12 months. The frequency was put
 up for auction on June 7, 2022, along with 26 other full-power TV 
licenses. BEK Sports Network, Inc. was awarded channel 27 with a 
$6,411,000 winning bid.
<p>BEK was formally granted a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Construction_permit" class="mw-redirect" title="Construction permit">construction permit</a>
 for the new station on July 25, 2022. KNGF filed for a license to cover
 on February 9, 2023, which usually indicates that a station has signed 
on the air.
</p><p>Prior to KNGF's launch, BEK programming was seen on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KRDK-TV" title="KRDK-TV">KRDK-TV</a> (channel 4) during the afternoon and evening hours.
</p>
</td>
<td rowspan="4"><sup id="cite_ref-802" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-802"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>772<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-803" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-803"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>773<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-kngfl2c_804-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kngfl2c-804"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>774<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-805" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-805"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>775<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-806" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-806"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>776<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>27.2
</td>
<td>BEK Sports Plus East
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>27.3
</td>
<td>BEK Sports Plus West
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>27.4
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NewsNet" title="NewsNet">NewsNet</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="2">September 26
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flagstaff,_Arizona" title="Flagstaff, Arizona">Flagstaff, Arizona</a>
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KAZF" class="mw-redirect" title="KAZF">KAZF</a>
</td>
<td>32.1
</td>
<td rowspan="2"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_station_(North_America)" class="mw-redirect" title="Independent station (North America)">Independent</a>
</td>
<td rowspan="2">In 2022, Gray Television participated in an FCC auction of new TV stations and paid $4.648 million for channel 32 in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flagstaff,_Arizona" title="Flagstaff, Arizona">Flagstaff</a> and $1.345 million for channel 11 in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yuma,_Arizona" title="Yuma, Arizona">Yuma</a>. The FCC approved a request from Gray Television to change the Yuma allotment from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VHF" class="mw-redirect" title="VHF">VHF</a> channel 11 to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UHF" class="mw-redirect" title="UHF">UHF</a> channel 27 in February 2023. KAZS, the Yuma station, began broadcasting by September 26, 2023, when KAZF in Flagstaff debuted.
</td>
<td rowspan="10"><sup id="cite_ref-807" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-807"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>777<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-808" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-808"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>778<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-809" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-809"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>779<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-810" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-810"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>780<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yuma,_Arizona" title="Yuma, Arizona">Yuma, Arizona</a>-<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/El_Centro,_California" title="El Centro, California">El Centro, California</a>
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KAZS" class="mw-redirect" title="KAZS">KAZS</a>
</td>
<td>27.1
</td></tr></tbody></table>

<td>January 13
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/El_Paso,_Texas" title="El Paso, Texas">El Paso, Texas</a>
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KVIA-TV" title="KVIA-TV">KVIA-TV</a>
</td>
<td>7.4
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QVC" title="QVC">QVC</a> Over the Air
</td>
<td>On October 21, 2022, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Innovate_Corp" class="mw-redirect" title="Innovate Corp">Innovate Corp</a>,
 the company that owned Azteca America, announced that the network would
 cease operations on December 31, 2022. Prior to the announcement, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TV_Azteca" title="TV Azteca">TV Azteca</a> had entered into a content and co-production agreement with competitor <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Estrella_TV" title="Estrella TV">Estrella TV</a> that will see its news and entertainment programming blended onto that network's schedule.<sup id="cite_ref-TV_Azteca_Estrella_TV_agreemnent_811-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TV_Azteca_Estrella_TV_agreemnent-811"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>781<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> TV Stations were notified of the closure and had switched affiliations to other networks such as Estrella TV and Vision Latina.<sup id="cite_ref-Azteca_America_Closure_812-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Azteca_America_Closure-812"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>782<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td>

</td>

</td>
<td rowspan="2"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bryan,_Texas" title="Bryan, Texas">Bryan, Texas</a>
</td>
<td rowspan="2"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KRHD-CD" title="KRHD-CD">KRHD-CD</a>

programming from TrueReal would be folded into the schedule of sister 
multicast network Defy TV (see Closures above). The Scripps spectrum 
space TrueReal leaves behind will be leased by Scripps to the shopping 
channel Jewelry Television.

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Stations_changing_network_affiliations">Stations changing network affiliations</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Stations changing network affiliations"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>

<td rowspan="38">January 1
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albuquerque,_New_Mexico" title="Albuquerque, New Mexico">Albuquerque, New Mexico</a>
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KQDF-LD" class="mw-redirect" title="KQDF-LD">KQDF-LD</a>
</td>
<td>25.1
</td>
<td rowspan="38"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azteca_America" class="mw-redirect" title="Azteca America">Azteca America</a>
</td>
<td>Vision Latina
</td>
<td rowspan="38">On October 21, 2022, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Innovate_Corp" class="mw-redirect" title="Innovate Corp">Innovate Corp</a>,
 the company that owned Azteca America, announced that the network would
 cease operations on December 31, 2022. Prior to the announcement, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TV_Azteca" title="TV Azteca">TV Azteca</a> had entered into a content and co-production agreement with competitor <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Estrella_TV" title="Estrella TV">Estrella TV</a> that will see its news and entertainment programming blended onto that network's schedule.<sup id="cite_ref-TV_Azteca_Estrella_TV_agreemnent_811-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TV_Azteca_Estrella_TV_agreemnent-811"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>781<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Many stations owned by Innovate switched to other networks such as Estrella TV and Vision Latina.<sup id="cite_ref-Azteca_America_Closure_812-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Azteca_America_Closure-812"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>782<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td>
<td><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2023)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>

<tr>
<td>March 1
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoenix,_Arizona" title="Phoenix, Arizona">Phoenix, Arizona</a>
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KPHE-LD" class="mw-redirect" title="KPHE-LD">KPHE-LD</a>
</td>
<td>44.1
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LATV" title="LATV">LATV</a>
</td>
<td>Independent
</td>
<td>On March 11, 2022, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gray_Television" class="mw-redirect" title="Gray Television">Gray Television</a> (owner of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a> affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KPHO-TV" title="KPHO-TV">KPHO-TV</a> and independent station <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KTVK" title="KTVK">KTVK</a>) acquired KPHE-LD from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotus_Communications" title="Lotus Communications">Lotus Communications</a>
 for $1.75 million; the sale was completed on May 4. Ten months later on
 January 25, Gray announced that it would convert KPHE into an 
independent station (branded as the "Arizona's Family Sports and 
Entertainment Network," the first part referencing KTVK/ KPHO's shared 
slogan that originated on the former in 2003) on March 1; the station 
airs simulcasts of most of KTVK/KPHO's newscasts, sporting events (such 
as <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoenix_Rising_FC" title="Phoenix Rising FC">Phoenix Rising FC</a> soccer matches, selected games of which will be simulcast on either KTVK or KPHO during the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USL_Championship" title="USL Championship">USL</a> regular season, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arizona_Interscholastic_Association" title="Arizona Interscholastic Association">Arizona Interscholastic Association</a> high school state championship games), and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PowerNation" title="PowerNation">PowerNation</a>-distributed sports and automotive programming. With KTVK, KPHE also serves as the television home of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoenix_Mercury" title="Phoenix Mercury">Phoenix Mercury</a> of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WNBA" class="mw-redirect" title="WNBA">WNBA</a> as of May, and the NBA's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoenix_Suns" title="Phoenix Suns">Phoenix Suns</a>, beginning in October.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-kphetogray_831-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kphetogray-831"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>801<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-832" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-832"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>802<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-833" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-833"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>803<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>

</td>
<td><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. <tr>
<td>August 28
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laughlin,_Nevada" title="Laughlin, Nevada">Laughlin</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Las_Vegas,_Nevada" class="mw-redirect" title="Las Vegas, Nevada">Las Vegas, Nevada</a>
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KMCC" title="KMCC">KMCC</a>
</td>
<td>34.1
</td>
<td rowspan="2"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ion_Television" title="Ion Television">Ion Television</a>
</td>
<td rowspan="2">Independent
</td>
<td rowspan="2">On May 4, as part of the announcement a deal that would bring the games of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Hockey_League" title="National Hockey League">National Hockey League</a>'s <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Stanley_Cup_Finals" title="2023 Stanley Cup Finals">defending champion</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vegas_Golden_Knights" title="Vegas Golden Knights">Vegas Golden Knights</a>
 to the station starting that Fall (see that entry above), the E. W. 
Scripps Company announced that KMCC would convert into an independent 
station later in the year, offering syndicated entertainment 
programming, news (including local newscasts produced by ABC-affiliated 
sister <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KTNV" class="mw-redirect" title="KTNV">KTNV</a>
 as well as Scripps-distributed news programs), and local sports events.
 Ion programming moved to the second digital subchannel of KMCC.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-tvnt-knights_258-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tvnt-knights-258"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>248<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ktnv-knights_259-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ktnv-knights-259"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>249<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-KMCC_257-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KMCC-257"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>247<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-kmcc-switch_834-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kmcc-switch-834"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>804<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="19">September 1
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salt_Lake_City,_Utah" class="mw-redirect" title="Salt Lake City, Utah">Salt Lake City, Utah</a>
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KUPX-TV" title="KUPX-TV">KUPX-TV</a>
</td>
<td>16.1
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-835" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-835"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>805<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="2"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlanta,_Georgia" class="mw-redirect" title="Atlanta, Georgia">Atlanta, Georgia</a>
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WUPA" title="WUPA">WUPA</a>
</td>
<td>69.1
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_CW" title="The CW">The CW</a>
</td>
<td>Independent
</td>
<td rowspan="18">On May 5, CBS News and Stations announced that the 
company would convert its eight CW-affiliated stations into independents
 on September 1, intending to fill prime time slots with locally 
produced programs (including news and live sports, with CBSNS likely to 
pursue rights to professional sports teams currently held by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bally_Sports" class="mw-redirect" title="Bally Sports">Bally Sports</a> networks in those markets) and programming from other properties owned by parent company <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramount_Global" title="Paramount Global">Paramount Global</a>,
 which sold most of its 50% stake in The CW (as did original co-parent 
Warner Bros. Discovery, both of which retained 12.5% shares in the 
network) to Nexstar Media Group in October 2022. CW programming will 
move to other stations in the affected markets (four of which, 
Philadelphia, San Francisco, Sacramento and Tampa, are home to stations 
operated by Nexstar—<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPHL-TV" title="WPHL-TV">WPHL</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KRON" class="mw-redirect" title="KRON">KRON</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KTXL" title="KTXL">KTXL</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WFLA-TV" title="WFLA-TV">WFLA</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WTTA" title="WTTA">WTTA</a>, respectively), while Nexstar partner company <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mission_Broadcasting" title="Mission Broadcasting">Mission Broadcasting</a> is in the process of acquiring <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WADL_(TV)" title="WADL (TV)">WADL</a>
 in the Detroit market (that station would confirm its switch to The 
CW—replacing WKBD—through a promotional video posted on its website in 
late August). On June 14, Nexstar announced that MyNetworkTV affiliates 
WPHL, KRON and WTTA would switch to The CW on September 1, with 
MyNetworkTV programming either moving to a different timeslot or one of 
the stations' digital subchannels. CBS's stations in San Francisco and 
Pittsburgh will also change their callsigns in concert with the 
affiliation switch on September 1. On August 1, it was announced that 
KQCA would switch to The CW as part of a broader deal extending the 
network's affiliations with Hearst-owned stations in six other markets, 
with Nexstar station KTXL retaining the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox</a>
 affiliation. During the week of August 28, Gray Television—under a deal
 extending the network's affiliations in eight other markets—announced 
that WPCH (which had been operating as an independent since its 1967 
sign-on and was the originating feed of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TBS_(American_TV_channel)" title="TBS (American TV channel)">TBS</a>
 from 1976 to 2007) would replace WUPA as the network's Atlanta 
affiliate, while Sinclair Broadcast Group—as part of a renewal deal 
involving 18 other CW affiliates—agreed to assume the CW affiliations in
 Seattle (ABC affiliate KOMO-TV, which will become the network's largest
 subchannel-only affiliate by market size) and Pittsburgh (MyNetworkTV 
affiliate WPNT), in exchange for letting Nexstar assume the CW 
affiliation rights in Oklahoma City (which will move from KOCB to 
KAUT-TV).
</td>
<td rowspan="18"><sup id="cite_ref-CBS-1_836-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CBS-1-836"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>806<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-837" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-837"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>807<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-838" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-838"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>808<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-839" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-839"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>809<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-840" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-840"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>810<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-841" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-841"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>811<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-Gray-9-1_842-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gray-9-1-842"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>812<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-843" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-843"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>813<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><br><sup id="cite_ref-sinclair-cw_844-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sinclair-cw-844"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>814<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>

the network as part of a compensation dispute before the close of the 
Mission sale. Four days later, Nexstar announced that WMYD would take 
over the affiliation as of November 13.

</td>
<td>61.1
</td>
<td>The CW
</td>
<td>Independent
</td>
<td>A little over a month after sister station <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KNXV-TV" title="KNXV-TV">KNXV-DT2</a> acquired the rights to the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arizona_Coyotes" title="Arizona Coyotes">Arizona Coyotes</a>, the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._W._Scripps_Company" title="E. W. Scripps Company">E. W. Scripps Company</a>
 announced that KASW would become an independent to accommodate 
Scripps's local sports rights. KNXV-DT2 transitioned to carrying The CW 
on KASW's former pay-TV channel positions, with Antenna TV continuing to
 air at all other times.
</td>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Subchannels_changing_network_affiliations">Subchannels changing network affiliations</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Subchannels changing network affiliations"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>

<td rowspan="9">January 1
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fremont,_California" title="Fremont, California">Fremont</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco,_California" class="mw-redirect" title="San Francisco, California">San Francisco, California</a>
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KEMO-TV" title="KEMO-TV">KEMO-TV</a>
</td>
<td>50.4
</td>
<td rowspan="6"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azteca_Am%C3%A9rica" title="Azteca América">Azteca América</a>
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeless_TV" class="mw-redirect" title="Timeless TV">Timeless TV</a>
</td>
<td rowspan="9">On October 21, 2022, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Innovate_Corp" class="mw-redirect" title="Innovate Corp">Innovate Corp</a>,
 the company that owned Azteca America, announced that the network would
 cease operations on December 31, 2022. Prior to the announcement, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TV_Azteca" title="TV Azteca">TV Azteca</a> had entered into a content and co-production agreement with competitor <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Estrella_TV" title="Estrella TV">Estrella TV</a> that will see its news and entertainment programming blended onto that network's schedule.<sup id="cite_ref-TV_Azteca_Estrella_TV_agreemnent_811-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TV_Azteca_Estrella_TV_agreemnent-811"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>781<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> TV Stations were notified on the closure and had switch affiliations to other networks.<sup id="cite_ref-Azteca_America_Closure_812-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Azteca_America_Closure-812"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>782<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
 WTXX-LD, which was also an Azteca America affiliate moved its Timeless 
TV affiliation to the main subchannel as part of the closure, and 
WQDH-LD which was also an Azteca America affiliate moved its Shop LC 
affiliation to the main channel as part of the closure.
</td>

<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grit_(TV_network)" title="Grit (TV network)">Grit</a>
</td>
<td>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="84">March 28
</td>
<td rowspan="4"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albany,_New_York" title="Albany, New York">Albany</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schenectady" class="mw-redirect" title="Schenectady">Schenectady</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Troy,_New_York" title="Troy, New York">Troy, New York</a>
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WXXA-TV" title="WXXA-TV">WXXA-TV</a>
</td>
<td>23.3
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laff_(TV_network)" title="Laff (TV network)">Laff</a>
</td>
<td>Grit
</td>
<td rowspan="84"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._W._Scripps_Company" title="E. W. Scripps Company">E. W. Scripps Company</a> announced on March 10 that programming from TrueReal would be folded into the schedule of sister multicast network <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defy_TV" class="mw-redirect" title="Defy TV">Defy TV</a> (see Closures above). The Scripps spectrum space TrueReal leaves behind will be leased by Scripps to the shopping channel <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jewelry_Television" title="Jewelry Television">Jewelry Television</a>.
</td>
<td rowspan="84"><sup id="cite_ref-auto_794-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-794"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>764<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Deaths">Deaths</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Deaths"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="January_2">January</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: January"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<table class="wikitable sortable jquery-tablesorter">

<thead><tr>
<th class="headerSort" tabindex="0" role="columnheader button" title="Sort ascending">Date
</th>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="April_2">April</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: April"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>

<thead><tr>

<td>Game show host and animal rights activist best known for being the long-time host of <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truth_or_Consequences" title="Truth or Consequences">Truth or Consequences</a></i> from 1956 to 1975 and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Price_Is_Right" title="The Price Is Right">The Price Is Right</a></i> from 1972 to 2007. Also hosted the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miss_Universe" title="Miss Universe">Miss Universe</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miss_USA" title="Miss USA">Miss USA</a> pageants from 1967 to 1987.
</td>
<td><sup id="cite_ref-1005" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1005"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>975<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>

<td rowspan="2">August 29
</td>
<td><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don_Browne" title="Don Browne">Don Browne</a>
</td>
<td>80
</td>
<td>Television executive (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telemundo" title="Telemundo">Telemundo</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC_News" title="NBC News">NBC News</a>)
