<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Notes">Notes</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2023_in_American_television&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: Notes"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1239543626"><div class="reflist">
<div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-75"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-75" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Viewership
 for Super Bowl LVII was initially estimated at 113 million across Fox, 
Fox Deportes and streaming platforms; errors in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nielsen_Media_Research" title="Nielsen Media Research">Nielsen</a>'s
 audio encoding and out-of-home viewing methodologies were later 
determined to have undercounted viewership by two million viewers (one 
million misattributed to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL_Network" title="NFL Network">NFL Network</a>'s Super Bowl coverage and one million undercounted in out-of-home viewership tallies).<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-126"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-126" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">As
 part of the restructuring, Diamond Sports Group is expected to 
terminate less-profitable team contracts, particularly involving MLB 
teams for which it has been unable to acquire regional streaming rights 
for its Bally Sports+ service. MLB intends to acquire television rights 
for any teams contracted to air on selected Bally Sports networks in the
 event Diamond is unable to make its broadcast rights fee payments or 
terminates individual deals outright, distributing games from any 
affected clubs via <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MLB.tv" class="mw-redirect" title="MLB.tv">MLB.tv</a> and a traditional pay television network to be determined. On March 11, the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas_Rangers_(baseball)" title="Texas Rangers (baseball)">Texas Rangers</a> informed Diamond that it would terminate its media rights deal with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bally_Sports_Southwest" class="mw-redirect" title="Bally Sports Southwest">Bally Sports Southwest</a> (which syndicates its Rangers telecasts to its sister channels in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bally_Sports_Oklahoma" class="mw-redirect" title="Bally Sports Oklahoma">Oklahoma</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bally_Sports_New_Orleans" title="Bally Sports New Orleans">New Orleans</a>)
 in the event of the company's insolvency; Diamond stated it would 
contest the declaration on grounds it has not missed rights fee payments
 with the team.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>120<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Diamond later missed fee payments due to the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland_Guardians" title="Cleveland Guardians">Cleveland Guardians</a> (carried by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bally_Sports_Great_Lakes" class="mw-redirect" title="Bally Sports Great Lakes">Bally Sports Great Lakes</a>) and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minnesota_Twins" title="Minnesota Twins">Minnesota Twins</a> (carried by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bally_Sports_North" class="mw-redirect" title="Bally Sports North">Bally Sports North</a>) on April 1, and to the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Reds" title="Cincinnati Reds">Cincinnati Reds</a> (carried by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bally_Sports_Ohio" class="mw-redirect" title="Bally Sports Ohio">Bally Sports Ohio</a>) due on April 17.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>121<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>122<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On April 20, the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_District_Court_for_the_Southern_District_of_Texas" title="United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas">U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of Texas</a>
 (which is overseeing Diamond's Chapter 11 restructuring) instructed 
Diamond to pay half of the payments owed to the Diamondbacks, the 
Guardians, the Rangers and the Twins before the May 1 grace period 
deadline;<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>123<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
 it submitted a fee payment to the Reds on May 2, one day after the team
 indicated it would reclaim its broadcast rights effective May 6 unless 
Diamond paid out its 2023 contract before the end of its 15-day grace 
period.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>124<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On February 20, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_City_Business_Journals" title="American City Business Journals">Sports Business Journal</a></i>
 reported that the NBA quietly renewed its broadcast and streaming 
contracts with Diamond in June 2022, extending them through the 2024-25 
season. Diamond's $10.8 billion purchase of the Fox Sports Networks 
(renamed Bally Sports in March 2021) was necessitated due to antitrust 
concerns with Disney's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acquisition_of_21st_Century_Fox_by_Disney" title="Acquisition of 21st Century Fox by Disney">purchase</a> of certain <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/21st_Century_Fox" title="21st Century Fox">21st Century Fox</a> assets related to its controlling interest in competitor <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN_Inc." title="ESPN Inc.">ESPN Inc.</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-130"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-130" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Nexstar Media Group has long maintained <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_marketing_agreement" title="Local marketing agreement">outsourcing agreements</a>
 with affiliate companies like Mission and White Knight, through which 
Nexstar handles certain operational responsibilities—including 
advertising sales, newscast production and engineering services—for 
stations owned by the licensees.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-147"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-147" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">WPMI
 continues to produce early- and late-evening newscasts seven nights a 
week, WACH continues to produce half-hour 5:00 and 11:00&nbsp;p.m. 
newscasts on weekdays and an hour-long 10:00&nbsp;p.m. newscast seven 
nights a week, WGXA continues to produce a half-hour 5:00&nbsp;p.m. 
newscast as well as weekday morning and evening newscasts for its 
ABC-affiliated DT2 subchannel, and WEYI continues to produce 6:00 and 
11:00&nbsp;p.m. newscast on weekdays as well as a nightly 
10:00&nbsp;p.m. newscast for Fox-affiliated sister <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WSMH" title="WSMH">WSMH</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-199"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-199" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Lemon had co-anchored <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN_This_Morning_(2022)" title="CNN This Morning (2022)">CNN This Morning</a></i> since its November 2022 debut, after being moved from his prime time show, <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don_Lemon_Tonight" title="Don Lemon Tonight">Don Lemon Tonight</a></i> (originally titled <i>CNN Tonight with Don Lemon</i> from 2014 to 2021).</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-217"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-217" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The
 legislation grants authority to OETA in accordance with the Oklahoma 
Sunset Law, which includes provisions that would allow the Oklahoma 
Legislature to allocate funding for the namesake OETA state agency 
through July 2024, independently of securing its full authorization to 
operate. Stitt (who approved funding for OETA four times during his 
first term, including one passed in 2020 that runs through July 1) 
previously vetoed House Bill 1009XX, a bill that would have provided 
$8.1 million to fund the replacement of transmitters used to relay <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergency_Alert_System" title="Emergency Alert System">emergency alert</a> messages via its Warning, Alert and Response Network (WARN), in October 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>211<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-230"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-230" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">KTVL will continue to provide local weather updates presented by meteorologists from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eugene,_Oregon" title="Eugene, Oregon">Eugene</a>-based NBC sister <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KMTR" title="KMTR">KMTR</a> during the Sinclair-syndicated national newscast and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_Mornings" title="CBS Mornings">CBS Mornings</a></i>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-241"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-241" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Although
 all Phoenix Suns games will require a subscription to stream live, 
under the terms of the deal, the Phoenix Mercury will stream its games 
free of charge for its 2023 season. KUTP acquired local over-the-air 
rights to broadcast Phoenix Suns games in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1987%E2%80%9388_Phoenix_Suns_season" title="1987–88 Phoenix Suns season">1987</a>, taking over the contractual rights from then-Fox affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KNXV-TV" title="KNXV-TV">KNXV-TV</a> (now an ABC affiliate).</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-252"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-252" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">At 148 days, the 2023 Writers Guild of America strike was the second longest in the union's history (only the 153-day <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1988_Writers_Guild_of_America_strike" title="1988 Writers Guild of America strike">strike in 1988</a> was longer).</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-256"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-256" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The suspect, Jarrad Nathan, was identified to Memphis police officers as the shooter by family members.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-278"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-278" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Prior to the elimination of the rule through a 2021 <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States" title="Supreme Court of the United States">Supreme Court</a>
 decision that upheld modifications to media ownership rules made by the
 agency four years prior, the San Diego market—largely because several 
full-power channel allocations were reserved by Mexico's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Telecommunications_Institute" title="Federal Telecommunications Institute">Federal Telecommunications Institute</a> (and the predecessor <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Commission_of_Telecommunications" class="mw-redirect" title="Federal Commission of Telecommunications">Federal Commission of Telecommunications</a>) to the nearby <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tijuana" title="Tijuana">Tijuana</a> area—did not have enough full-power television stations to permit a duopoly under the FCC's "Eight Voices test" requirement.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-290"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-290" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">WideOpenWest ceased active marketing of WOW! tv+ in June 2020, in favor of marketing YouTube TV and rival vMVPD providers <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FuboTV" title="FuboTV">fuboTV</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sling_TV" title="Sling TV">Sling TV</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philo_(company)" title="Philo (company)">Philo</a> to its subscribers.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-311"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-311" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The
 restrictions will not apply to Netflix subscribers that access the 
service on their personal tablets or laptops, or log into a TV (such as 
at hotels or vacation rental properties) while traveling.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-319"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-319" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YurView_California" title="YurView California">YurView California</a>—
which airs the team's MLB-produced telecasts on Cox Communications' San 
Diego-area systems—previously acquired local cable rights to broadcast 
San Diego Padres games in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1997_San_Diego_Padres_season" title="1997 San Diego Padres season">1997</a> (as Channel 4 San Diego, which shared the contractual rights with independent station <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KUSI" class="mw-redirect" title="KUSI">KUSI</a> until <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_San_Diego_Padres_season" title="2003 San Diego Padres season">2003</a>). The Padres moved its regional telecasts to Bally Sports San Diego (then Fox Sports San Diego) when the network launched in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_San_Diego_Padres_season" title="2012 San Diego Padres season">2012</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-325"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-325" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The only granted waiver of the FCC's "top-four" prohibition involved <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gray_Television" class="mw-redirect" title="Gray Television">Gray Television</a>'s acquisition of NBC affiliate <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KDLT" class="mw-redirect" title="KDLT">KDLT</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sioux_Falls" class="mw-redirect" title="Sioux Falls">Sioux Falls</a>,
 which Red River Broadcasting sold to Gray in May 2018 for $32.5 
million, creating a duopoly with the latter's existing ABC affiliate in 
that market, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KSFY" class="mw-redirect" title="KSFY">KSFY</a>. The Forum acquisition was to have included a waiver to allow the company to purchase KVRR's three satellite stations, KBRR/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thief_River_Falls" class="mw-redirect" title="Thief River Falls">Thief River Falls</a>, KJRR/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamestown,_North_Dakota" title="Jamestown, North Dakota">Jamestown</a> and KNRR/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pembina,_North_Dakota" title="Pembina, North Dakota">Pembina</a>, allowing it to operate them alongside WDAY semi-satellite <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WDAZ" class="mw-redirect" title="WDAZ">WDAZ</a>/<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Devils_Lake,_North_Dakota" title="Devils Lake, North Dakota">Devils Lake</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-336"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-336" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Game 3 of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland_Cavaliers" title="Cleveland Cavaliers">Cleveland Cavaliers</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Knicks" title="New York Knicks">New York Knicks</a>
 first-round series aired nationally on ABC and within their designated 
markets on the teams' respective regional sports network partners, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bally_Sports_Ohio" class="mw-redirect" title="Bally Sports Ohio">Bally Sports Ohio</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MSG_Network" title="MSG Network">MSG Network</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-341"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-341" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">TBS did not carry the deciding Game 5 of the Stanley Cup Finals on June 13, due to a scheduling conflict with a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Mets" title="New York Mets">New York Mets</a>–<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Yankees" title="New York Yankees">New York Yankees</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MLB_on_TBS" title="MLB on TBS">Major League Baseball</a> game telecast, resulting in the Stanley Cup game being simulcast only on TNT and TruTV.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-347"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-347" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">KJZZ was owned by former Jazz owner <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larry_H._Miller" title="Larry H. Miller">Larry H. Miller</a>
 (who died in February 2009) from 1993 to 2016, when the Miller estate 
sold the station to Sinclair; Miller purchased the station to replace 
then-Fox O&amp;O (now affiliate) <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KSTU" title="KSTU">KSTU</a> as the local over-the-air carrier of Utah Jazz games, after the latter chose not to continue its contract after the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1992%E2%80%9393_Utah_Jazz_season" title="1992–93 Utah Jazz season">1992–93 season</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-leaguepass-356"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-leaguepass_356-0"><span class="cite-accessibility-label">Jump up to: </span><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-leaguepass_356-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">EverPass
 Media, a new investment company funded by RedBird Capital and the NFL, 
will also distribute NFL Sunday Ticket to bars, restaurants, hotels and 
other commercial venues via existing cable and satellite providers 
(including DirecTV, which signed a multi-year agreement with EverPass on
 May 25, to continue distributing the package to its business customers)
 under non-exclusive agreements.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>336<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>337<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-364"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-364" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The dispute also affected four stations licensed to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilo" class="mw-redirect" title="Hilo">Hilo</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wailuku" class="mw-redirect" title="Wailuku">Wailuku</a> that operate as <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadcast_relay_station#Satellite_stations" title="Broadcast relay station">satellites</a> of KHON and KHII: KHON repeaters KHAW and KAII, and KHII repeaters KGMD and KGMV, respectively.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-372"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-372" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Carriage
 agreements negotiated by RSNs have typically required their inclusion 
in highly-subscribed base tiers in order to generate additional carriage
 fees paid by subscribers (including non-sports viewers), though these 
fees as well as those from other networks (including larger national 
sports channels) have contributed to cord-cutting in recent years as the
 cost of programming packages have risen. The Spectrum Select Signature 
tier will include a limited slate of national sports networks (such as 
ESPN and FS1) among its channel offerings.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-377"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-377" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Raycom Sports previously distributed <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ACC_Network_(syndication_package)" title="ACC Network (syndication package)">ACC football and basketball game packages</a> to local over-the-air television stations throughout the U.S. from 1982 to 2010 (originally through a joint venture with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jefferson-Pilot_Communications" class="mw-redirect" title="Jefferson-Pilot Communications">Jefferson-Pilot Communications</a>,
 which transferred the syndication rights to its standalone ACC football
 package to the Raycom/Jefferson-Pilot venture in 2004). After ESPN 
acquired the ACC basketball and football rights in 2010, it reached a 
sublicensing deal with Raycom Sports that allowed the latter to continue
 the syndicated package, which was primarily distributed to 
cable-originated regional sports networks (including <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Sports_Networks" title="Fox Sports Networks">Fox Sports Networks</a>,
 whose Raycom/ACC contract was carried over to Diamond Sports Group 
after its 2018 purchase of the networks from Disney/Fox and their 
subsequent rebranding as Bally Sports).</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-386"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-386" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <i>NextTV</i> article erroneously identified WHAG as a CW affiliate; <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WDCW" title="WDCW">WDCW</a> (which Nexstar acquired in 2019 through its purchase of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tribune_Media" title="Tribune Media">Tribune Media</a>) has exclusively served as the CW affiliate for the Washington, D.C. market since the network's 2006 debut.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-393"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-393" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The video was later re-edited to remove footage from an <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlanta" title="Atlanta">Atlanta</a>-area <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_Lives_Matter" title="Black Lives Matter">Black Lives Matter</a> protest, excerpted from Fox O&amp;O <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WAGA" class="mw-redirect" title="WAGA">WAGA</a> (by way of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Television_Stations" title="Fox Television Stations">Fox Television Stations</a>-
owned streaming news service LiveNOW from Fox), that was not properly 
cleared before its original release; this version of the "Try That in a 
Small Town" music video was uploaded to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a> on July 26.<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>369<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-399"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-399" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Arizona Diamondbacks had been carrying their regional telecasts on Bally Sports Arizona since the team's inception in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1998_Arizona_Diamondbacks_season" title="1998 Arizona Diamondbacks season">1998</a> (when the network went by its original identity as Fox Sports Arizona).</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-406"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-406" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Event
 rights to the NASCAR Xfinity Series have either been split between 
broadcast and cable networks on a per-race basis or have been 
cable-exclusive since the series' 1982 inception as the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Budweiser" title="Budweiser">Budweiser</a> Late Model Sportsman Series.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-490"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-490" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netflix" title="Netflix">Netflix</a>'s YouTube channel, before moving to Netflix itself in 2024.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-494"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-494" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><i>Dancing with the Stars</i> previously aired on ABC from its premiere in 2005 until 2021; Disney+, which streamed <i>DWTS</i> exclusively for its <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dancing_with_the_Stars_(American_season_31)" class="mw-redirect" title="Dancing with the Stars (American season 31)">31st season</a> in 2022, will continue to livestream the program simultaneous with the ABC telecast.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-500"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-500" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"Get Stewie", which aired on November 20, 2022, was publicized as the 400th episode.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-762"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-762" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"Golazo" is a Spanish soccer term, meaning "great goal".</span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>
